Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: Here bigynneth the prolog of this book the which is namede the talis of Cauntur bury in the whiche pro log thautour openly declarith the names of alle the pilgremes there condicioıı̄uns ⁊and there array
Whan that Apprill with his shouris soote
The drought of Marche hath ꝑpershid to the roote
And bathed eủery veyne in swich licoure
Of which v̉ertue / engendrid is the floure
Whan zepherus eke / with his swete breth
Inspirid hath in eủery holt ⁊and hethe
The tendre croppis / ⁊and the yonge sonne
Hath in the Ram / his halff cours I ronne
And smale fowlis make melodie
That slepen al nyght / with open eyghe
So priketh hem nature / in here coragis
That longen folk to gon / on pilgⁱmagis
And Palmeris for to seke strange strondes
To serue halowes couthe / in sondre londes
And specially / from eủery shiris ende
Of Ingelond to Caunturbery thei wende
The holy blisfull mart̉er / for to seke
That hem hath holpen / whan thei were seke /
Bifill that on that sesoıı̄un on a day
In Suthwork atte Tabard as I lay
Redy to wende / on my pilgⁱmage
To Caunt̉erbury / with ful deuout corage
At night was come / in to that hosterie
Wel . xxixᵗⁱ . in a companye
Of sondry folk / bi auenture I falle
In feloship / ⁊and pilgremes were thei alle
That toward Caunt̉erbury wolde ryde
The chambres ⁊and stablis weren wyde
And wel weren eased at the beste
And shortly whan the sonne was to reste
So hadde I spokyn / with hem eủerychon
That I was of here feloship anon
And made forward erly for to ryse
To take oure wey / there as I yow devise
But nertheles while I haue tyme ⁊and space
Or that I ferther in this tale pace
Me thynketh it acoordaıı̄unt to resoıı̄un
To telle yow al the condicioıı̄un
Of ech of hem so as it semed me
And which they were ⁊and of what degre
And eke in what array that thei were inne
And at a knyght than woll I first bigynne
A knyght ther was / ⁊and that a worthi man
That fro the tyme / that he first bigan
To riden owt / he loued chyualrie
Trouth ⁊and honour / fredom ⁊and curtesie
Ful worthi was he / in his lordis werre
And ther to had he riden / no man ferre
As wel in cristendom / as in hethenesse
And eủere honoured / for his worthynesse
At Alisandre he was whan it was wonne
Ful ofte tyme he hadde the bord bigonne
Aboven alle nacōns in Pruce
In Lectow hadde he reysed ⁊and in Ruce
No cristenman / so ofte of his degre
In Garnade at the sege eke hadde he be
Of Algezire ⁊and riden in Belmarye
At Lyeis was he ⁊and at Satalye
Whan thei were wonne ⁊and in the grete See
At many a noble arme hadde he be
At mortal batailles had he ben Fiftene
And foughten for our feith at Tramessene
In listes thries ⁊and ay slayn his foo
This ilke worthi knyght hadde ben also
Somtyme with the lord of Palatye
Ayeyne another hethen in Turkye
And eủere more he had a soủerayne prys
And though that he was worthy he was wys .
And of his port as meke as is a mayde
He neủere yit no vilonye ne saide
In al his liff / vn no mane wight
He was a verry ꝑparfit gentill knight
For to tellen yow . of his array
His hors were gode / but he was not gay
Of fustioıı̄un he wered a gepoıı̄un
Al bi smotered with his haburgeoıı̄un
For he was late I come from his viage
And wente for to don / his pilgrimage
With him ther was his sone a yonge Squyere
A loviere ⁊and a lusty bachelere
With lokkes crulle as thei were leyde in presse
Of . xxᵗⁱ . yere of age / he was I gesse
Of his stature he was of evene lengthe
And wonderli delivere ⁊and grete of strengthe .
And he had be somtyme in chyuachie
In Flaundres in Artoys ⁊and Picardie .
And born him wel as of so litill space
In hope to stonden in his lady grace .
Embroyded was he as it were a mede
Al ful of fresshe floures white ⁊and rede
Syngynge he was or floityng al the day
He was as fressh as is the moneth of may
Short was his gowne with slevis longe ⁊and wide
Wel cowde he sitte on an hors ⁊and faire ride
He cowde songes make ⁊and wel endite
Iuste ⁊and eke daunce ⁊and wel portrey ⁊and write
So hote he loued that bi night̉er tale
He slepte no more than doth anightyngale
Curteys he was lowly ⁊and suysable
And karff biforn his fader at the table .
A yeman hadde he ⁊and ʆseruantes no mo
At that tyme for him liste ride so
And he was clad in coote ⁊and hood of grene
A sheeff of pecok arwes bright ⁊and ken
Vnder his belt he bar ful thrifftyly
Wel couth he dresse his takell yomānly
His arwes drouped not with fetheris lowe
In his hond he bar a mighti bowe
A not hed hadde he with a broun visage
Of wode craft wel couth he al thusage
Vppon his harme he bar agay bracer
And bi his side a swerde ⁊and a bokeler
And on that other side agay daggere
Harneysed wel ⁊and sharp as poynt of spere
A xpophre on his breste of siluer shene
An horn he bar the bawderike was of grene
A foster was he sothly as I gesse
Ther was also a Nonne a Prioresse
That of hir smylyng was ful symple ⁊and coy
Hir grettest ooth was but bi seint loy
And she was cleped madame Englentyne
Ful wel she songe the ʆseruyse dyuine
Entuned in hir nose ful semely
And frenssh she spak ful faire ⁊and fetisly
After the scole of Stratford atte Bowe
For frenssh of Paris was to hir vnknowe
At meete wel I taught was she with alle
She leet no morsell from hir lippes falle
Ne wette hir fyngres in hir savse depe
Wel couth she carye a morsell ⁊and wel kepe
That no droppe ne fil vppon hir breste
In curtesie was sette ful mechel hir leste
Hir oủerlippe wiped she so clene
That in hir cuppe th̉ere was no ferthyng sene
Of grece whan she hadde dronken hir draughte
Ful semely after hir meete she raughte
And sekerly she was of grete disporte
And ful plesaunte ⁊and amyable of porte
And peyned hir to counterfete chere
Of courte / ⁊and to ben estatlich of manere
And to ben holden digne of reủerence
But for to speken of hir conscience
She was so charitable ⁊and pitous
She wolde wepe yiff that she saw amous
Kaught in a trappe if it were ded or bledde
Of smale houndis had she that she fedde
With rosted flessh or mylke or wastelbrede
But soore wept she if oon of hem were dede
Or if men smote it with a yerde smerte
And al was conscience ⁊and tendre herte
Ful semlich hir wympil pynched was
Hir nose was streight hir eyghen grey as glas
Hir mouth ful smal . ⁊and ther to softe ⁊and rede
But sekerly she hadde a faire forhede
It was almost a spanne brood I trowe
For hardly she was nought vndirgrowe
Ful fetis was hir cloke as I was war
A smal coral abowte hir arme she bar
A peire of bedis gavded al with grene
And ther on heng a broch of gold ful shene
On which ther first wreten a crowned A .
And after Amor vincit omnia .
Another Nonne with hir had she
That was hir chapeleyne ⁊and prestes thre .
A Monke ther was a faire for the maistrie
An owtrider that loued venorie
A manly man to ben an abbot able
Ful many a deynte hors hadde he in stable
And whan he rood men myghte his bridel here
Gyngelyng in a whistlyng wynde as clere
And eke as lowde as doth the chapel belle
Ther as this lord was keper of the celle
The rewle of seint Mavre / or of seint Benet
Bi cause that it was olde ⁊and somdel streit
This ilke monke leet olde thinges pace
And helde after the newe world the trace
He yaff nought of the text a pulled hen
That seith that hunters ben nought holy men .
Ne that a monke whan he is recheles
Is likned to a fyssh that is waterles
That is to seie amonke owt of his cloystre
But thilke text held he nought worth a noystre
And I seide his opynyon was goode
What shulde he studie / ⁊and make him silff woode
Vppon a book alday in cloystre to poure
Or swynke with his houndes ⁊and laboure
As Austyn bit how shal the world be sued
Lat Austyn haue his swynke to hym reʆserued
Ther fore he was a prikasour a right
Grehoundes he hadde as swifft as foule in flight
Of prikyng ⁊and huntyng for the hare
Was al his luste for no cost wolde he spare
I say his slevis I purfiled at the honde
With grys and that the fyneste in a londe
And for to fastne his hood vndir the chynne
He hadde of gold wrought a ful curious pynne
A love knotte in the grett̉er ende ther was
His hed was balled that shon as eny glas
And eke his face as he hadde ben anoynt
He was a lord ful fatt ⁊and in good poynt
His eighen stepe ⁊and rollyng in his hede
That stemed as a forneys of lede
His botis souple his hors in gret estate
Now c̉erteīnly he was a faire prelate
He nas nought pale as a forpyned goost
A fatt swan louede he beste of any roost
His palfray was as broun as is a berye
A Frere ther was a wantoun ⁊and a merye
A lymytour a ful solempne man
In al the ordres foure is noon that can
So mechel of Daliaunce ⁊and faire langage
He hadde made ful many a Mariag
Of yonge wōmmen at his owne coost
Vn to his ordre he was a noble poost
Ful wel biloued ⁊and famulier was he
With Frankeleyns oủer al in his contre
And with worthi wōmmen of the town
For he hadde power of confessioıı̄un
As seide him selff more than a curat
For of his ordre he was licenciat
Ful swetely herde he confessioıı̄un
And plesaunt was his absolucioıı̄un
He was an esy man to yeff penaunce
Ther as he wiste to haue a good pitaunce
For vn to a poure ordre for to yive
Is signe that a man is wel I shrive
For if he yaff he dorste make auaunt
He wiste that a man was repentaunt
For many a man so hard is of his herte
He may nought wepe al though hīm sore smerte
Therfore in stede of wepyng ⁊and preyeres
Men mote yeve siluer to the poure freres
His tepet was ay farsed ful of knyvis
And pynnes for to yeve to faire wivis
And c̉erteinly he hadde a mery note
Wel cowde he syngen ⁊and pleyen on a rote
Of tydyngges bar he witt̉erli the pris
His nekke was whight as the floure delys
Ther to he was strong as a champioıı̄un
He knewe the taủernes wel in eủery toıı̄un
And eủerich hostiller ⁊and tapster
Bet than a lazar or a begger
For vn to swich a worthi man as he
Accorded nought as bi his faculte
To haue with swich sike lazar a queyntaunce
It is nought honest it may not avaunce
For to delen with swich poraille
But al with riche ⁊and sellers of vitaill
And oủeral ther as ꝓprofit shulde a rise
Curteys he was ⁊and lowly of ʆseruyse
Ther nas no man nowher so v̉ertuous
He was the beste begger in his hous
For though a widewe hadde not a sho
So plesaunt was his In principio
Yit wolde he haue a ferthing or he wente
His purchace was wel bett̉er than his rente
And rage he couth right as it were a whelpe
In louedaies ther cowde he mech helpe
For ther he was not lich a cloystrer
With a thredbare cope as a poure scoler
But he was like a maist̉er or a pope
Of double worstede was his semy cope
That rounded as a belle out the presse
Somwhat he lipsede for his wantounesse
To make his englissh swete vppon his tonge
And in his har ping / whan that he hadde songe
His eighen twynklede in his hede a right
As don the sterris in the frosty night
This worthi lymitour was called Huberd
A marchaunt ther was with a forked berd
In mottle ⁊and high on hors he satte
Vppon his hede a flaundrissh beuer hatte
His botis clapsid faire ⁊and fetislye
His resoıı̄uns he spak ful solempnelye
Shewyng alwey thencres of his wynnynge
He wolde the see were kept for any thinge
Bitwixe Middelburgh ⁊and Orewelle
Wel coude he in eschaunge sheldes selle
This worthi man / so wel his witt bisette
Ther wiste no whight that he was in dette
So estatly was he of his goủernaunce
With his bargeynes ⁊and with his chevisaunce
For soth he was a worthi man with alle
But sothlich to seyn I not how men hīm calle
A clerke ther was of Oxonford also
That vn to logik hadde longe I go
As lene was his hors as is a rake
And he nas not right fatt I vndir take
But loked holowe ⁊and ther to soburly
Ful thredbare was his oủereste curteby
For he had geten hīm no benefice
Ne was so worldly to haue office
For hīm was lever haue at his beddis hede
. xxᵗⁱ . bookes clad in blak ⁊and rede
Of Aristotle ⁊and his philosophie
Than robes riche or fithel or gay sawtrie
But al be that he was a Philosophre
Yit hadde he but litil gold in cofre
But al that he myghte of his frendes hente
On bookes ⁊and in lernyng he it spente
And besily gan for tho soules praye
Of hem that fonde hīm wher with to scole aye .
Of studie toke he most cure ⁊and hede
Not o word spak he more than was nede
And that was seide / in forme ⁊and reủerence
And short ⁊and quyk / ⁊and ful of high sentence
Sownyng in moral v̉ertue was his speche
And gladly wolde he lerne / ⁊and gladli teche
A sergiant of the lawe war ⁊and wis
That often hadde ben at parvis
That was also ful riche of excellence
Discret he was ⁊and of gret reủerence
He semyd swich his wordes weren so wise
Iustice he was ful often in assise
Bi patent ⁊and bi pleyne cōmmissioıı̄un
For his science ⁊and for his high renoıı̄un
Of fees ⁊and robes hadde he many on
So grett̉er purchasour was nowher noon
Al was fee symple to hīm in effecte
His purchasing might not ben infect
Nowher so bisy a man as he ther nas
And yit he semyd besyer than he was
In termes hadde he caas ⁊and domes alle
That from the tyme of kyng william wer falle
Ther to he couth endite ⁊and make a thing
Ther coude no whight pynche at his writyng
And eủery statut couth he pleyne bi roote
He rood but homly in a medle coote
Girt with a seint of silk with barres smale
Of his array telle I no lenger tale
A Frankeleyne was in that companye
Whight was his berde as is the dayissye
Of his complexioıı̄un he was sangwyne
Wel loued he bi the morow a sop in wyne
To liven in delitte eủere was his wone
For he was Epiournes owne sone
That held opynyoıı̄un that pleyne delite
Was v̉erreye felicite ꝑparfite
An housholder ⁊and that a gret was he
Senyt Iulian he was in his contre
His bred his ale was alweys aft̉er one
A bett̉er envyned man was nowher none
With oute bakemete was neủere his hous
Of fissh ⁊and flessh ⁊and that so plentivous
It snewed in his hous of mete ⁊and drynke
Of alle deyntethis that men couth thinke
Aft̉er the sondry sesoıı̄uns of the yere
So changed he his mete ⁊and his sopere
Ful many a fatt partrich had he mewe
And many a brem ⁊and many a luce in stuwe
Wo was his coke but his sauce were
Poynaıı̄unt ⁊and sharpe ⁊and redy al his gere
His table dormant in his halle alway
Stood redy coủered al the longe day
At sessioıı̄uns ther was lord ⁊and sire
Ful ofte tyme he was knyght of the shire .
An analas ⁊and a gipser al of silke
Heng at his girdel whight as morne mylke
A shreve had he ben ⁊and
Was nowher swich a worthi vauasour
An haburdasshere ⁊and a Carpentere
A Webbe a Dyere ⁊and a Tapecere
And they were clothed alle in oo lyủere
Of a solempne ⁊and a gret frat̉ernite
Ful fressh ⁊and newe here gere I piked was
Here knyvis nere chaped nought with bras
But al with silủere wrought ful clene ⁊and well
Here girdellis ⁊and here povches eủerydell
Wel semed ech of hem a faire burgeys
To sytten in a yeldhalle on a deys
Eủerich for the wisdom that he can
Was shaply for to ben an Alderman
For catal hadde thei I nough ⁊and rente
And eke here wives wolde it wel assente
And ellis c̉erteyne thei were to blame
It is ful faire to be clepid madame
And gon to vigilies al byfore
And haue a mantel riallich I bore
A Cook thei hadde with hem for the nones
To boille the chikenes with the marie bones
And poudre marchānt tart ⁊and galyngale
Wel coude he knowe a draught of londoıı̄un ale
He couth roost ⁊and seth broille ⁊and frye
Maken mortreux ⁊and wel bake a pye
But gret harm was it a thoughte me
That on his shene a mormal hadde he
For blank manger that made he with the beste
A shipman was there wonyng fer bi weste
For ought I woot he was of Dertemouthe
He rood vppon a rouncy as he couthe
In a gowne of faldyng to the kne
A dagger hangynge in a lace hadde he
Abowte his necke vnder his harm down
The hote somer hadde made his huwe al brown
And c̉erteynly he was a good felawe
Ful many a draughte of wyn he hadde drawe
From Burdeux ward while the chapmen slepe
Of nyce conscience toke he no kepe
Iff that he faughte ⁊and hadde the higher honde
Biwat̉er he sente hem hom to eủery londe
But of his craft to riken wel his tydes
His stremes ⁊and his daunger him bisides
His herborewe ⁊and his moone ⁊and his lodemanage
Ther nas noon swich from Hulle to Cartage
Hardy he was ⁊and wys to vndertake
With many a tempest had his berd be shake
He knewe alle the havenes as they were
Fro Stotlond to the Cape Defynystere
And eủery Creke in Bretaigne ⁊and in Spayne
His barge clepid was the Mavdeleyne
With vs ther was a doctour of Phisike
In al this world ne was ther noon hīm like
To speke of Phisike ⁊and of Surgerye
For he was grounded in Astronomye
He kept his pacient a ful gret del
In houres bi his magik naturel
Wel couthe he fortune the ascendent
For his ymages for his pacient
He knewe the cause of eủerych maladie
Were it of hoot or colde or moiste or drye
And where engendred ⁊and of what humour
He was a verry ꝑparfite practisour
The cause I knowe ⁊and of his harm the rote
Anon he yaff the sike man his bote
Ful redy hadde he his appoticaries
To sende hem drugges ⁊and his lettuaries
For ech of hem made other for to wynne
Here frendship nas not newe to bigynne .
Wel knewe he the olde Escalapius
And discorides ⁊and eke Ruphus
Olde ypocras haly ⁊and Galyen
Serapion Razie ⁊and Avisen
Aueroys Damascien ⁊and Constantyne
Bernard Gatisdene ⁊and Gylbertyne
of his diete mesurable was he
For it was of no suꝑperfluyte
But of gret norsshing ⁊and digestible
His studie was but litel in the bible
In sangweyne ⁊and in pers he clad was al
Lyned with taffata ⁊and with sendal
And yit he was but esy of dispence
He kepte that he wan in pestilence
For gold in phisik is a cordial
Therfore he loved gold in special .
A good wiff ther was of be side Bathe
But she was somdel deff ⁊and that was scathe
Of cloth makinge / she hadde swich an haunte
She passed hem of Ipres ⁊and of Gaunte
and in al the parissh wiff was ther noon
That to the offryng to forn hir shulde goon
And if ther ded c̉erteyne wroth was she
That she was owte of alle charite
Hire coủerchiefs ful fyne were of grounde
I dorste swere they weyeden ten pounde
That on a sonday weren vppon hir hede
Hir hosyn weren of fyne scarlet rede
Ful streyte I tyede ⁊and shoos moiste ⁊and newe
Bolde was hir face ⁊and faire ⁊and rede of hewe
She was a worthi woman al hir lyve
Housbondes at the chirch dore she hadde fyve
Withouten other companye in youthe
But ther of nedith nought to speke as nouthe
And thries hadde she ben at Ierusalem
She hadde passid many a strange strem
At Rome she hadde ben ⁊and at Boloigne
In Galyce at seint Iame ⁊and at Coloigne
She couth mech on wandryng bi the weye
Gape tothed was she sothly for to seye
Vppon an ambler esily she satte
I wympled wel ⁊and on hir hede an hatte
As brood as is a bokeler or a targe
A foote mantel a bowte hir hepes large .
And on hir feete a peire of spores sharpe
In felowship wel couth she laughe ⁊and carpe
Of remedies of love she knewe ꝑpar chaunce
For she couth of that arte the colde daunce
A good man ther was of religioıı̄un
And was a poure ꝑperson of a town
But rich he was of holy thought ⁊and werk
He was also alerned man ⁊and a clerk
That cristis gospel truly wolde preche
His parisshyns deuoutly wolde he teche
Benigne he was ⁊and wonder diligent
And in adủersite ful pacient
And swich he was previd often sithes
Ful loth were him to cursen for his tithes
But rather wolde he yeven oute of doute
Vn to his poure parisshens aboute
Of his offryng ⁊and of his substaunce
He couth in litel thing haue suffisaunce
Wide was his parissh ⁊and houses fer a sondre
But he ne laft nought for rayne ne thondre
In sikenesse nor in myschief to visite
The ferreste in his parisshe meche ⁊and lite
Vppon his feete ⁊and in his honde a staff
This noble ensample to his shepe he yaff
That first he wrought ⁊and aft̉er that he taughte
Owte of the gospel he tho wordes kaughte
And this figure he addede eke ther to
That and yif gold ruste what shal Iren do .
For yf a preste be foule on whom we truste
No wonder is a lewde man to ruste
And shame it is if a prest take kepe
A shetyn shepherde ⁊and a clene shepe
Wel ought a preste ensample for to yeve
Bi his clennesse how that his shepe shulde live
He sette naught his bnfice to hire
And laft his shepe a combred in the myre
And ran to london vn to seint Poules
To seke him a chauntrie for soules
Or with a britherhede / to ben witholde
But dwelte at hom ⁊and kepte wel his folde
So that the wolff ne made it not myscarye
He was a shepeherde ⁊and not a mercenarye
And though he holy were ⁊and v̉ertuous
He was nought to synful men dispitous
Ne of his speche dangerous ne digne
But in his techyng discret ⁊and benigne
To drawen folk to heuen bi fairnesse
Bi good ensample this was his besynesse
But hit were ony ꝑparsoıı̄un obstinate
What so he were of high or lowe estate
Him wolde he snebbe sharply for the nones
A bett̉er preest I trowe that nowhere non es
He waytede after no pompe ⁊and reủerence
Ne maked him no spiced conscience
But cristis lore ⁊and his apostelis twelve
He tawte / but first he folwede it him selve .
With him ther was a plowman was his brother
That hadde I ladde of donge ful many a fother
And a trewe swynker ⁊and a good was he
Livynge in pees ⁊and ꝑparfite charite
God loued he beste with al his herte
At alle tymes though he gamede or smerte
And than his neighebore right as him selve
He wolde thresshe ⁊and ther to dike ⁊and delve
For cristis sake for eủery poure whight
Withoute hire yf it lay in his myght
His tithes paied he ful faire ⁊and wel
Bothen of his propre swynke ⁊and his catel
In a Tabard he rood vppon a Mere
There was also a Reve ⁊and a Millere
A Sompnour ⁊and a Pardoner also
A Maunciple ⁊and my selff ther were no mo
The Millere was a stoute carle for the nones
Ful bigg he was of brawne ⁊and of bones
That preved wel for oủeral thare he cam
At wrastlyng he wolde haue a wey the Ram
He was short shuldred a thikke knarre
The was no dore but he wolde heve of barre
Or breke it at a rennyng with his hede
His berd as any sowe or fox was reede
And ther to brood as though it were a spade
Vppon the cop right of his nose haade
A werte ⁊and theron stood a tufte of heeris
Rede as the berstelis of a sowes Eris
His nose thrillis blak were ⁊and wide
A swerd ⁊and a bokeler / bar he bi his side
His movthe as gret was / as a fourneys
He was a Iangler ⁊and a goliardeys
And that was most of synne ⁊and of harlotrie
Wel couthe he stele corn ⁊and tolle thrie
And yit he hadde a thombe of gold parde
A whighte coote ⁊and a bliewe hood wered he
Abaggepipe wel couthe blowe ⁊and sown
And therwithal he brought vs owt of town
A gentil Maunciple was there of a temple
Of which a catour myght take ensample
For to ben wise in biyng of vitaylle
For whethir he paiede or toke bi taylle
Algate he wayted so in his a chate
That he was ay aforn ⁊and in good estate
Now is not that of god a ful faire grace
That swich a lewid mannys witte shal pace
The wisdom of an hepe of lernede men
Of maistres hadde he mo than thries ten
That were of lawe expert ⁊and curious
Of which ther were a doseyne in that hous
Worthi to ben Stiwardes of rente ⁊and londe
Of any lord that is in al Ingelonde
To make him live with his ꝓpropre good
In honour detteles but yf that he were wood
Or live as scarsly as him list desire
And able for to helpen al a shire
In any caas that mighte falle or happe
And yit this maunciple sette ther alther cappe .
The Reve was a sclendir colorik man
His berd was shave as nygh as eủere he can
His heer was bi his eeris ful rounde I shorne
His toppe was docked lik a preest bi forne
Ful longe were his legges ⁊and ful lene
I like a staff ther was no calff I sene
Wel couthe he kepe a garner or a bynne
Ther was noon Auditour couthe on him wynne
Wel wiste he bi the droughthe ⁊and bi the reyne
The yeldyng of his seed ⁊and of his greyne
His lordis shepe his nete his dayerie
His swyn his hors his stoor his pulletrie
Was hooly in this reves goủernynge
And bi his couenaunt yaff the rikenynge
Syn that his lord was twenty yere of age
Ther couthe noman bringe him in arrerage
Ther nas bailliff ne herde ne other hyne
That he ne knewe his sleight ⁊and his covyne
They were adrad of him as of the deth
His wonynge was ful faire vppon an heth
With grene trees shadewed was his place
He couthe bette than his lord purchace .
Ful riche he was a stored privily
His lord he couth wel plesen subtyly
To yive ⁊and lene him / of his owne good
And haue a thanke ⁊and yit a cote ⁊and hood
In youthe he hadde lerned a good mystere
He was a wel good whrighte a carpenter
This Reve satte vppon a wel good stot
That was pomly grey ⁊and highte scot
A long surcote of peers vppon he hadde
And bi his side he bar a rusty bladde
Of Northfolk was this reve of which I telle
Biside a town men clepen it Bladeswelle
Tukked he was as is a frere a bowte
And eủere he rood the hyndereste of our rowte
A Sompnour was ther with vs in that place
That hadde a firy cherubynnes face
For savseflem he was with eyghen narwe
Als hoote he was ⁊and lecherous as a sparwe
With scalled browes blak ⁊and piled berde
Of his visage children weren a ferde
Ther quyk siluer litarge or bremston
Boras orsure ne oyelle of tartre noon
Ne oynement that wolde clennce ⁊and bite
That him myghte helpe of his whelkes whighte
Nor of the knobbes sittyng in his chekes
Wel loued he garlik oynons ⁊and eke lekes
And for to drinke stronge wyn reede as blood
Than wolde speke ⁊and crie as he were wood .
And whan he hadde wel dronken the wyne
Than wolde he speke no worde but latyne
A fewe t̉ermes hadde he two or thre
That he hadde lerned owt of som decre
No wonder is he herde it all the day
And ek ye knowen it wel / how that a Iay
Can clepe watte / as wel as can the pope
But ho so couthe in other thing him grope .
Than hadde he spent al his philosophie
Ay questio quid iuris wolde he crie
He was agentil harlot ⁊and a kynde
A better felowe shulde no men fynde
He wolde suffre for a quarte of wyn
A good felowe to haue his concubyn
A twelf moneth ⁊and excuse him atte fulle
Ful privily ek a fynch couthe he pulle
And yf he founde owher a good felawe
He wolde techyn him to haue noon awe
In swich caas of the Archidekyns curs
But yf mannys soule were in his purs
For in his purs he sholde punysshed be
Purs is the Archideknes helle seide he
But wel I woot he lyhede right in dede
Of cursyng oughte ech gilty man him drede
For curs wol sle right as a soillyng savith
And also war him of a significauith
In daungere hadde he at his owne gyse
The yonge gerles of al the diocise
And knewe here consaille ⁊and what was al her rede
A garland hadde he sette / vppon his hede
As gret as it were for an ale stake
A bokeler hadde he made him of a cake
With him ther rood agentil ꝑpardoner
Of Rounvale his frende ⁊and his comper
That streight was comen fro the court of Rome
Ful lowde songe he come hider love to me
This sōmpnour bar to him a stiff burdoıı̄un
Was neủere trompe of halff so gret a sown
This pardoner hadde heere as yolowe as wax
But smowthe it heng as doth a strike of flax
Bi ounces henge his lokkes that he hadde
And therwith he his shildres oủerspradde
But thynne it lay bi culpons oon ⁊and oon
But hood for iolyte werede he noon
For it was trussed vp / in his walet
Him thoughte he rood al of the newe get
Discheuele saf his cappe he rood al bare
Swich glaryng eyghen hadde he as an hare
A vernycle hadde he sewid vppon his cappe
His walet biforn him in his lappe
Bret ful of ꝑpardoıı̄un comen fro Rome al hoote
A voys he hadde as smal as a goote
No berd hadde he ne neủere shulde haue
As smothe it was as it were late shaue
I trowe he were a geldyng or a mare
But of his crafft fro Berwyke in to ware
Ne was ther swich a nother Pardoner
For in his male he hadde a pelewber
Which that he seide was our lady veylle
He seide he hadde a gobet of the seylle
That seint Peter hadde whan that he wente
Vppon the see til ihu crist him hente
He hadde a croys of latoıı̄un ful of stones
And in a glas he hadde pigges bones
But with these relikes whan that he fonde
A poure ꝑpersoıı̄un dwelling vppon londe
Vppon a day he gat him more moneye
Than the ꝑpersoıı̄un gat in monethis tweye
And thus with feyned flatryng ⁊and Iapes
He made the ꝑperson ⁊and the peple his Apes
But trwly to tellen at the laste
He was in chirche a noble ecciaste
Wel couthe rede a lessoıı̄un or a story
But alderbest he song an offertory
For wel he wiste whan that song was songe
He moste preche ⁊and wel affile his tonge
To wynne seluer as he wel cowde
Ther fore he songe so merily ⁊and lowde
Now haue I tolde yow sothly in a clause
Thestate . the araye the nombre ⁊and eke the cause
Whi that assembled was this companye
In Suthwerk at this gentill hostrie
That highte the Tabard faste bi the belle
But now is tyme to yow for to telle
How that we beren vs that ilke night
Whan we were in that hostrie alight
And aft̉er wol I tellen of our viage
And al the remanent of our Pilgrimage
And first I praye yow of your curtecie
That ye ne rette it nought my vilonye
Though that I pleynly speke in this matere
To tellen here wordes ⁊and here chere
Ne though I speke here wordes ꝓpropurly
For this ye knowen as wel as I
Who so shal tellen a tale aft̉er a man
He mot reherce as nyghe as eủere he can
Eủery worde yf it be in his charge
Al speke he neủere so rudely ⁊and large
Or elles he mot telle his tale vn trewe
Or feyne thinges or fynde wordes newe
He may nought spare al though he were his brother
He mote also wel seye o worde as a nother
Criste spak hīm silff ful brode in holy writte
And wel ye wot no vilonye is hitte
Eke Plato seith whoso can him reede
The wordes mote be cosyn to the deede
Also I praye yow for yeve it me
Al haue I nought sette folk in here degre
Here in these talis as thei shulde stonde
My witte is short / ye may wel vndir stonde
Greet chere made our host to vs eủerychon
And to the soper sette he vs anoon .
And served vs with vitailles at the beste
Strong was the wyn ⁊and wel drynke vs leste
A semly man our oost was with alle
For to ben a marchall in an halle .
A large man hewas with eyghen stepe
A fairer burgeys is noon in chepe
Bold of his spech wys ⁊and wel I taughte
And of manhode him lakked right naughte .
Eke therto he was right a mery man
And aft̉er soper pleyen he bigan
And spak of merthe among ⁊and other thinges
Whan that we hadde made our rikenynges
And seide thus / Now lordynges trwely
Ye ben to me welcome right hertely
For bi my trouthe yf that I shal not lye
I saw not this yere so mery a companye
At oones in this herburgh as is now
Fayne wolde I don yow merthe wiste I how
And of a merthe I am right now bi thought
To don yow ease ⁊and it shal coste yow nought
¶ Ye goon to Caunturbury god yow spede
The blisful martir quyte yow your mede
And wel I woot as ye goon bi the weye
Ye shapen yow to talkyn ⁊and to pleye
For truly conforte ne merthe is noon
To riden bi the wey dombe as a stoon .
And therfore wol I makyn yow disporte
As I seide arst ⁊and don yow som conforte
And yf yow like alle bi oon assente
For to stonden at my iugemente
And for to werkyn as I shal yow seye
To morow whan we riden bi the weye
¶ Now bi my fader soule that is ded
But ye be merye I wol lese myn hed
Holde vp youre hondes withoute more speche
Oure counsaille was not longe for to seche
Vs thought it was not worth to make it wys
And graunted him withoute more advys
And bad him sey his verdite as him leste
Lordynges qd he now herkneth for the beste .
But take it nought I praie yow in disdeyne
This is the poynt to speke shorte ⁊and pleyne
That ech of yow to shorte with oure weye
In this viage shal telle talis tweye
To Caunturburyward I mene it so
And homwardes he shal telle other two
Of auentures that whilom haue bifalle
And which of yow that berith him best of alle
That is to seyn that tellith in this caas
Talis of best sentence ⁊and most solaas
Shal haue a soper at our alder coste
Here in this place sittyng bi this poste .
Whan that we comen ageyn fro Caunturbury
And for to make yow the more mery
I wol my silff goodly with yow ride
Right at myn owne coste ⁊and be your gyde
And who so wol my Iuggement with seye
Shal pay al that we spende bi the weye
And yf ye vouchesaf that it be soo
Telle me a noon withouten wordes moo
And I wol erly shape me therfore
This thing was graunted ⁊and our othes swore
With ful glad herte ⁊and praied him also
That he wolde vouchesauff for to do soo .
And that he wolde be oure goủernour
And of oure talis Iugge ⁊and reportour .
And sette a soper / at a c̉erteyne prys
And we wol rewled ben at his devys
In hygh ⁊and lough ⁊and this bi oon assente
We ben accorded to the Iuggemente
And ther vppon the wyn was fet anoon
We dronken ⁊and to reste wente echoon
Withouten eny lenger tariyng
Amorowe whan the day gan to spryng .
Vp roos oure oste ⁊and was oure alder cok
And gaderede vs to gyder in a flok .
And forthe we riden a litil more than paas
Vn to the wateryng of seynt Thomas .
And there our hoste gan his hors areste
And seide lordes herkneth yf yow leste
Ye woot youre forward ⁊and I it wol recorde
Yif euvensong ⁊and morowsong accorde .
Lat se now who shal telle the firste tale
As eủere mot y drynke wyn or ale
Who so be rebell to my Iuggement
Shal paie for al that bi the weye is spent .
Now drawith Cutte or that we ferther twynne
Which hath the shorteste shal begynne .
Sir knyght qd he my maister ⁊and my lorde
Now drawith Cut for that is myn accorde
Cometh nere qd he my lady prioresse
And ye sir clerke lat be your shamestfastnesse
Ne studieth nought lay honde to eủery man
Anoon to drawe eủery whight bigan
And shortly for to tellen as it was
Were it bi auenture or sorte or cas
The soth is this the cut fel to the knyght
Of which ful blithe ⁊and glad was eủery whight
And tellen he moste his tale as it was resoıı̄un
Bi forward ⁊and by composicioıı̄un
As ye han herde what nedith wordes moo
And whan this good man saw that it was soo .
As he that wys was ⁊and obedient
To kepen his forward bi his fre assent
He seide sitthen I shal bigynne the game
What welcome be the cut a goddes name
Now lat vs ride ⁊and herneth what I seie
And with that word we reden forth our weie
And he bigan with right a mery chere
His tale anoon ⁊and seide as ye may here .
Here endith the prolog of this book
(base) And next folwith the knyghtis tale of Arcyte ⁊and Palamon
Whilom as olde stories tellen vs
Ther was a Duke that hight Theseus
Of Athenes he was lord ⁊and goủernour
And in his tyme swich a conquerour
That gretter was noon vnder the sonne
Ful many a riche contre hadde he wonne
What with his wysdom ⁊and his chivalrie
He conquered al the regne of Femynye

div.l: And brought hir hom with him to his contre
With mech glorie ⁊and gret solempnite
And eke hir yonge suster Emelye
And thus with victorie ⁊and with melodie
Late I this noble Duk to Athenes ride
And al his oost in armes him biside
And cirtis yf it nere to longe to heere
I wolde haue tolde fully the manere
How wonnen was the londe of Femenye
Bi Theseus ⁊and bi his chivalrie
And of the gret bataille for the nones
Bitwixen Athenes ⁊and Amazones
And how assegid was Ypolyta
The faire hardy queene of Scithia
And of the feste that was at hir weddyng͗ e
And of the tempest at hir hom comyng͗ e
But al that thing I mote as now forbere
I haue god woot alarge feld to eere
And weyk ben the oxen in my plough
The remanent of the tale is long I nough
I wol nat letten eke noon of this rounte
Lat eủery felawe telle his tale abovte
And lat se now who shal the soper wynne
And there I lafte I wol ayen bigynne
This duc of whom I make mencion
Whan he was comen almoost to the toun
In al his wele ⁊and his moost pride
He was war as he cast his eighe aside
Wher͗e that ther kneled in the heighe weie
A company of ladies tweie ⁊and tweye
Eche aft̉er other clad in clothis blake
But swich a crie ⁊and swich a woo thei make
That in this ths this world nys creature levynge
That herde swich another weymentynge
And of this crie thei neủere wolde stente
Til thei the reynes of his bridel hente
What folk ben ye that at myn hom comynge
ꝐPerturben so my feste with criynge
Qduod Theseus haue ye so gret envie
Of myn honour that thus compleyne ⁊and crie
Or who hath yow mysboden ⁊and offended
And tellith me yf it may be amended
And whi that ye ben clothed thus in blak
The eldeste lady of hem alle spak
Whan she had swonned with a dedly chere
That it was routhe for to sen ⁊and here

Theseus ¶ She seide lord to whom fortune hath yeven
Victorie ⁊and as a conquerour to leven
Nat grevith vs your͗e glorie ⁊and honour͗e
But we biseke m̉ercy ⁊and socour͗e
Haue m̉ercy on oure wo ⁊and oure distresse
Som drope of pite thorugh your͗e gentilenesse
Vppon vs wrecched wymen lat yow falle
For c̉ertes lord ther is noon of vs alle
That she nath ben a duchesse or a queene
Now be we caytevis as it is wel seene
Thanked be fortune ⁊and hir fals whell
That noon estat ensurith for to ben well
Now c̉ertes lord to abide youre p̉ersence
Here in this temple of godesse Clemence
We haue be waityng al this fourtenyght
Helpe vs lord sithe it is in your͗e myght
I wrecche which that wepe ⁊and weylle thus
Was whilom wiff of kyng Camppaneus
That starff at Thebes cursed be that day
And alle we that ben in this aray
And maken al this lamentacioıı̄un
We lofte alle our͗e housbondes at that toun̄
While that thassege ther͗e abought lay
And yit now thoolde Creon wellaway
That lord is now / of Thebes cite
Fulfilled of Ire ⁊and of iniquyte
He for dispite ⁊and for his tirannye
To don̄ the ded bodies vilonye
Of alle oure lordes which that ben slawe
Hath alle the bodies on an hepe I drawe
And wol not suffre hem bi noon assent
Neither to ben I buried neither I brent
But makith houndes ete hem in dispit
And with that word withoute more respit
Thei Thi Thei fullen gruff ⁊and crieden pitously
Haue on vs wrecched wȳmmen som mercy
And lat oure sorowe synkyn in your͗e herte
This gentil Duc down̄ from his curser͗e sterte
With herte pitous whan he herde hem speke
Him thought his herte wolde breke
Whan he saw hem so pitous ⁊and so maate
That whilom were of so gret estate
And in his armes he hem alle vp hente
And hem hem conforteth in ful ful ful good entente
And swore his hooth as he was trewe knyght
He wolde don̄ so ferforthly his myght
Vpon the tiraunt Creon hem to wreke
That al the peple of Grece shulde speke
How Creon was of Theseus I served
As he that hadde his deth ful wel deserved
And right anoon withouten more abode
His baner he displayede ⁊and forth rode
To Thebes ward ⁊and al his oost biside
No nerre Athenes wolde he go ne ride
Ne take his ease fully halff a day
But onward on his way that night helay
And sente anoon Ypolyta the queene
And Emelye hir yonge suster shene
Vnto the town̄ of Athenes ⁊and ther͗e to dwelle
And forth he ritte ther is no more to telle
¶ The rede statue of Mars with sper͗e ⁊and targe
So shyneth in his whighte baner large
That alle the feldis gliteren vp ⁊and down̄
And bi his baner born̄ was his pynown̄
Of gold ful riche in which ther was I bete
The Mynataur which that he wan in Crete
Thus right this duk thus right this conquerour
And in his oost of chivalrtie the flour͗e
Til that he com to Thebnes ⁊and a light
Faire in a felde ther͗e as he thought to fight
But shortli for to spekin of this thing͗e
With Creon which that was of Thebes kinge͗e
He faught ⁊and slough him manly as a knyght
In pleyne bataille ⁊and put his folk to flight
And bi assavte he wan the Cite after
And rente a down̄ bothe wall spere ⁊and rafter

¶ Here Duc Theseus
distroyed Thebes ·And to the ladies restored the agayne
The bones of ther͗e frendis that were slayne
To don̄ obsequies as was tho the gyse
But it were al to longe for to devise
The grete clamour ⁊and the waymentyng͗e
That the ladies made at the brennyng͗e
Of the bodies ⁊and the grete honour͗e
That Theseus the noble conquerour͗e
Doth to the bodies whan thei from him wente
But shortli to tellen is myn entente
Whan that this worthi Duc this Theseus
Hath Creon slayn ⁊and wonne Thebes thus
Stille in that felde took al night his reste
And did with al the contre as him leste
To ransake in the caas of the bodies dede
Hem for to stripe of harneys ⁊and of wede
The piloures diden bisynes ⁊and cure
After the bataille ⁊ and the disconfiture
And so bifille in the caas they founde
Thorugh girt with many a grevous wounde
Two yonge knyghtes liggyng͗e bi ⁊and by

But Penneus dought̉er / which that high Dane
¶ Ther saw I Attheon / an herte I maked
For vengiaunce that he saw Dyane al naked
I saw there how his houndis han him caught
And freten him / for thei knew him naught
Yit I peynted was / a litil forthermore
How Arthalaunce hunted the wilde bore
And Meliagre / ⁊and many other moo
For which Dyane / wrought him care ⁊and woo
Ther̉e saw I many another wonder storie
The which me list not / to drawe in memorie
This godde vap an herte / ful wel she seete
And smale houndis / al abought hir feete
And vnder hir feete / she had a Moone
Wexyng it was / ⁊and shulde wanye soone
In gaudy grene hir statue / clothid was
With bowe in honde / ⁊and arwis / in a caas
Hir yghen cast she ful lowe a doun̄
There Pluto hath his derke regioıı̄un
A woman travailyng / was hir biforn̄
But for hir child was so long vnborn̄
Ful pitously lucyna / gan she calle
And seide helpe / for thow maist best of alle
Wel coude he he peynte lifly / that it wroughte
With many a floreyne / he the clolours cllours colours boughte
¶ Now ben these listes made / and Theseus
That at his grete cost / hath arayed thus
The templez temple templez ⁊and the theatre eủerydel
Whan it was don̄ / him liked wonder wel
But stynte I wol of Theseus a lite
And speke of Palamon / ⁊and of Arcite
The day approchith / of here retournyng
That eủerych shulde / an hundred knyghtes bryng̉e
The bataille to darrayne / as I yow tolde
And to Athenes / her̉e couenaunt to holde
Hath eủerych of hem brought / an hundred knyghtis
Wel armed / for werre / at alle rightis
And sekerly / there trowed many a man
That neủere sith the world bigan
That for to speke / of knyghthod of here honde
As ferre as god / hath maked see ⁊and londe
Nas of so fewe / so noble a companye
For eủery wight / that loued chyualrie
And wolde his thankes / haue a passaunt name
Hath praide that he myght be of that game
And wel was him / that therto chosēn was
For if ther fil to morow / such a caas
Ye knowen wel / that eủery lusty knyght
That loueth paramours / ⁊and hath myght
Were in Englonde / or elles where
They wolde fayne / wilned to be there
¶ To fight for a lady / a bn̄enedicite
Hit were a lusty sight for to se
And right so ferden thei / with Palamon
With him there wenten knyghtes many oon
Sōmme wol be armed / in an habergion
And a brestplate / ⁊and a lighte gippon
And som̄me wil haue / a peire platis large
And sōmme wil haue a pruce shelde or targe
Sōmme wil be armed / in his legges wele
And haue an axe / ⁊and sōmme a mace of stele
Ther nas no newe gyse / that hit nas holde
Armed were thei / as I haue yow tolde
Euerich aft̉er his owne oppyynyon
Ther̉e maistow se / comyng with Palamon

¶ Lygurgus the
grete kyng of

nesLygurge him silff / the grete kyng of Trace
Blak was his visage / ⁊and manly was his face
The cercles of his yghen / in his hede
Thei gloweden / bitwix yolow ⁊and rede
And like a lion / loked he a boughte
With kempte heeris / on his browis stoughte
His lymes grete / his braunes hard and strong
His shuldres brode / his armes rounde ⁊and longe
And as the gise was / in his contre
Ful highe vppon a chare of gold stode he
With ·iiij· white bolis in the trays
In stede of coote armure / oủere his harneys
With nayles yolow ⁊and bright / as any golde
He had a beris skynne / colblak for olde
His longe heere was kempt / bihynde his bak
As eny ravenes fether it shon for blak
¶ A wrethe of gold / arme grete of huge wighte
Vppon his heed sette / ful of stones brighte
Of fyne rubies / ⁊and of Diamauntis
A bovte his chaare wente / white Alauntis
·xxᵗⁱ· ⁊and mo / as grete as any steere
To hunten the lyon / or ellis at the deere
And folwed him with mosel faste I bounde
Colers of gold / ⁊and torrectis filed rounde
An hundred lordes had he / in his rovte
Armed ful wel / with hertis sterne ⁊and stovte
¶ With Arcite in stories / as men fynde

The grete Emetreus / the kyng͗e of ynde ¶ Emetreus the gret
kyng of Inde com
with Arcite to the
batayle to Athenes
Vppon a stede bay / trapped in stele
Couered with cloth of gold / diapred wele
Com ridyng like the god of armes Mars
His coote armure / was of clothe of tars
Covchid with perelis / white rounde ⁊and lite grete lite grete
His sadel was of brent gold / newe I bete
Amantelet vppon his shuldre hangyng
Bretful of rubies rede / as fire sparklyng
His crips heere / like ryngis was I ronne
And that was yolow / ⁊and gliteryng as the sonne
His nose was high / his yghen bright citryne
His lippes rounde / his coloir was sangwyne
A few fracles / in his face were spreynte
Bitwix̄en yolow / ⁊and somdelblak I meynte
And as a lyon / he his yghen caste
Of ·xxvᵗⁱ· yere / his age I caste
His berd was wel bigonne / for to spryng
His voys / as was a trompet / thondryng
Vppon his heed he wered / a lavrer grene
A garland fressh / ⁊and lusty for to seene
Vppon his honde he bare / for his delite
An Egle tame / as any lilie white
An hundred lordis / had he with him there
Al armed / saf here hedis / in al here gere
Ful richely in al man̉ere thinges
For trusteth wel / that Dukes · Erles · kynges
Were gadred / in this noble companye
For loue ⁊and for increse of chivalrie
A bovte this kyng ther͗e ran on eủery parte
Ful many a tame lyon / ⁊and leoparte
And in this wise / these lordes alle ⁊and sōmme
Ben on the sonday / to the cite come
A boute pryme / ⁊and in the town̄ alight
¶ This Theseus / this Duc / this worthi knyght
Whan he had brought hem / in to his cite
And inned hem / after here degre
He festeth hem / ⁊and dooth so grete laboure
To easen hem / ⁊and doun̄ hem alle honoure
That yit men wenen / that no mannys witt
Of noon estate / ne coude amenden it
The mystralsie / the servise at the feste
The grete yifftis / to the meste ⁊and leste
The riche araie / of Theseus paleys
Ne who satt firste / or laste vppon the deys
What ladies fairest ben / ⁊and best daunsyng
Or which of hem / can best daunce or syng
Ne who most felyngly /spekith of loue
What hawkes sitte / or perche a bove
What houndis liggen / on the floor a doıı̄un
Of al this now / make I no mencioıı̄un
But al the effecte / that thenkith me the beste
Now comyth the poynte / herkenyth if yow leste
The sonday night / or day bigan to spring
Whan Palamon / the larke herde syng
Al though it nere not day / by houres two
Yit song the larke / ⁊and Palamon right tho
With holy herte / ⁊and with an high corage
He roos vp to wenden / on his pilgremage
Vnto the blisful Cithera benigne
I meene Venus / honourable ⁊and digne
And in hir hour̉e / he walketh forth a paas
Vn to the listes / there the temple waas
And doun̄ he knelith / ⁊and with humble chere
And herte sore / he seide as ye shal here
Fairest o· faire / o lady myn Venus
Dought̉er to Ioue / ⁊and spouse to Vlcanus
Thow glader̉e of the mount of Citheroıı̄un
For thilke loue thow haddest to Adoun̄
Haue pite on my bitter teres smerte
And take myn humble praiere / at thyn herte
Alas I ne haue / no langage to telle
Theffecte ne the tourment / of myn helle
Myn herte may myn harmes not bewreye
I am so confused / that I can not seye
But m̉ercy lady bright / that wost wele
My thought and sest what harmes I fele
Considre al this / ⁊and rewe vppon my sore
As wisly as I shal / for eủermore
Emforth my myght / thi trewe s̉eruaunt be
And hold werre / alwey with chastite
That make I myn a vow / so ye me helpe
I kepe not of armes / for to yelpe
Ne I ne axe not to morow / to haue victorie
Ne renoun in this caas / ne veynglorie
Of price of armes / blowen vp ⁊and doun̄
But I wolde haue / fully possessioıı̄un
Of Emelye / ⁊and dye in hir seruise
Fynde thow the man̉ere how / ⁊and in what wise
I reche not / but it may better be
To haue victorie of hem / or thei of me
So that I haue / my lemman in myn armes
For though so be / that Mars is god of armes
Your̉e vertue is so grete / in heuen a boue
That if the liste / I shal wel haue my loue
Thi temple shal I worshop eủermo
And on thyn Avter / where I ride or go
I wol don̄ sacrifice / ⁊and fires bete
And if ye wil not so / my lady swete

div.l: Than rek I not / whan I haue lost my liff
Though Arcita wynne hir / to his wiff
This is theffecte ⁊and ende of my praiere
Yive me my lady / thow blisful lady dere
¶ Whan thorison̄ was don̄ / of palamon
His sacrifice he dide / ⁊and that anoon̄
Ful pitously / with alle circumstaunces
Al telle I not as now / his obseruaunces
But at the laste / the statue of Venus shooke
And made a signe / wherby that he tooke
That his praiere / acceptid was that day
For though the signe / shewid a delay
Yit wist he wel / that graunted was his bone
And with glad herte / he wente a way ful soone
¶ The thride houre / inequal that Palamon
Bigan to Venus temple / for to good
Vp ros the sonne / ⁊and vp roos Emelye
And to the temple / of Dyane gan she highe
Hir maidenss / that she thider with hir ladde
Ful redily with hem / the fire thei hadde
Thensence / the clothes / ⁊and the remenaunt all
That to the sacrifice / longen shall
The hornes ful of meethe / as was the guyse
There lakked nought / to don̄ hir sacrifice
Smokyng the temple / ful of clothis faire
This Emelye / with herte debonaire
Hir body wesshe / with water of a welle
But how she dide hir rite / I dar not telle
But it be any thing / in general
And yit it were a game / to hire it al
To him that meneth wel / it were no charge
But it is good / aman to be at his large
Hir bright heeres were kempt / vntressed al
A corone of grene eke ferial
Vppon hir heed was sette / ful faire ⁊and meete
Two fires on the auter / gan she beete
And did hir thinges / as men may biholde
In Stace of Thebes / ⁊and in bookes olde
Whan kyndelid was the fire / with pitous chere
Vnto Dyane she spake / as ye may here
¶ O chaste goddes / of the woode grene
To whom both heuen erthe / ⁊and see is sene
div.fw: Queene of the regne of Pluto
div.l: Queene of the reigne of Pluto derke ⁊and lowe
Goddes of maidenes / that myn herte hast knowe
Ful many a yere ⁊and wost what I desire
As kep me from thi vengeaunce / ⁊and thyn Ire
That Attheon a boughte trewely
Chaste goddes wel wostow that I
Desire to be a maide al my liff
Ne neủere wol I be loue ne wiff
I am thow wost yit / of thi companye
A maide / ⁊and loue huntyng ⁊and venerie
And for to walke in the woodes wilde
And not to be a wiff ⁊and be with childe
Nat wol I knowe the companye of man
Now helpe me lady / sith ye may ⁊and can
For tho thre formes / that thow hast in the
And Palamon that hath such loue to me
And eke Arcite / that loueth loue loueth me so sore
This grace I pray the / withouten more
And sende loue ⁊and pees / bitwix hem two
And from me tourne awey / here hertes so
Tht al here hoote loue / ⁊and here desire
And al here besy turment / ⁊and here fire
Be queynte or turned / in a nother place
And if so be thow wolt do me no grace
Or if so be my destyne be shapen so
That I shal nedis haue oon / of hem two
As sende me him / that most desirith me
Biholde goddes of clene chastite
The bitter teres that on my chekes falle
Syn thow art maide / ⁊and keper of vs alle
My maidenhode thow kepe / ⁊and wel conserue
And while I lyve / a maiden I wil the serue
The fires brenne / vppon the auter clere
Whil eEmelie was thus / in hir praiere
ForBut For But sodenly she sy / a thing queynte
For right anoon / on of the fires queynte
And quykked ageyne / and aft̉er that anoon
That other fire was queynte / ⁊and al a goon
And as it queynte / it made a whistelyng
As don̄ wete brondes / in her̉e brennyng
And at the brondes ende / oute ran anoon
As it were blody dropes / many oon
For which so sore agast / was Emelie
That she was nygh madde / ⁊and gan to crie
For she ne wiste / what it signified
But only for the fire / thus she cried
And wepte / that it was pite for to here
And therwithal / Dyane gan to appere
With bowe in honde / right as an hunteresse
And seide dought̉er / stynte thyn hevynesse
Among the godis an high / it is affermed
And bi et̉erne world write / ⁊and confermed
Thow shalt be wedded / vnto on of thoo
That haue for the / so mech care ⁊and woo
But vn to which of hem / I may not telle
Fare wel / for I may no lenger dwelle
The fires which on myn auter brenne
Shulle the declaren / or that thow go henne
Thyn auenture of loue / as in this caas
And with that word the arowis in the caas
Of the goddes clateryn / fast ⁊and rynge
And forth she wente / ⁊and made avanysshinge
For which this Emelie / astoned was
And seide what amounteth this alas
I putte me / vnder thi proteccion
Dyane / in thi disposicion
And hom she goth / the nexte way
This is theffecte / there is no more to say
¶ The nexte houre of Mars / folowyng this
Arcite vn to the temple / I walked is
Of fires to Mars / to do his sacrifice
With al the rites / of his panym wise
With pitous herte / ⁊and high deuocion
Right thus to Mars / he saide his orison
A stronge god / that in the reignes colde
Of Tars / honoured art / ⁊and lord I holde
And hast in eủery regne / ⁊and eủery londe
Of armes alle / the bridel in thyn honde
And hem fortunest / as the list devise
Accepte of me / my symple pitous symple pitous sacrifice
Yif so be / my thought may deserve
And that my myght / be worthi for to serve
Thi godhede / that I may be on of thyne
Thenne pray I the / to rewe vppon my pyne
For thilke peyne / ⁊and that hoote fire
In which thow brendist whilom for desire
Whan thow vsedist the beaute
Of faire / yonge / fresshe Venus fre
And haddist hir in armes / at thi wille
Al though the ones on a tyme mysfille
Whan Vlcanus / had caught the in his laas
And fonde the liggyng / bi his wiff alaas
For thilke sorow / that was in thin herte
Haue routhe / vppon my peynes smerte
I am yonge ⁊and vn connyng / as thow wost
And as I trowe / with loue offended most
That eủer was / eny livis creature
For she that doth me / al this woo endure
Ne recceth neủere / whether I synke or flete
And wel I wot / or she me m̉ercy heete
I mote with strength / wynne hir in this place
As wel I wot / withoute helpe or grace
Of the / ne may my strength not availe
Than helpe me lord to morow / in my bataile
For thilke fire / that whilom brente the
As wel as that fire / now brenneth me
And do that I to morow haue victorie
Myn be the travaile / ⁊and thyn be the glorie
Thi soủeraigne temple / wol I most honouren
Of any place ⁊and alway most labouren
In thi plesaunce / ⁊and in thi craftes stronge
And in thi temple I wil my baner honge
And al tharmes / in my companye
And eủermo / vnto that day I dye
Eterne fire / I will before the fynde
And eke to this avow / I wil me bynde
My berd my heere / that hongeth low a doıı̄un
That neủere yit / ne felte non offension
Of rasour ne of shere / I wil the yive
And ben thi trewe s̉eruaunt / while I live
Now lord haue routhe / vppon my sorowes sore
Yive me the victorie / I axe the nomore
The praiere stynte / of Arcita the stronge
The rynges on the temple dore thei ronge
And eke the doris clateriden / ful faste
Of which Arcita / somwhat him agaste
The fires brenne / vppon the auter bright
That it gan al the temple for to light
And swete smel / anoon the ground vp yaff
And Arcita anoon / his hond vp haff
And more ensence / in to the fire he caste
With other rites mo / ⁊and at the laste
The statue of Mars / bigan his hauberk rynge
And with that sown̄ he herd a murmurynge
Ful lowe ⁊and dym / that seide this victorie
For which he yaf to Mars / honour ⁊and glorie
And thus with ioye / ⁊and hope / wel to fare
Arcite a rose / ⁊and to his Inne gan fare
As fayne as foule is / of the bright sonne
And right anoon / such stryff is bigonne
¶ For thilke grauntyng in the heuen a bove
Bitwix Venus / the goddes of loue
And Mars the sterne god Armypotente
That Iubiter was besy it to stynte
Til that the pale Saturnus / the coolde
That knewe so mony of aventures oolde
Fonde in his olde exꝑperience / an arte
That he ful soone / hath plesid eủery parte
As soth is seide / elde hath grete avaıı̄untage
In elde is both wisdom / ⁊and vsage
Men may tholde at renne / but not at rede
Saturne anoon / to stynten striff ⁊and drede
Al be it that it is / agayn his kynde
Of al this striff / he gan remedies fynde
My dere doughter Venus / qduod Saturne
My cours that hath so wide / for to turne
Hath more power / than wote any man

Myn is the drenchyng / in the see so wan ¶ the ꝓpropertes of
Saturne the pla
nete is eủere euel
Myn is the prison / in the derke coote
Myn is the strangelyng / ⁊and hangyng bi the throote
The murmur / ⁊and the chereles rebellyng
The groynyng / ⁊and the prevy enpoisonyng
I do vengiaunce / ⁊and playne correccion
Whils that I duelle / in the signe of the lyon
Myn is the ruyne / of the highe hallis
The fallyng of the touris / ⁊and of the wallis
Vppon the mynour̉e / or the Carpentere
I slough Sampson / shakynge the pelere
And myn ben / the maladies coolde
The derke tresounes / ⁊and the castis oolde
Mi lokyng is the fader / of pestilence
Now wepe no more / I shal do my diligence
That Palamon that is thin owne knyght
Shal haue his lady / as thow hast hight
Though Mars helpe his knyght / yit natheles
Bitwix yow tweyne / mote be somtyme pees
Al be ye nought / of oon complexcion
That causeth alday / such division
I am thyn alredy at thi wille
Wepe no more / I wol thi luste fulfille
Now wol I stynten of these goddis above
Of Mars / ⁊and of Venus goddes of loue
And playnly / I wol telle yow as I can
The grete effecte / of which I first bigan
¶ Grete was the feste / in Athenes that day
And eke that lusty seson / of May
Made eủery wight to be / in such plesaunce
That al that day iusten thei / ⁊and daunce
And spenden it / in Venus high s̉eruise
But bi the cause / that thei shulden rise rse rise
Erly / for to sen / the grete sight
Vn to here reste / wente thei at night
And on the morow whan day gan to sprynge
Of horse ⁊and harneys / noise ⁊and claterynge
Ther was in hostelries al a boute
And to the paleys rood ther̉e mony a route
Of lordes vppon steedis ⁊and palfreys
There maistow se / divising of harneys
So vn couth / ⁊and so riche / ⁊and wrought so wel
Of goldsmytherie / of brondryng / ⁊and of stel
The sheldes bright / testers ⁊and trappures
Gold hewe helmes / hauberkes ⁊and cote armures
Lordes Lorde Lordes in paramentis on here coursers
Knyghtes of retenue / ⁊and eke squyers
Nailyng the speres / ⁊and helmes bokelyng
Shynyng of sheldes with poyntis lasyng
There as nede is thei were nothing ydel
The fomyng stedes / on the golden bridel
Gnawyng faste / ⁊and the armurers also
With file ⁊and hamer / ridyng to ⁊and fro
Yoman on foote / ⁊and comyns mony oon
With shorte stavis / thikke as thei may goon
Pipis trompis / nakers ⁊and clariones
That in the batayle blowen / blody sownes
The paleys ful of peple vp ⁊and doıı̄un
Here thre there ten holdyng here questioıı̄un
Diuinyng of these Theban knyghtis two
Sōmme seide thus / some seide it shal be so
Some helde with him / with the blake berid
Some with the balled / some with the thikke heerid
Some seide he loked grym / ⁊and he wold fighte
He hath a sparthe of ·xxᵗⁱ· pounde of wighte
Thus was the halle / ful of divynyng
Longe aft̉er the sonne / gan to spryng
The grete Theseus / of his slepe gan wake
With mynstralsie / ⁊and noise that thei make
Helde yit the chaumbre / of his paleys riche
Til that the Theban knyghtis / both I liche
Honoured weren / ⁊and in to the paleys fette
Duc Theseus is at the wyndow sette
Arraied right as he were a god in trone
The peple preseed / thiderwarde ful sone
Him for to sen / ⁊and don̄ him high reủerence
And eke to herken his heest / ⁊and his sentence
An Herawde on a scaffolde / made an Oo
Til al the noise of the peple / was doo
And whan he saw the peple /of noise al stille
Thus shewed he / the myghti Dukes wille
¶ The lorde hath / of his high discression
Considered / that it were distruccion
To gentil blode / to fighten in this wise
Of mortal bataile / now in this emprise
Wherfore to shapen / that thei shul not dye
He wol his first purpose modifye
Noman therfore / vp peyne of los his liff
No maner shoot / ne pollax / ne shorte knyff
In to the listes sende / or thider bryng
Ne shorte swerde / for to steke with poynte bityng
No man ne drawe / ne bere it bi his side
Ne noman shal vnto his felow ride
But oo cours with a sharpe grounden spere
Foyne if him list on foote him silff to weere

div.l: And he that is at myschieff shal be take
And not slayne / but be brought to a stake
That shal be ordeynede on either side
But theder he shal bi force / ⁊and there abide
And if so falle / the chieftayne be take
On either side / or ellis slen his make
No lenger shal / the turnement laste
God spede yow / goo ⁊and ley on faste
With swerdes ⁊and longe maces fighteth your͗e fille
Gooth now your͗e wey / this is the lordes wille
The voise of the peple / touchid heuen
So lowde cried thei / with mylde steuen
God save such alord / that is so good
He willith no distruccion of blood
Vp goon the trompes / ⁊and the melodie
And to the listes / rideth this companye
Bi ordenaunce / thorughtoute the cite large
Honged with cloth of gold / ⁊and not with
¶ Ful like a lord / this noble Duc gan ride
These two Thebeans / on either side
And aft͗er rode the queene / ⁊and Emelie
And aft͗er that / a nother companye
Of oon ⁊and other / after here degre
And thus thei passen / thorughoute the cite
And to the listes / com thei bi tyme
It nas not of the day / yit fully pryme
Whan sette was Theseus / ful riche on highe
Ypolita the queene / ⁊and Emelie
And other ladies / in degrees aboute
Vn to the seetis / presith al the route
And westward / thorugh the gates vnder Marte
Arcite and eke the hundred of his parte
With baner rede is entred / right anoon
And that selff moment / Palamon
Is vnder Venus / Estward in that place
With baner white / ⁊and hardy chere ⁊and face
And in al the world / to seken vp ⁊and doıı̄un
So even withouten variacioıı̄un
Ther͗e nere suche companyes tweyne
For ther͗e was noon so wise / that coude seyne
That any had of other / avantage
Of worthynesse / ne of estate ne age
So even were thei chosen / for to gesse
And in two renges / faire thei hem dresse
Whan that here names / red were eủerychon
That in here nombre / gile were ther noon
Tho were the gates shette / ⁊and criede was lowde
Doth now your͗e devoyre / yonge knyghtis proude
The herowdes left here prikyng / vp ⁊and doun̄
Now ryngen trompis lowde / ⁊and clarioun
¶ There is no more to seyn / but est ⁊and west
In gon the speris / ful sadly in the rest
There sen men / who can iuste ⁊and ride
In gon the sharpe sporis / in to the side
There shiverne shaftes / vppon sheldis thikke
He felith thorugh the herte spone / the prikke
Vp spryngen speres ·xxᵗⁱ· foote on hight
Oute gon the swerdis / as the seluer bright
The helmes thei to hewen / ⁊and to shrede
Out brestith the blode / with sterne stremes rede
With myghti maces / the bones thei to brast
And thorugh the thikkest / thei thrynge ⁊and thrast
Ther͗e stomblen stedes strong / ⁊and doun gon falle
He rollith vnder foote / as doth a balle
He foyneth on his foote / with his tronchoun̄
And he him hurteth / with his hors adoun̄
He thorugh the body is hurt / and sithen take
Mavgre his heed is take / ⁊and brought to the stake
As forward was / right there he muste abide
An other lad is / on that other side
¶ And somtyme doth hem Theseus for to reste
Hem to refresshe / ⁊and drynke if hem leste
Ful ofte that day / haue these Thebans two
To geder met / ⁊and wrought ech other woo
Vnhorsed han eche other / of hem tweye
Ther is no Tigre / in the vale of Galgopheye
Whan hir whelpe is stole / whan it is lite
So cruel on the hunte / as is Arcite
For ielous herte / vppon this Palamon
Ne in Belmarie / there is noon so fel lyon
That hunted is / or for his hongor wood
Ne of his preye / desirith so the blood
As Palamon / to sle his foo Arcite
The ielous strokes / on here helmes bite
Out renneth blood / on both here sides rede
Somtyme an ende ther is / of eủery dede
For or or the sonne / vn to the reste wente
The strong kyng Emetreus / gan hente
This Palamon / as he faughte with Arcite
And made his swerde / depe in his flesshe bite
And bi the force of ·xxᵗⁱ· is he take
Vnyolden ⁊and drawen / to the stake
And in the rescow / of this Palamon
The strong kyng Lygurge / is born̄ adoun̄
And kyng Emetreus / for al his grete strengthe
Is born̄ out of his sadel / his swerdis lengthe
So hitte him Palamon / or he were take
But al for nought / he was brought to the stake
His hardy herte / may him helpe naughte
He muste abide / whan that he was caughte
Bi force / ⁊and eke bi composicion̄
Who soroweth now / but wooful Palamon
That may nomore gon / agayn to fighte
And whan that Theseus had seyn / that sighte
He cried hoo nomore / for hit is don̄
Ne noon shal lenger / to his felowe gon
¶ I wil be trewe Iuge / ⁊and not partie
Arcite of Thebes / shal haue Emelie
That bi his fortune / hath hire faire wonne
Anoon ther is a noyse of peple / bigonne
For ioye of this / so lowde ⁊and high withalle
It semed the listes / shulde falle
What can now faire Venus do aboue
What seith she now / what doth this queene of loue
But wepith so for wantyng of hir wille
Til that hir teres in the listes fille
She saide I am a shamed doutelees
Saturnus saide dought̉er / holde thi pees
Mars hath his wil / his knyght hath his bone
And bi my heed / thow shalt be eased sone
The trompours / with lowde mystralcie
The Herowdis / ful lowde yolle ⁊and crie
Ben in her weel for ioye / of Daun Arcite
But herkneth me / ⁊and stynte noise alite
Whiche a miracle / there bifille anoon
This ferce Arcite / hath oof his helm I doon
And on a courser for to shewe his face
He priketh endelonge / the large place
Lokyng vpward vppon this Emelie
And she agayn him cast a frendely yghe
For women as to speke in comune
Thei folwen al the fauour of fortune
And was al his chere as in his herte
Out of the grounde / a fire infernal sterte ¶ a Miracle
From Pluto sente / at the requeste of Saturne
For which his hors / for feere gan to turne
And lepe aside / ⁊and foundred as he lepe
And or that Arcite / may taken kepe
He pight him / on the pomel of his hede
That in the place he lay / as he were dede
His breste to brosten / with his sadel bowe
As blake he lay / as any cole or crowe
So was the blood I ronne in to his face
Anoon he was born̄ / out of the place
With herete herete herte sore / vn to Theseus paleys
Tho was he corven / out of his harneys
And in abedde brought / right faire ⁊and blyve
For he was yit / in memorie ⁊and on live
And alwey crying / after Emelie
Duc Thesesus / withal his companye
Is comen hom / to Athenes his cite
With al blis / ⁊and grete solempnyte
Al be it / that this auenture is falle
He wold not discomfort / hem alle
Men seide eke / that Arcite shuld not dye
He shal be helid / of his maladieve maladive maladie
And of another thing / thei were fayne
That of hem alle / ther was noon slayne
Al were thei sore I hurte / ⁊and namely oon
That with a spere was thirled the breste bon
Two other wounded / ⁊and two broken armes
Some had salue / ⁊and some had sharmes
Fermacies of herbis / ⁊and eke save
Thei dronken / for thei wold her he her livis haue
For which this noble Duc / as he wel can
Comfortith / ⁊and honourith / eủery man
And made revel / al the longe night
Vn to the strange lordes / as it was right
Ne there was hold /
no discomfeture
For failyng is / but an auenture
Ne to be lad bi force / vn to the stake
Vnyolden / ⁊and with ·xxᵗⁱ· knyghtis take
O ꝑperson alone / withouten moo
And haried forth / bi arme foote / ⁊and too
And eke his stede / dreven forth with staves
With footemen / both yemen ⁊and knaves
Hit was directed him / no vilonye
Ther͗e may noman / clepe hit cowardye
¶ For which anoon / this Duc Theseus lete crie
To styntyn al rancour͗e / ⁊and envie
The gre as wel on o side as on other
And either side I like / as others brother
And yaff hem yiftes / aft̉er here degre
And fully held a feste / dayes thre
And conueyed the kynges / worthily
Out of his towne / a iouneye largely
And hom wente eủery man / the right way
Th̉ere nas no more / but farewel haue good day
¶ Of this bataile / I wol no more endite
But speke of Palamon / ⁊and of Arcite
Swellith the breste / of Arcite ⁊and the sore
Encresith at his herte / more ⁊and more
The clotered blood / for any leche crafte
Coruptith / ⁊and is in his body lafte
That neither veyneblood / ne ventusing
Ne drynke of herbis / may be his helping
The vertu expulsiff / or anymal
And thilke vertu cleped natural
Ne may the venym voyde / ne expelle
The pipes of his longes / gan to swelle
And eủery lacert / in ∧his his herte adoun̄
Is shent with venym / ⁊and corrupcioun̄
Him geyneth nother / for to gete his liff
Vomyte vpward / ne donward laxatiff
Al is to brosten thilke regioıı̄un
Nature hath no dn̄ominacioıı̄un
¶ And certeynly / ther̉e nature wol not wirche
Farewel phisik / go bere the man to chirche
This al ⁊and som / that Arcita most dye
For which he sendith after Emelie
And Palamon / that was his Cosyn dere
Than seide he thus / as ye shal affter here
Now may may the wooful spirit / in myn herte ¶ thende of Arcite
Declare o poynte / of my sorowes swerte
To you my lady / that I loue moste
Thus biquithe I the s̉eruise of my goste
To yow a boven / eủery creature
Syn that my liff / may no lenger dure
Alas the woo / alas the peynes stronge
That I for yow haue suffred ⁊and so longe
Alas the deth / alas myn Emelie
Alas deꝑparting of oure companye
Alas myn hertis queene / alas my wiff
Myn hertis lady / ender of my liff
What is this world / what axen men to haue
Now with his loue / now in his colde grave
Alone / withouten any companye
Farewel my swete fo / myn Emelie
And sofft take me / in your̉e armes tweye
For the loue of god / ⁊and herkneth what I seye
¶ I haue here / with my cosyn Palamon
Had striff ⁊and rancour̉e many day gon̄
For loue of yow / ⁊and for my ielousie
And Iubiter so wis / my soule gye
To speken of a s̉eruaunt ꝓpropurly
With circumstaunces alle truly
That is to seyne / trouth / honour / ⁊and knyghthede
Wisdom / humblesse / estate / ⁊and high kynrede
Fredom / ⁊and al that longeth to that arte
So Iubit̉er haue on my soule parte
As in this world / right now know I noon
So worthi to be loued / as Palamon
That seruith yow / ⁊and wil do al his liff
And if that ye shal eủere ben a wiff
For yete not Palamon the gentil man
And with that worde / his spech faile bigan
For fro his feete / vnto his herte was come
The colde of deth / that had him oủercome
And yit more ouer / for in his armes two
The vital strength / is lost ⁊and al a go
Save only / the intellecte / withouten more
That duelled dulled duelled in his herte / sike ⁊and sore
Gan faylen / whan the herte feleth deth
Dusked his yghen two / ⁊and failith his breth
But on his lady / yit cast he his yghe
His last worde / was m̉ercy Emelie
¶ His spirit changed hous / ⁊and wente there
As I cam neuer / I can not tellen where
Therfore I stynte / I am no divynister
Of soulis fynde I nought / in this register
Ne me ne list / not not such opynyons to telle
Though that I myghte fynde wreten / wher͗e thei duelle
Arcite is colde / that Mars his soule gye
Now wol I speken forth / of Emelie
Shrite Emelie / ⁊and ha ha wailith Palamon
And Theseus his suster / took anoon
Swounyng ⁊and bare hir / fro the corps away
What helpith vs / to tarien forth the day
To telle how she wepte / both eve ⁊and morowe
For in such caas / women haue suche sorowe
Whan that here husbondes ben from them a go
That for the more ꝑpart / thei sorowen so
Or ellis fallen / in suche maladie
That at the laste / serteynly thei dye
Infinite harmes ben / ⁊and eke teres
Of olde folk / ⁊and folk of tendre yeres
In al the town̄ for deth / of this Theban
There wepith both woman / child ⁊and man
So grete weping / was noon c̉ertayne
Whan Ector was brought / al fresshe I slayne
To Troy / alas the pite that was there
Cracchyng of chekes / rentyng of heere
¶ Whi woldestow dye / these women crie
And haddest gold I nough / ⁊and Emelie
No man myghte / glade Theseus
Savyng his olde fader / Egeus
That knewe / this worldis transmutacion
As he had seyn hit / vp ⁊and doun
Ioye after wo ⁊and wo after gladnesse
And shewith him ensample ⁊and liknesse
Right as ther diede neuer man qduod he
That he ne lived in erthe / in som degre
Right so ther lived / neuer man he seide
In al this world / but somtyme he ne deide
¶ This world is nought / but a thorughfare ful of woo
And we ben pilgremes / passing to ⁊and fro
Deth is an ende of eủery wordly worly wordly sore
And oủeral this / yit seide he mech more
To this effecte / ful wisely to exhorte
The peple / that thei hem shulle recomforte
Duc Theseus / with al his busi cure
Casteth now where the sepulture
Of good Arcite / may best I maked be
And eke most honourable / of degre
And at the laste / he toke conclusion
That there as first Arcite ⁊and Palamon
Had for loue the batayle / hem bitwene
That in the selff grove / swete ⁊and grene
There as he had / his amorous desires
His complaynte / ⁊and for loue his hoote fires
He wold make a fire / in which thoffice
Funeral he myght hem alle accomplice
He lete anoon comaunde / to hakke ⁊and hewe
The okes olde / ⁊and ley hem on a rewe
In colpons / wel araied for to brenne
His officers / with swift foote thei the thei renne
And right anoon / at his comaundemente
And after this Thesesus hath I sente
After a beere / ⁊and he it oủerspradde
With cloth of gold / the richest that he hadde
And of the same sute / he clothed Arcite
Vppon his hondes / his glovis white
Eke on his heed a growne / of laurer grene
And in his hond a swerde / bright ⁊and kene
He ladde him bare / the visage on the beere
Therwith he wepte / that pite was to heere
And for the peple / shulde sen him alle
Whan it was day / he brought him to the halle
That rorith of the crye / ⁊and of the drery sown
Tho gan this woful Theban Palamon
With flotery berd / ⁊and roggy asshi heres
In clothes blake / dropped al with teres
And passing other / of weping Emelie
The rufullest / of al the companye
In as meche / the s̉eruise shuld be
The more noble ⁊and riche / in his degre
Duc Theseus / lete forth thre stedis bringe
That trappit were in stele / al gliteringe
And couered with tharmes / of Daun Arcite
Vppon these stedes grete / ⁊and white
Ther̉e stoden folk / of which oon bare his sheelde
Another his spere / in his honde helde
The thrid bar̉e with him / his bowe turkeys
Of burned gold / was caas ⁊and the harneys
And riden forth a paas / with sory chere
Toward the grove / as ye shulle aft̉er here
The noblest of the Grekes / that there were
Vppon here shuldres / caried the bere
With slak paas / ⁊and yghen weete ⁊and weete ⁊and rede ⁊and wete
Thorughoute the cite / bi the maister strete
That sprad was al with blak / ⁊and wonder highe
Right of the same / is the strete I wrye
On the right honde / wente olde Egeus
And on the other side / Duc Theseus
¶ With vesselis in here honde / of gold ful fyne
Al ful of hony / mylke / blood / ⁊and wyne
Eke Palamon / with ful grete companye
And aft̉er that / com woful Emelie
With fire in honde / as was that tyme the gyse
To do the offfice / of funeral s̉eruise
High labour / ⁊and ful grete apparalling
Was at the s̉eruise / ⁊and at the fire makyng͗e
That with his grene top / the heuen raughte
And ·xxᵗⁱ· fadme in brede / the armes straughte
This is to seyn / the bowes were so brode
Of stre first ther was leyde / mony a lode
But how the fire / was maked vppon highte
Ne eke the names / how the trees highte
As oke · vir / birche / asp / alder / elme / popeler
Welew / holme / plane / assh / box / chesteyn / lynde / laurer
Mapul / thorn / beche / ew / hasel / whipultree
How thei were fild / shal not be told for me
Ne how the goddes ronne / vp ⁊and doun̄
Disherite / of here habitacioıı̄un
In which thei woneden / in rest ⁊and pees
Nymphes / Fawnes / ⁊and Amadries
Ne how the bestes / ⁊and the briddes alle
Fledden for fere / whan the wood was falle
Ne how the grounde / agast was of the light
That was not wonte to se / the sonne bright
Ne how the fire was couchid first / with stre
And thenne with drie stikkes clouen on thre
And thenne with with grene wode / ⁊and spicerie
And than with cloth of gold / ⁊and perreie
And garlandes hangyng with mony a floure
The mirre thensence / with al swte odoure
Ne how Arcite lay / among al this
Ne what richesse / aboughte his body is
Ne how Emelie / as was the gyse
Put in the fire / of funeral s̉eruise
Ne how she swouned / whan made was the fire
Ne what she spake / ne what was hir desire
Ne what iewelles / men in the fire caste
Whan that the fire was grete / ⁊and brente faste
Ne how some caste here sheelde / ⁊and some here spere
And of here vestementis / which thei weete
¶ And coppes ful of mylke / ⁊and wyn ⁊and blood
Into the fire that brente / as it were wood
Ne how the grekes / with an huge route
Thries riden / al the fire aboute

✠✠ Vppon the lift honde /
with a lowde shoutyng Vppon the lift honde / with a lowde shoutyng
