div.l: Ne how Arcite is brente / to asshen colde
Ne how this liche wake / was I holde
Al that night / ne how the grekes pleye
The wake pleyes / kepe I not to seye
Who wrastelith best naked / with oyle anoynte
Ne who bare him best / in no disioynte
I wol not telle al / how thei gon̄
Hom to Athenes / whan the pley was don̄
¶ But shortly to the poynt / than wol I wende
And make / of my longe tale a nende
Bi proces ⁊and bi lengthe / of c̉erteyn yeres
Al stynted is the mornyng̉e / ⁊and the teres
Of grekes / bi on general assente
Thanne assigned ther was / a ꝑparlemente
At Athenes / vppon c̉ertayne poynte ⁊and caas
Among al other poyntes / spoken it was
To haue with c̉erteyne contrees alliaunce
And haue of Thebans / fulli obeysaunce
For which this noble Theseus anoon
Lete sende / aft̉er gentil Palamon
Vnwist of him / what was the cause ⁊and whi
But in his blake clothes / sorowfully
He come at his comaundemente on highe
Tho sente Theseus / for Emelie
Whan thei were sette / ⁊and huyst was in the place
And Theseus abiden hath / a litil space
Or eny worde cam / from his wise breste
His yghen sette he / ther̉e as him leste
And with a sad visage / he siked stille
And aft̉er that right thus he seide his wille
The first movere / of the cause aboue
Whan he first made / the firy cheyne of loue
Grete was theffecte / ⁊and high was his entente
Wel wiste he whi / ⁊and what therof he mente
For with that firy cheyne of loue he bonde
The fire the ayre / the water / ⁊and the londe
In c̉erteyne bondes / that thei may not flee
That same prynce / ⁊and that same movere qduod hee
Hath stablisshid / in this wrecchid world adoun
Certeyne dayes ⁊and dủracioıı̄un
To alle that be / engendrid in this place
Ouer the which day / thei may not paace
Al mowe thei yit / tho dayes abrigge
Ther̉e nedith noon autorite / to alegge
For it is is previd / by experience
But that me list not / declare my sentence
Than may man wel / bi this ordre discerne
That thilke movere / stable is / ⁊and eterne
Wel may may man knowe / but it be a folle
That eủery ꝑpartie derrayued / from his hoole
For nature hath not takyn his bigynnyng
Of no ꝑpartie / or of cantel / of no thyng̉e
¶ But oo thing / that ꝑparfite is ⁊and stable
Descendyng so / til it be corrumpable
And therfore / of his wise purviaunce
He hath so wel bisette / his ordynaunce
That specifieth / of thinges ⁊and ꝓprogressioıı̄uns
Shullen endure / by successioıı̄uns
And not eterne / withoute eny lye
This maistow vnderstonde / ⁊and se at yghe
Lo the oke / that hath so longe a norsshyng
Fro the tyme / that hit first bigynnyth to sprynge
And hath so longe a liff / as ye may se
Yit at the laste / wasted is the tre
Considerith eke / how that the harde ston
Vnder oure feete / on which we trede ⁊and gon̄
Yit wasteth it / as it lith in the weye
The brode river / somtyme wexith dreye
The grete townes / so wide wane ⁊and wende
Than ye se / that al this thing hath a nende
Of man ⁊and woman / so we shulle also
That outher in oon / of the termes two
That is to seyn in youthe / or elles age
He mot be ded the kyng / as shal a page
Some in his bed / some in the depe see
Some in the large felde / as ye may se
There helpith nought ther goth noon other wey
Than may ye se that all thing moiste dey
What makith this but Iubit̉er the kyng
That is prince / ⁊and cause of al thing
Conủertyng al yn to his ꝓpropre wille
From which it is darreyued / soth to teille
And here agayne / no creature on live
Of no degre / availith for to strive
¶ Then is it wisdom / as it thinkith me
To make vertu of necessite
And take it wel / that we may not eschewe
And namely that / that to vs alle is dewe
And who so gruccheth ought he doth folie
And rebel is to him / that al may gye
And certaynly / aman hath moste honour̉e
To dyen in his excellence / ⁊and flour̉e
Whan he is siker / of his gode name
Than hath he don̄ / his frende ne him no shame
And gladder ought / his frende ben of his deth
Whan with honour / I yolden is vp the breth
Than whan his name appalled is for age
For al forgeten is / his vassellage
Than is the best / as for aworthi fame
To dien whan he is best of name
The contrarie / of al this is wilfulnesse
Whi grucche we / whi haue we hevynesse
The gode Arcite / of chivalrie the flour͗e
Deꝑpartid is / with duete / ⁊and with honour͗e
Out of the foule prison of this liff
Whi grucchyn here / his cosyn ⁊and his wiff
Of his welfare / that loueth him so well
Can he hem thanke / nay god wote neủer a dell
That both his soule / ⁊and eke him offende
And yit thei mow not / here lustes amende
What may I conclude / of this longe serye
But aft̉er woo / I rede vs to be merye
And thanken Iubiter / of al his grace
Or we deꝑparten / from this place
I rede we make / of sorowes two
Oo ꝑparfite ioye / lastyng eủer mo
¶ And loke now / where moste sorow is inne
And there wil I first / amenden / ⁊and bigynne
Suster qduod he / this is my ful assente
With al thavis here / of my ꝑparlemente
That gentil Palamon / youre owne knyght
That servith yow / with wil herte ⁊and myght
And eủer hath doon̄ / sithen ye first him knewe
That ye shulle / of your͗e grace vppon him rewe
And take him for husbonde / ⁊and for lorde
Lene me youre honde / for this is oure accorde
Lete se now / of youre womanly pite
He is a kynges brother sone ꝑparde
And though he be a pore bachelere
Sithe hath servid yow so mony yere
And had for yow / so grete adủersite
It most be considred / levith me
For gentil m̉ercy / oughte to passen right
Than seide he thus to Palamon the knyght
I trow ther nede / litel sermonyng
To make yow assente to this thing
¶ Cometh nere / ⁊and takith your͗e lady bi the honde
Bitwix hem two / was made anoon the bonde
That hight matrymonye / or mariage
Bi alle the counsaille / ⁊and baronage
And thus with alle blisse / ⁊and melodie
Hath Palamon / I wedded Emelie
And god that al this world / hath wrought

Vn to the tubbes / hangyng in the balkes
And hem vitailled both trough ⁊and tubbe
With brede ⁊and with chese / ⁊and good ale in a Iubbe
Suffising right I now / as for a day
But ar that he hadde / made al this aray
He sente his knave / ⁊and eke his wenche also
Vppon his nede to Londoıı̄un / for to go
¶ And on the monday / whan it drough to night
He shette his dore / withoute candel light ¶
And dressid al thing / as it sholde be
And shortly clomben vp alle thre
Thei setten stille / wel a forlong way
Now pater noster clum / seide Nicholay
And clum qd Iohn / ⁊and clum seide Alisoıı̄un
This Carpenter / seide his deuocioıı̄un
And stille he sitte ⁊and biddith his prayere
A waityng on the rayne / if he it hiere
The deth slepe / for wery besynesse
Fil on this Carpent̉er / right as I gesse
A boute corfew tyme / or litel more
For travaille of his gost / he groneth sore
And efte he routeth / for his hed myslay
Doun bi the laddre / stalketh Nicholay
And Alisoıı̄un ful softe / a doun she spedde
Withouten wordes mo / thei goıı̄un to bedde
There as the Carpenter / is wonte to lye
There was the reuel / ⁊and the melodie
And thus lith Alisoıı̄un / ⁊and Nicholas
In besynesse / or merthe / ⁊and in solas
Til that the belle / of laudes gan to rynge
And freris in the chauncell gonne synge .
¶ This parisshe clerc / this amorous Absoloıı̄un
That is for loue alwey / so wo bigoıı̄un
Vppon the monday / was at Oseney
With compaigne / him to disport ⁊and pley
And axede vppon cas / a cloistrer
Ful privily / after Iohn the Carpenter
And he drough him aparte / out of the chirche
And seide I not / I saugh him here not wirche
Sithe Saturday I trowe that he be wente
For tymber / there oure Abbot hath him sente
For he is wont / for tymber for to go
And duellyn at the graunge / a day or two
Or ellis he is / at his hous c̉erteyne
Where that he is / I can not sothly seyne
This Absoloıı̄un ful ioly was / ⁊and light
And thoughte now is tyme / to wake alnight
For sekerly / I saw him not sterynge
Abouten his dore / syn day bigan to sprynge
So moty thrive / I shal at cokkes crowe
Ful privily knokken / at his wyndowe
That stant ful lowe / vppon his bowres walle
To Alison now wol I / tellen alle
My loue longyng / for yit I shal not mysse
That at the leste wey / I shal hir kysse
Som maner comforte / shal I haue parfay
My mouth hath icched / al this longe day
That is a signe / of kissyng at the leeste
Alnight me met eke / I was at a feeste
Therfore I wol go slepe / an houre or twey
And al the night / than wol I wake ⁊and pley
Whan that the first cokke / hath crowe a noon
Vp rist this ioly louer Absoloıı̄un
And him arayeth gay / at poynt devise
But first he chewith grayn ⁊and likorise
To smellen swete / ar he hadde kempt his heere
Vnder his tonge / a trewe loue he bere
For therby wende he / to be gracious
He rowmeth to the Carpenteris hous
And stille he stant / vnder the shotwyndowe
Vn to his breste it raught / it was so lowe
And softe he coughed / with a semy sown
What do ye hony combe / swete Alisoıı̄un
My faire brid / my swete synamome
A wake lemman myn / ⁊and spekith to me
Wel litil thenke ye / vppon my wo
That for youre loue I sweete there I go
No wonder is though that I swelte ⁊and swete
I morne as doth a lambe / after the tete
I wis lemman / I haue swiche loue longyng
That like a turtil trewe / is my mornyng . ¶
I may not eten / no more than a mayde
Go fro the wyndowe Iakke foole she sayde
As helpe me god / it wol not be combame
I loue another / ⁊and ellis I were to blame
Wel bet than the / bi Ihıı̄un Absolon
Go forth thi wey or I wil caste a ston
And lete me slepe / a twenty deuel way
Allas qd Absoloıı̄un / ⁊and wayllaway
That trewe loue / was eủere so yuel bisette
Than kisse me / syn it may be no bette
For Ihus loue / ⁊and for the loue of me
Woltow than go thi way / therwith qd she
Ye c̉ertes lemman / qd this Absoloıı̄un
Than make the redy qd she / I come anoon
And vnto Nicholas she seide stille
Now hust / ⁊and thow shalt laugh thi fille .
This Absoloıı̄un doun sette him / on his knees
And saide I am a lord / at alle degrees
For after this I hope / ther cometh more
Lemman thi grace ⁊and swete brid thin ore
The wyndow she vndoth / ⁊and that in haste
Haue do quod she com of ⁊and spede the faste
Lest that oure neghbores / the espie
This Absolon gan wipe his mouthe / ful drye
Derke was the night / as picche or as the cole
And at the wyndowe out / she putte hir hole
And Absolon him fil / no bet ne wers
But with his mouthe / he keste hir naked ers
Ful sauourly / or he were war of this
Abak he sterte / ⁊and thoughte it was amys
For wel he wyste / a woman hath no bered
He felt a thing al rough / ⁊and longe I hered
And seide fy allas what haue I do
Tehe quod she / ⁊and clapt the wyndowe to
And Absolon goth forth / a sory paas
A berde a berde / seide hendy Nicholas
By godis corpus / this goth faire ⁊and wel
This sely Absoloıı̄un herde it eủerydel
And on his lippis he gan for angur bite
And to him selff he seide / I shal the quyte
Who rubbeth now / who froteth now his lippes
With dust / with sonde / with strawe / with cloth / with chippes
But Absoloıı̄un / that seith ful ofte allas
My soule bi take I / vn to Satanas
But me were leuer / than al this toun qd he
Of this dispite a wreken for to be
Allas qd he allas / I ne hadde I bleynt
His hote loue is cold / ⁊and al I queynt
For fro that tyme / that he had kest hir ers
Of paramours / he sette nought a kers
¶ For he was heled / of his maladie
Ful ofte ꝑparamours / he gan diffie
And wepe as doth a child / that is I bete
A softe paas / he wente oủere the strete
Vn to a smyth / men called Daun Geruays
That in his forge / smethith / plough harnays
He sharpith share / ⁊and cultour besily
This Absoloıı̄un knokketh / al esily
And seide vn do Geruays / ⁊and that anoon
What who artow / it am I Absolon
What Absolon / what cristes swete tree
Whi rise ye so rathe / ey benedicite
What eyleth yow / som gay gerle god it woot
Hath brought yow thus / on the viritoot
Bi seynt note ye wot wel what I meene
This Absoloıı̄un ne rought not a beene
Of al his pley / no worde ageyn he gaff
He had more tow / on his distaff
Than Geruays knewe / ⁊and seide frende so dere
The hote cultour in the chemeney here
As lene it me I haue therwith to done
I wol bringe it ageyn / to the ful sone
Geruays answerde / c̉ertes were it golde
Or in a poke nobles / alle vntolde
Thow shuldist haue it / as I am trewe smyth
Ey cristes foo / what wil ye do ther with
Ther of qd Absolon / be as be may
I shal wel tellen it the / to morow or day
And caughte the cultour / bi the colde stele
Ful softe out at the dore / he gan stele
And wente vn to the Carpent̉eris wal
He koughede first / ⁊and knokkede therwithal
Vppon the wyndowe / right as he dede ere
This Alison answerde / who is there
That knokketh so / I warante it a theff
Whi nay qd he / god woot my swete leff
I am thin Absolon / thi derelyng
Of gold qd he / I haue the brought aryng
My moder yaff it me / so god me save
Ful fyn it is / ⁊and therto wel I grave
This wol I yeven the / if thow me kisse
This Nicholas was risen / for to pisse
And thoughte he wolde / amenden al the iape
He shulde kisse his ers / or that he scape
And vp the wyndowe / dide he hastily
And owte his ers / he putte privily
Ouer the buttok / to the haunche boıı̄un
And therwith spak this clerc / this Absoloıı̄un
Speke swete brid / I not where thow art
This Nicholas anoon / leete fle a fart
As grete as it had ben / a thonder dente
That with the stroke / he was almost I blente
And he was redy / with his yren hoot
And Nicholas / in the ers he smoot
Of goth the skyn / an handbrede abovte
The hoote cultour / brend so his tovte
And for the smerte / he wende for to dye
As he were wood / for woo he gan to crye
Helpe water water / helpe for godus herte
This Carpenter / out of his slomber sterte
And herde oon cryen water / as he were wood
And thought allas / now cometh Noyes flood
And sette him vp / withoute wordes mo
And with an ax / he smoot the corde atwo
And doun goth al / he founde neither to seille
No bred nor ale til he com to the selle
Vppon the flore / ⁊and there a swoıı̄un he lay
Vp sterte Alison / ⁊and hende Nicholay
And criden out / ⁊and harow / in the strete
The neighbores / both smale ⁊and grete
In ronnen / for to gavren on this man
That a swown lay / both pale ⁊and wan
¶ For with that fall / he brosten hath his arme
But stonden he moste / to his owne harme
For whan he spak / he was anoon bore down
With hende Nicholas / ⁊and Alisoıı̄un
Thei tolde eủery man / that he was wood
He was so agast / of Noyes flood
Thorurgh fantasie / that of his vanyte
He hadde bought him / knedyng tubbes thre
And hadde hem hanged / in the roff above
And that he praide hem / for godis loue
To sitten in the roff / ꝑpar companye
The folk gan laughwen / at his fantasie
And to the roff thei kyken / ⁊and thei gape
And torned al his harm / vn to a Iape
For what so eủer this Carpenter answerde
It was for nought / no man his resoıı̄un herde
With othes grete / he was so sworn adown
That he was holden wood / in al the town
For eủery clerc anonright / helde with other
Thei seide the man is wood / my leue brother
And eủery wight gan laughwen / at this striff
Thus swives was / the Carpenters wiff
For al his kepyng / ⁊and his ialousie
And Absoloıı̄un hath kest / hir nether eighe
And Nicholas is scalded in his tovte
This tale is don / ⁊and god saue al the route .

Here endith the miller͗e his tale of Absolon and
hende Nicholas
And next folwith the Revis ꝓprolog͗e
Whan folk had laughwen / at this nyce cas
Of Absolon / ⁊and hende Nicholas
Diủerse folk / diủersly thei seide
But for the more part / thei lough ⁊and pleide
Ne at this tale / I saw noman him greve
But it were only Osewolde / the Reve
Bi cause he was / of Carpenters crafft
Alitel Ire / is in his herte lafft
He gan to grucche / ⁊and blamed it alite
So the yk qduod he / ful wel kouthe I yow quyte
With bleryng / of a proude myllers yeghe
If that me list to speke of ribaudie
But yk am olde / me list not pley for age
Gras tyme is don̄ / my fodder is forage
This white toppe writeth / myn olde yeres
Myn herte is also movled as myn heere es
But if I fare / as doth doth an open ers
That ilke frute / is eủere lenger the wers
Til it be roten / in mullok or in stre
We olde men I drede / so faren we
Til we be roten / can we nought be ripe
We hoppen alwey while the world wol pipe
For in oure wil / ther steketh eủere a naylle
To haue an hoor hed / ⁊and a grene taylle
As hath a leek / for though oure myght be gon̄
Oure wil desireth folye eủere in oon̄
For whan we may nought don̄ / than wil we speke
Yit in oure asshen olde / is fire I reke
Foure gledes han we / which I shal devise

¶ noᵃta · iiij ꝓpropertes
longyng to age
div.l: Avauntyng liyng Anger ⁊and covetise
These foure sparkles / longeth vn to eelde
Oure olde lymes mow wel ben vnweeld
But wil ne shal not faylen / that is soth
And yit haue I alwey a coltes toth
As many a yere / as it is passed henne
Syn that my tappe of liff / bigan to renne
For sikerly whan I was born anoon
Deth drough the tappe of liff / ⁊and leete it goon
And eủere sithen / hath so the tappe I ronne
Til that almost / empty is the tonne
The streem of liff / now droppith on the chymbe
The sely tonge / may wel rynge and chymbe
Of wrecchednesse / that passed is ful yore
With olde folke / saue dotage is no more
¶ Whan that oure oost had herde / this s̉ermonyng
He gan to speke / as boldly as a kyng
He seide / what amontith al this witte
What shal we speke alday / of holy writte
The deuel made a Reve / for to preche
Or of a souter / shipman or a leche
Sey forth thi tale ⁊and tarye nought the tyme
Lo Depford / ⁊and it is halfwey pryme
Lo Grenewiche / that many a shrewe is inne
It were al tyme / thi tale to bigynne
¶ Now sires qduod this Osewolde the reve
I pᵃray yow alle / that I yow nought greve
Though I answere / ⁊and somdel sette his howve
For leveful it is / with force / force of to showve
This dronken Miller / hath tolde vs here
How that bigyled was / a Carpentere
ꝐParauenture in skorne / for I am oon
And bi youre leve / I shal him quyte anoon
Right in his cherlis t̉ermes / wol I speke
I pray to god / his necke mote to breke
He can wel in myn yghe / seen a stalke
But in his owne / he can nought seen a balke
Here endith the Revis ꝓprolog

And next folwith
his tale of the Miller͗e ⁊and his wiff how thei were bigile
AT Trumpynton / nought fer fro Cambrigge
Ther goth a broke / ⁊and ouer that a brigge
Vppon the which broke / ther stante a melle
And this is verray soth / that I yow telle
A Miller͗e was there / duellyng many a yere dayyereday
As eny pecok / he was proude ⁊and gay
Pipen he couthe ⁊and fisshen ⁊and nettes bete
And torne coppes / ⁊and wel wrastle ⁊and shete
Ay bi his belt / he bar a longe panade
And of a swerd / ful trenchaunt was the blade
A ioly popper bar he / on his pouche
Ther was no man for ꝑperil / durste him touche
A sheffeld twetil / bar he in his hose
Round was his face / camused was his nose
As piled as an ape / was his sculle
He was a markat beter / at the fulle
Ther was no wight / that durst hand on him legge
But if he swore anoon / he sholde a begge There is an erasure above the "e" in "begge," consistent with a possible original reading "bygge" or "bigge."
A theff he was for soth of corn ⁊and mele
And that a sleigh / ⁊and vsaunt for stele
His name was hoten deynous symkyn
A wiff he hadde comen of noble kyn
¶ The ꝑperson of the town̄ / hir fader was
With hir he yaff / ful may a panne of bras
For that symkyn / shulde in his blood allye
She was I fostered / in a Nonnerye
For symkyn wolde no wiff / as he saide
But she were wel I norsshed / ⁊and a maide
To sauen his estate / of yomanrye
And she was proude ⁊and perte / as is a pye
A ful faire sight was it / vppon hem two
On halidayes to forn hir / wolde he go
With his tipet wonden / al aboute his hede
And she cam after / in a gyte of rede
And Symkyn hadde hosen / of the same
Ther durst no wight / clepen hir but dam
Was noon so hardy / that wente bi the way
That with hir durste rage / or onys play
But if he wolde be slayn / of Symkyn
With panade / or with knyff / or boydekyn
For ielous folk ben ꝑperilous / eủer mo
Algate thei wolde / here wivis / wende so
And eke for she was / somdel smoterliche
She was a digne / as water in a diche
As ful of hoker / ⁊and of bismare
Hir thoughte that a lady / shulde hir spare
What for hir kynrede / ⁊and hir nortelrie
That she hadde lerned / in the Nonnerie
A dought̉er hadde thei / bitwix hem two
Of ·xxᵗⁱ· yere / withouten eny mo
Sauyng a child / that was of halff yere age
In cradel it lay / ⁊and was a ꝓproper page
This wenche thikke / ⁊and wel I growen was
With camoise nose / ⁊and yghen gray as glas
With buttokes brode / ⁊and brestis rounde ⁊and highe
But right faire was hir heere / I wil not lye
¶ The ꝑperson of the town̄ / for she was feyre
In purpose was / to make hir his heyre
Both of his catel / ⁊and his mesuage
And straunge he it made / of hir mariage
His purpose was / to bistowe hir highe
In to some worthi blood / of auncestrie
For holy chirches good / mot ben dispended
On holy chirche blood / that is descended
Ther fore he wolde / his holy blood honour
Though that he holy chirche / sholde devour
¶ Gret sokyn hath this Miller / oute of doute
With whete ⁊and malt / of al the londe a boute
And namely ther was / agrete Collige
Men clepith the Soler halle / at Cambrige
There was here whete / ⁊and eke here malt I grounde
And on a day it happid / in a stound
Sike lay the maunciple / on a maladie
Men wenden wisly / that he shulde dye
For which this Miller͗e / stale both mele ⁊and corn̄
An hundred tyme more / than biforn̄
For ther biforn̄ / he stal but curteysly
But now he was a theff / outrageously
For which the wardeyn / chidde ⁊and made fare
But therof sette the Miller / nought a tare
He crakede bost ⁊and swore / it was nought so
Than were there / yonge scolers two
That dwelten / in the halle / of which I seye
Testiff thei were / ⁊and lusty for to pleye
And oonly for here merthe / ⁊and reuelrie
Vppon the wardeyn / besily thei crie
To yeve hem leve / but a litel stounde
To go to mylle / ⁊and seen here corn̄ I grounde
And hardly thei durste / ley here nekke
The Miller shulde not / stele hem halff a pekke
Of corn / ne bi sleight / ne bi force hem reve
And at the last / the wardeyn yaff hem leve
¶ Iohn hight that oon / ⁊and Aleyn hight that other
Of oon town̄ were thei born̄ / that hight Strother
Fer in the northe / I can nought telle where
This Aleyn makith redy / al his gere
And on an hors / the sak he cast anoon
Forth goth Aleyn the clerc / ⁊and also Iohn
With good swerde ⁊and bokeler / bi here side
Iohn knewe the wey / him neded no gide
And at the Mille / the sak adoun̄ he layth
Aleyn spak first / al hail symon̄ in fayth
How fares thi faire dought̉er ⁊and thi wiff
Aleyn welcome / qduod symkyn bi my liff
And Iohn also / how now / what do ye here
Bigod qduod Iohn / Symond nede has no pere
Him bihoves s̉erue him silff / that has no swayn
Or ellis he is a fool / as clerkes sayn
Oure Maunciple I hope / he wil be dede
Swa werkes ay ther wanges / in his hede
And therfore I is com / ⁊and eke Alayn
To grynde oure corn / ⁊and cary it ham agayn
I pray yow spede vs / hethen in that ye may
It shal be don̄ qduod Symkyn / by my fay
What wil ye don̄ / while that it is in hande
Bigod right by the hoper / wil I stande
Qduod Iohn ⁊and se howgates / the corn gas inne
It saugh I neủere / bi my fader kynne
Howgates the hoper wagges / til ⁊and fra
Aleyn answerde / Iohn wiltow swa
Than wil I be bynethe / by my crowne
And se howgates the mele / falles adoune
In til the trough / that sal be my disporte
Qduod Iohn in faith / I may ben of youre sorte
I is as il a myller / als is ye
This Symkyn smyled / at here nycete
And thoughte / al this nys don̄ but for a wile
They wene noman / may them bigile
But bi my thrift / yit shal I blere here yghe
For al the sleight / in here philosophie
The more queynte crekes / that thei make
The more wil I stele / whan I take
In stede of flour / yit wil I yeve hem brenne
The grettest clerkes / ben nought the wisest menne
As whilom to the wolff / thus spake the Mare
Of al here arte / counte I nought a tare
Out at the dore he goth / ful privily
Whan that he saw his tyme / softly
He lokith vp ⁊and doun̄ / til he hath founde
The clerkes hors / there as it stode I bounde
Behynde the mylle / vnder a levesel
And to the hors he goth / faire ⁊and wel
He stripith of the bridel / right anoon
And whan the hors was lous / he gynneth to goo
Toward the Fen / the wilde Maris renne
And forth with wehe / thorugh thikke ⁊and thynne
This Miller goth ageyn / no worde he seide
But doth his note / ⁊and with these clerkes pleide
Til that here corn / were faire ⁊and wel I grounde
And whan the mele is sakked ⁊and I bounde
This Iohn goth out / ⁊and fynte his hors away
And gan to crie harow / ⁊and weylaway
Oure hors is lost Aleyn / bi godis banes
Stepe on thi fete / com of man / at anes
Allas oure wardeyn / has his palfray lorn
This Aleyn / al forgate / both mele ⁊and corn
Al was out of his mynde / his housbondrie
What whilk way is he gon̄ / he gan to crie
The wiff com lepyng / inward at a ren
She seide allas / youre hors goth to the fen
With wilde maris / as faste as he may go
Vnthank com on his honde / that bounde him so
And he that bett̉er sholde haue knytte the reyne
Allas qduod Iohn / Aleyn for cristes peyne
Ley doun thi swerde / ⁊and I wil myn alswa
I is ful swifft / god wate as is a ra
Bigodis herte he sal nought scape / vs bathe
Whi ne hadde thow put / the caple in the lathe
Il haille bigod Alayn / thow is a fonne
These sely clerkes / han ful faste I ronne
Toward the fen / both Aleyn ⁊and eke Iohn
And whan the Miller / saw they were gon̄
He halff a busshel of here flour hath take
And bade his wiff / go knede it in a cake
And seide I trowe / the clerkes wern a ferde
Yit can a Miller / make a clerkes berde
For al his arte / yit lat hem go here wey
Lo where he goth / ye lat the children pley
They gete him nought / so lightly by my crown̄
These sely clerkes / rennen vp ⁊and down
With kepe kepe / stande stande / iossa warderere
Ga whistil thow / ⁊and I sal kepe hum here
But shortly til it was verry night
Thei coude not / though thei dide al here myght
Here capul cacche / he ran alwey so faste
Til in a diche / thei caught him / at the laste
Wery ⁊and weet / as best is in the rayne
Comyth sely Iohn / ⁊and with him com Alayne
¶ Allas qduod Iohn / the day that I was born
Now are we dreven / til hething ⁊and til scorn̄
Oure corn is stole / men wol vs fonnes calle
Bathe the wardeyn / ⁊and oure felawes alle
And namely the Miller / weylawey
Thus pleyneth Ihon / as he goth bi the wey
Toward the Mille / ⁊and bayard in his honde
The Millere sittyng bi the fire / he fonde
For it was night / ⁊and ferther myghte they nought
But for the loue of god / thei him bisought
Of herborugh ⁊and for ease / as for here penye
The Miller seide ageyn / if ther be enye
Suche as it is / yit shaalsalshal ye haue youre parte
Myn hous is streight / but ye han lerned arte
Ye can bi argument / make a place
A myle brode / of ·xxᵗⁱ· fote of space
Lat se now / if this place may suffice
Or make it rowmer / with speche as is your͗e gise
Now Symond seide this Iohn / bi seint Cutberd
Ay is thow mery / ⁊and that is faire answerd
I haue herde say / men sal taken of twa thinges
Swilke as he fynt / or take swilke as he brynges
But specially I pray the myn host so dere
Gete vs some mete ⁊and drynke / ⁊and make good chere
And we wol payen treuly / at the fulle
With empty hondis / men may noon haukes tulle
Lo here oure seluer redy / for til spende
This Miller to the town̄ / his doughter send
For ale ⁊and breed / ⁊and rosted hem a goos
And bonde here hors / he shulde no more go loos
And in his owne chambre / he made a bedde
With shetis / ⁊and with chalons / faire I spredde
Not from his owne bed / ten fote or twelue
His doughter had a bed / al bi hir selue
Right in the same chambre / bi ⁊and by
Hit myghte be no bet / ⁊and cause why
Ther was no rowmer herborugh / in the place
Thei sopen ⁊and speken / hem to solace
And drynken eủere / strong ale of the beste
Abowte Midnight / wente thei to reste
Wel hath this Miller / vernysshed his hede
Ful pale he was for dronken / ⁊and nought rede
He yoxith ⁊and he spekith / thorugh the nose
As he were on the quakke / or on the pose
To bed he goth / ⁊and with him goth his wiff
As any iay she light was / ⁊and iolyff
So was hir ioly whistel / wel I wette
The cradel at hir beddis fete / is I sette
To rokken ⁊and to yeve the child / to souke
And whan that donken was al / in the crouke
To bedde wente the dought̉er / right anoon̄
To bedde goth Aleyn / ⁊and also Iohn
Ther nas no more / them nedide no dwale
This Miller hath so wisly / bibbed ale
That as an hors he fnortith / in his slepe
Ne of his taile bihynde / he toke no kepe
His wiff bar him a burdon / a ful stronge
Men myghte here rowtyng hire / two forlonge
The wenche rowtith eke / ꝑpar companye
Aleyn the clerke / that herde this melodie
He povkede Iohn ⁊and seide / slepist thow
Herdist thow eủere slike a songe / or now
Lo swilke a covplyng / is btwix hem alle
A wilde fire / on here bodyes fall
Who herde eủere / slike a ferly thinge
Ye thei sal haue the flour / of ille endynge
This longe night / ther tides me noanona reste
But yit na force / as sal be for the beste
For Iohn seide he / as eủer mot I thrive
If that I may / yon wenche wol I swyve
Som esement / hath lawe shapen vs
For Iohn there is a lawe / that seith thus
That if a man / in oo poynte be agreved
That in a nother / he sal be releved
Oure corn is stolen sothly / it is no nay
And we han had / an il fyt to day
And syn I sal haue noon amendement
Agayn my losse / I wol haue easement
Bi godis saule / it sal nan other be
This Iohn answerde / Aleyn avise the
The Miller is a ꝑperilous man / he seide
And if that he / out of his slepe abreide
He myghte don̄ vs bathe / a vilanye
Aleyn answerde / I counte him nought a flie
And vp he rist / ⁊and bi the wenche he crepte
This wenche lay vp right / ⁊and faste slepte
Til he so nygh was / or she myghte spie
That it hadde ben to late / for to crie
And shortly for to seyn / thei were aton̄
Now play Aleyn / for I wol speke of Iohn
This Iohn lith stille / a forlong wey or two
And to him selff / he makith routhe ⁊and wo
Allas qduod he / this is a wikked Iape
Now may mymay I seyn / that I is but an ape
Yit hath my felawe / somwhat for his harm
He has the Millers doughter / in his arm
He auntred him / ⁊and has his nedes spedde
And I lye as a draff sakke / in my bedde
And whan this Iape is tolde / another day
I sal be holden a daff / ⁊and a cokena
I wil arise ⁊and auntre it / by my faith
Vnhardy is vnsely / thus men saith
And vp he ros / ⁊and softely he wente
Vnto the cradel / ⁊and in his hand it hente
And bar it soffte / vn to his beddis fete
Sone after the wiff / hir routyng lete
And gan to wake / ⁊and wente hir vn to pisse
And com ageyn / ⁊and gan hir cradel mysse
And groped here ⁊and there / but she fond noon
Allas qduod she / I hadde almost mys gon̄
I hadde almost gon̄ / to the clerkes bedde
Ey benedicite / than hadde I foule I spedde
And forth she goth /til she the cradel fonde
She gropith alwey ferther / with hir honde
And fonde the bedde / ⁊and thought but good
Be cause the cradel / bi it stood
And nyst wherre she was / for it was derke
But faire ⁊and wel / she crepe in to the clerke
And lith ful stille / ⁊and wolde haue caught a slepe
Withinne a while this Iohn / the clerke vp lepe
And on this good wiff / he leyth on soore
So mery a fytte / ne hadde she not ful yoore
He priketh harde ⁊and depe / as he were madde
This ioly liff / han these two clerkes ladde
Til that the thridde cokke / bigan to synge
¶ Aleyn was wery / in the dawenynge
For he hadde swonkyn / al the longe night
And seide farewel Malyn / swete wight
The day is come / I may no lenger bide
But eủer ma / where swa I ga or ride
I is thin owne clerke / so haue I sele
Now dere lemman / qduod she /go farewele
But or thow go / oo thing I wol the telle
Whan that wendist homward / bi the Melle
Right at the entre of the dore bihynde
Thow shalt a kake of halff a busshel fynd
That was I maked / of thi nowne mele
Which that I hilp / my sire for to stele
And good lemman / god the saue ⁊and kepe
And with that worde / almost she gan to wepe
¶ Aleyn vp rist / ⁊and thought / or that it dawe
I wil go crepen in / bi my felawe
And fonde the cradel / with his honde anoon
Bigod thought he / al wrange I haue mysgon
Myn hede is toty / of my swynke to night
That maketh me / that I go nought right
I wate wil bi the cradel / I haue misga
Here lith the Miller / ⁊and his wiff alswa
And forth he goth / on twenty deuel way
Vn to the bedde / there as the the Miller lay
He wende haue cropen in / bi his felawe Iohn
And bi the Miller / in he crepe anoon̄
And caughte him bi bi the necke / ⁊and softe he spak
He seide thow Iohn / thow swyneshede a wak
For cristis saule / ⁊and hire a noble game
For bi that lord / that called is saint Iame
As I haue thries / in this shorte night
Swyved the Millers dought̉er / bolt vp right
Whils thow hast / as a coward ben agast
Ye fals harlot qduod the Miller hast
A fals traytour / fals clerke qduod he
Thow shalt be deed / bi godis dignite
Who durste be so bolde / to disparage
My doughter / that is comen of swich lynage
And bi the throte bolle / he caughte Alayn
And he hente him / dispitously agayn
And on the nose / he smote him / with his fiste
Down ran the blody stremes / vppon his briste
And in the flore / with nose ⁊and mouthe to broke
Thei walowe as don̄ two pigges / in a poke
And vp thei gon̄ / ⁊and down̄ ageyn anoon
Til that the Miller / spurned at a stoon
And down he fil bakward / vppon his wiff
That wist nothing / of this nyce striff
For she was falle a slepe / a litel wight
With Iohn the clerke / that waked hadde al night
And with the falle / out of hir slepe she brayde
Helpe holy crosse of Bromholm / she sayde
In manus tuas lord / to the I calle
A wake Symond / the fende is on me falle
Myn herte is broken / helpe I nam but dede
Ther lith on vp my wombe / ⁊and vp myn hede
Helpe Symkyn / for the fals clerkes fighte
This Iohn starte vp / as faste as eủere he myghte
And grasped bi the walles / to ⁊and fro
To fynden a staff / ⁊and she starte vp also
And knewe the estres / bet than dide this Iohn
And bi the walle / she fonde a staff anoon̄
And saw a litil shemeryng / of a light
For at an hole / in shon̄ the Mone bright
And bi that light / she saw hem both two
But sikerly she nyst / who was who
But as she saw / a whight thing in hir yghe
And whan she gan / this whight thing espie
She wende the clerke / had wered a volupere
And with the staff / she drough ay nere ⁊and nere
And wende han hitte this Aleyn / at the fulle
And smote the Miller͗e / on the piled skulle
That down̄ he goth / ⁊and cried harow I dye
These clerkes bete him wel / ⁊and lete him lye
And greythen hem / ⁊and toke here hors anoon̄
And eke here mele / ⁊and on here wey thei goon̄
And at the Mille / yit thei toke here cake
Of halff a busshel flour͗e / ful wel I bake
¶ Thus is the proude Miller / wel I bete
And hath I lost the gryndyng / of the whete
And paide for the souper / eủerydele
Of Aleyn ⁊and of Iohn / that bette him wel
His wiff is swyved / ⁊and his doughter als
Lo swiche it is / a Miller to be fals
And therfore this ꝓproủerbe is seide / ful soth
He may nought wilne wel / that yuel doth
A gilour shal him silff / begiled be
And god that sitteth highe in mageste
Saue al this companye / grete ⁊and smale
Thus haue I quytte the Miller / in my tale
Here endith the Reve his tale

And next
folwith the prolog of the Cook of london̄
The cook of london̄ / while the Reve spak
For ioye him thoughte / he clawede him on the bak
A ha qduod he / for cristes passioıı̄un
This Miller / hath a sharpe conclusioıı̄un
Vppon his argument / of herbigage
Wel seide Salamon / in his langage
Ne bring not eủery man / in to thin hous
For herborughyng bi nighte / is ꝑperilous
Wel oughte aman / avised for to be
Whom that he brought / in to his privite
I pᵃray to god / so yeve me sorow ⁊and care
Iff eủere sithen I hight / hogge of ware
Herde I Miller / bett̉ere I sette a werke
He hadde a Iape of malice / in the derke
And therfore / if ye vouchesaff to here
But god forbede / that we stynte here
A tale of me / that am apore man
I wol yow telle / as wel as eủery can
Oure ost ost answerde / ⁊and seide I graunte it the
A litil Iape / that fil in oure cite
Now telle on Roger / loke that it be good
For many a paste / hastow lete blood
And many a Iakke of Doủere hastow soold
That hath ben twies hote / ⁊and twies coold
Of many a pilgrem / hastow cristes course
For of thi ꝑpersely / yit they fare the woirs
That they han eten / with the stubbul goos
For in thi shoppe / is many a flye loos
Now telle on gentil Roger / bi thi name
But yit I pray the / be not wroth for game
Aman may sey ful soth / in game ⁊and play
Thow seist ful soth qduod Roger / by my fay
But soth play quade play / as the flemyng seith
And ther fore Harry Barry / bi thi feith
Be thow nought wroth / or we deꝑparten here
Though that my tale be / of an Ostellere
But natheles / I wol not telle it yit
But or we ꝑparte / I wis thow shalt be quyt
And therwithal he loughe / ⁊and made chere
And seide his tale / as ye shal affter here
Here endith the Cook his prolog And
next folwith his tale of a prentise of london̄
A prentis whilom / dwelt in oure Cite
And of a crafft of vitaillers / was he
And gaylard he was / as goldfynch in the shawe
Broun as a bery / a ꝓpropur shorte felawe
With lokkes blake / I kempt ful fetysly
Daunce he couthe / ful wel ⁊and iolyly
That he was cleped / Perkyn Revelour
He was as ful of love / ⁊and ꝑparamour
As is the hive / ful of hony swete
Wel was the wenche / that with him myghte mete
At eủery bridale / wolde he synge ⁊and hoppe
He loued bet the taủerne / than the shoppe
For whan eny ridyng / was in chepe
Owt of the shoppe / theder wolde he lepe
Til that he hadde / al the sight I seyn
And daunced wel / wolde he not come ageyn
And gedered him a mayne / of his sorte
To hoppe ⁊and synge / ⁊and maken swich dissporte
And there thei sette steven / for to mete
To pleyen at the dys / in swich a stret
For in the town̄ / ther nas no prentice
That fairer coude cast / a peire of dyce
Than ꝑperkyn kouthe / ⁊and therto he was free
Of his dispence / in place of privite
¶ That fonde his maist̉er wel / in his cheffare
For ofte tyme / he fonde his box ful bare
For sekerly / a prentys Revelour͗e
That hauntith dys / riot or ꝑparamour͗e
His maister shal it / in his shoppe abye
Al haue he not parte / of the mynstralcye
¶ For thefft ⁊and Riot / thei ben conủertible
Al konne he pley / on giterne or Rubible
Reuel ⁊and trouthe / as in a a loughe degre
They ben ful wroth alday / as men may se
This ioly prentis / with his maist̉er boode
Til he were nygh out / of his prentishoode
Al were he snybbed / both erly ⁊and late
And somtyme ladde with reuel / to Newgate
But at the laste / his maister him bithoughte
Vppon a day / whan he his paupire soughte
Of a ꝓproủerbe that seith / this same worde
Wel bet is roten appul / owt of horde
Than that it rotie / al the remenaunt
So fareth it / bi a riotous s̉eruaunt
It is ful lasse harm / to late him pase
Than he shende / alle the s̉eruauntis in the place
Therfore his maist̉er / yaff him a quitaunce
And bade him go / with sorow ⁊and meschaunce
And thus this Ioly prentys / hadde his leve
Now late him riote / al the night or leve
And for ther is no theff withouten a lowke
That helpith him / to wasten ⁊and to sowke
Of that he bribe can / or borowe may
Anoon he sende his bedde / ⁊and his array
Vn to a compere / of his owne sorte
That louede dys / ⁊and reuel / ⁊and disport
And hadde a wiff that helde for a contynaunce
A shoppe ⁊and swyved for hir sustynaunce
Here endith the Cook his tale

div.l: (base) Were alle his liges bothe lasse and moore

div.l: (base) I dar the bettre aske of yow a space

(base) And she ay sad and constant as a wal
(base) Continuynge euere hir Innocence ouer al vbique
(base) With pacience Grisild he quiteth
(base) This sturdy Markys gan his herte dresse
(base) To rewen vp on hir wifly stedfastnesse
(base) This is ynogh Grisilde myn quod he
(base) Be now namoore agast ne yuele apayed
(base) I haue thy feith and thy benygnytee
(base) Mankynde which that he wroght
(base) As wel as euere womman was assayed
(base) In greet estat and poureliche arrayed
(base) Now knowe I deere wyf thy stedfastnesse
(base) And hire in armes took and gan hir kesse
(base) And she for wonder took of it no keep
(base) She herde nat what thyng he to hir seyde
(base) She ferde as she hadde stirt out of a sleep
(base) Sche ferd as sche had stert oute of hir slepe
(base) Til she out of hir mazednesse abreyde
(base) Grisilde quod he by god that for vs deyde
(base) Thow art my wyf noon oother I haue
(base) Ne neuere hadde as god my soule saue
(base) This is thy doghter which thow hast supposed
(base) To be my wyf that oother feithfully
(base) Shal be myn heir as I haue ay supposed
(base) Thow bare hym in thy body trewely
(base) At Boloigne haue I kept hem priuely
(base) Tak hem agayn for now maistow nat seye
(base) That thow hast lorn noon of thy children tweye
(base) And folk that oother weys han seyd of me

(base) For no malice ne for no crueltee

div.l: (base) But for tassaye in thee thy wommanhede
(base) And nat to sleen my children god forbede
(base) But for to kepe hem pryuely and stille
(base) Til I thy purpos knewe and al thy wille
(base) Whan she this herde aswowne doun she falleth
(base) For pitous ioye and after hir swownynge
(base) She bothe hir yonge children vn to hir calleth
(base) And in hir armes pitously wepynge
(base) Embraceth hem and tendrely kissynge
(base) Ful lyk a moder with hir salte terys
(base) She batheth bothe hir visage and hir herys
(base) O which a pitous thyng it was to se
(base) O such a pitous þing it was to see
(base) Hir swownyng and hir humble voys to heere
(base) Grant mercy lord god thanke it yow quod she
(base) That ye han saued me my children deere
(base) Now rekke I neuere to been ded right heere
(base) Sith I stonde in your loue and in youre grace
(base) No fors of deeth ne whan my spirit pace
(base) O tendre o deere o yonge children myne
(base) Youre woful moder wende stedefastly
(base) That cruel houndes or som foul vermyne
(base) Hadde eten yow but god of his mercy
(base) And youre benygne fader tendrely
(base) Hath doon yow kept and in that same stounde
(base) Al sodeynly she swapte adoun to grounde
(base) And in hir swogh so sadly holdeth she
(base) Hir children two whan she gan hem tembrace
(base) That with greet sleghte and greet difficultee
(base) The children from hir arm they gonne arace
(base) O many a teer o many a pitous face
(base) Doun ran of hem that stoden hir bisyde
(base) Vnnethe aboute hir myghte they abyde
(base) Walter hir gladeth and hir sorwe slaketh
(base) She riseth vp abaysed from hir traunce
(base) And euery wight hir ioye and feste maketh
(base) Til she hath caught agayn hir contenaunce

div.l: (base) Walter hir dooth so feithfully plesaunce
(base) That it was deyntee for to seen the cheere
(base) Bitwix hem two now they ben met yfeere
(base) Thise ladies whan that they hir tyme say
(base) Han taken hir and in to chambre goon
(base) And strepen hir out of hir rude aray
(base) And in a clooth of gold that brighte shoon
(base) With a coroune of many a riche stoon
(base) Vp on hir hed they in to halle hir broghte
(base) And ther she was honured as hir oghte
(base) Thus hath this pitous day a blisful ende
(base) For euery man and womman dooth his myght
(base) This day in murthe and reuel to dispende
(base) Til on the welkne shoon the sterres lyght
(base) For moore solempne in euery mannes syght
(base) This feste was and gretter of costage
(base) Than was the reuel of hir mariage
(base) Ful many a yeer in heigh prosperitee
(base) Lyuen thise two in concord and in reste
(base) And richely his doghter maried he
(base) Vn to a lord oon of the worthyeste
(base) Of al Ytaille and thanne in pees and reste
(base) His wyues fader and his court he kepeth
(base) Til that the soule out of his body crepeth
(base) His sone succedeth in his heritage
(base) In reste and pees after his fader day
(base) And fortunat was eek his mariage
(base) Al putte he nat his wyf in gret assay
(base) This world is nat so strong it is no nay
(base) As it hath been in olde tymes yore
(base) And herkneth what this Auctour seith therfore
(base) This storie is seyd nat for that wyues sholde
(base) Folwen Grisilde as in humylitee
(base) For it were inportable thogh they wolde
(base) But for that euery wight in his degree
(base) Sholde be constant in aduersitee

div.l: (base) As was Grisilde therfore Petrak writeth
(base) With pacience he Grisilde aquiteth
(base) This storie which he with heigh stile enditeth
(base) For sith a womman was so pacient
(base) Vn to a mortal man wel moore vs oghte
(base) Receyuen al in gree that god vs sent
(base) For gret skile is he preue that he wroghte
(base) But he ne tempteth no man that he boghte
(base) As seith Seint Iame if ye his pistel rede
(base) He preueth folk al day it is no drede
(base) And suffreth vs as for oure excercise
(base) With sharpe scourges of aduersitee
(base) Ful ofte to be bete in sondry wise
(base) Nat for to knowe oure wyl for certes he
(base) Er we were born knew al oure freletee
(base) And for oure beste is al his gouernance
(base) Lat vs thanne lyue in vertuous suffrance
(base) But o word lordynges herkneth er I go
(base) It were ful hard to fynde now a dayes
(base) In al a town Grisildis thre or two
(base) For if that they were put to swiche assayes
(base) The gold of hem hath now so badde alayes
(base) With bras that thogh the coigne be fair at eye
(base) It wolde rather breste atwo than plye
(base) For which heere for the wyues loue of Bathe
(base) Whos lyf and al hir secte god mayntene
(base) In heigh maistrie or ellis were it scathe
(base) I wol with lusty herte fressh and grene
(base) Seye yow a song to glade yow I wene
(base) And lat vs stynte of ernestful matere
(base) Herkneth my song that seith in this manere
(base) Here is ended the tale of the clerk of Oxenford
Grisilde is dede / ⁊and eke hir pacience
And both atonys buried / in Itail
For which I crye / in open audience
No wedded man so hardy be / to a sail
His wivis pacience / in truste to fynde
Grisildis / for in c̉erteyne he shal fail . ¶
O noble wivis ful of highe prudence
Lat noon humilite / youre tongis nail
Ne lat no clerkis haue cause / ne diligence
To write of yow a story / of such mervail
As of Grisildis paciente / ⁊and kynde
Lest Chichevache yow swalowe / in hir entrail .
Folwith Ecco / that holdith no scilence
But eủere answerith / in the contirtail
Beth nat bidaffid / for youre innocence
But sharply take on yow / the goủernail
Enpoynteth wel this lessoıı̄un / in youre mynde
For comune ꝓprofit / sith hit may avail .
And ye Archiwivis / stondith at defence
Syn ye be stronge / as is a grete Camail
Ne suffrith not / that men do yow offence
And slender wivis / as feble in batail
Beith egre as a Tigre / bi yende the se fer in ynde
Ay clappith as a mylle / I yow consail .
Ne dredith hem nought / doith hem no reủerence
For though thyn housbond armed be / in mail
The wordis of thi crabbed eloquence
Shal perssh his breste / ⁊and eke his auentail
In gelousie I rede eke / thow him bynde
And thow shalt make him covche / as a quail .
Yf thow be feyre / there folk ben in psence
Shewe thow thi visage / ⁊and thin apparail
Yf thow be foule / be fre of thi dispence
To gete the frendis / ay do thi travail
Be eủer of chere as light / as leff on lynde
And lete hem care . wepe / wrynge ⁊and wail .
Hre endith the Clerke of Oxenford his tale / and next aft̉er thost spake
This worthi clerke / whan endid was his tale
Oure oste seide / ⁊and swore by Cokkis bonys
Me were lever / than a barel of ale
My wiff at hom / had herde this legende onys ¶
This is a gentil tale / for the nonys
As to my purpos / wist ye my wil
But thing that wol not be / let hit be stil .
Here bigynneth the wiff of Bathe hir ꝓprolog .
Experience though noon autorite
were in this world / is right I nough for me
to speke of wo / that is in mariage
but lordingis syn I / xij. wynt̉er was of age
thanked be god / that is et̉erne on live
housbondis at chirche dore / haue I had five
and I so often / haue wedded be
and alle were worthi men / in there degre
but me was tolde / that longe ago nys
that criste ne wente / neủere but onys
to wedding / in the Cane / of Galyle
that bi the same ensample / taughte he me
that I ne weddid shulde be / but onys
lo herken which a sharp worde / for the nonys
be side awelle / Jhıı̄uns god ⁊and man
spak in repref / of the Samaritan
thow hast had .v. housbondis qd he
and that ilke whiche now hath the
is not thin housbond / thus he seide c̉erteyne
what he ment therby / I can not seyne
but that I aske / whi the .v. man
was not housbond / to the Samaritan
how many myghte she haue / in mariage
that herde I neủere telle / in myn age
of this nombre / definicioun
men mowe demen ⁊and glosen / vp ⁊and doun
but wel I woot expresse / withouten lye
god bad vs wex / ⁊and multiplye
that gentil texte / can I wel vnderstonde
for wel I woot / that myn housbonde
sholde lete fader ⁊and moder / ⁊and take to me
but of nombre / no mensioıı̄un made h
of bigamye / or of octogamye
whi shulde men speke of hit vilonye
lo here the wise kyng Salamon
I trowe he had wivis mo than oon
as wolde god / hit lefful were to me
to ben refresshed / half so ofte as he
which a yift of god had he / for al his wivis
noman hath such / that now on live is
god woot this noble kyng / vn to my witte
the first night / had many a mery fitte .
with eche of hem / so wel was him on live
blissed be god / for I haue had five
of which I haue piked out the beste
both of here nether purs / ⁊and of here cheste
diủers skolis / makith sotil clerkis
and diủers practik / in many sondry werkis
makith the parfectour / man to be sekerly
of five housbondis skoling / am I
wel com the sixte / whan that eủere he shal
I wol him not for sake / nothing at al
whan myn housbonde / is fro the world I goon
som cristen man / shal wedde me anoon
for the Appostil seith / that I am fre
to wedde a godishalff / where hit liketh me
he seith to be wedded / is no synne
bett is to be wedded / than to blynne
what recke me / though men sey wellaweye
of shrewed Lameth / ⁊and of his bigameye
I woot Abraham was / aful holy man
and eke Iacob / as fer as hiryn I can
and eche of them / had mo wivis than two
and many a nother man / hath had also
¶ where can ye sey / in eny maner age
that eủere god / defended mariage
by expresse wordis / I pray yow tellith me
or where commaunded he / eủere virginit
I woot as wel as ye hit is no drede
the Appostil whan he spekith of maydenhede
he seith therof pcept haue I noon
men may consail a woman to be oon
but consail is no maner commaundement
he puttith hit / in oure owne Iugement
for had god comnaunded maydenhede
than had he dampned /wedding withouten drede
and certis if ther were no seede I sowe
virginite what shulde therof than growe
Paule dorst nought / commaunde at the leste
a thing of which his maist̉er / yaf non heste
the darte is sette vp / of virginite
cacche whos may / who renneth best lat se
but this worde is not take / of eủery wight .
but there as god wol yeve hit / of his myght
I woot wel the Appostil was a mayde
but natheles though he spake ⁊and sayde
he wolde that eủery wight / were as he
al nys but consail / to virginite
and for to be a wiff / he yaff me leve
of indulgence / so hit is not to repve
to wedde me / if that my make dye
withouten excepcioıı̄un / of bigamye
al were hit good / no woman for to tovche
he ment in his bed / or in his covche
for ꝑperel hit is / fire ⁊and towe to assemble
ye knowe what this ensample / may resemble
this al ⁊and som / he helde virginite
more parfite than wedding / in freylte
freylte clepe I / but if he or she
wolde leden here liff / in chastite
I graunte hit wel / I haue noon envie
though maydenhede / pferre bigamye
hit liketh hem to be clene / in body ⁊and goste
of myn estate / I wol make no boste
Ful wel I knowe / a lord in his housolde
hath not eủery vessel of golde
some ben of tre ⁊and do here lord suice
god clepith to him folk / in sondry wise
and eủerych hath of god / a ꝓpropir yifte
some this some that / as him list to shifte
virginite is a grete ꝑperfeccioun
and contynence eke / with deuocioıı̄unn
but criste that is of ꝑperfeccoıı̄un the welle
bad not eủery wight / he sholde go selle
al that he had / ⁊and yeve hit to the pore
and in such wise / folwe him ⁊and his lore
he spak to hem / that wolde leve ꝑparfitly
and lordingis bi your leeve / that am not I
I wol be stowe the flour / of al myn age
in the actis ⁊and the fruyte / of mariage
¶ Tel me also / to what conclusioıı̄un
weere membris made / of genacoıı̄un
and in so ꝑparfite wise / and why I wroughte
trust right wel / they were not made for noughte
glose who so wol / ⁊and serch both vp ⁊and doun
that they were made / for purgacioun
of vryne / ⁊and other thingis smale
and eke to knowe / a female / from a male
and for noon other cause / sey ye no
the exꝑperience woot wel / hit is not so
so that ye clerkis / be not with me wrothe
I sey thus / that they ben made for bothe
that is to sey / for office / ⁊and for ease
of engendrure / there we not god displease
whi shulde men ellis / in here bookes sette
that man shulde yelde / to his wiff hir dette
now wherwith shulde he / make his payment
yf he ne vsede / his sely instrument
than were they made / vppon a creature
to purgen vryne / ⁊and eke to engendrur
but I sey not / that eủery wight is holde
that hath such harneys / as I yow tolde
to gon ⁊and vsen hem / in engendrure
than shulde men take of chastite / no cure
crist was a maide / ⁊and shapen as a man
and many an holy seynt sithe the world bigan
yit lived they eủere / in ꝑparfite chastite
I ne wol envie / no virginite
lete hem with brede of pured whete be fedde
and lete vs wivis / ete barly brede
and yit with barly brede Mark telle can
our Lorde Ihu refresshed / many a man
in suche estate as god hath cleped vs
I wol ꝑperceiver / I am nought pcious
in wiffhode wol I vse myn instrument
as frely as my maker / hath hit sent
yiff I be dangerous / god yeve me sorowe
myn housbonde shal it haue both eve ⁊and amorowe
whan that him list / com forth ⁊and pay his dette
an housbonde wol I haue / I wol not lette
which shal be / both my dettour ⁊and my thral
And han his tribulacioıı̄un with al
vppon his flesshe / while that I am his wiff
I haue the power / durynge al my liff
vppon his propre body / ⁊and not he
right thus the Appostel / tolde vn to me
and bad our housbondes / for to love vs wel
al this sentence / me liketh eủerydel
Uppe sterte the pardoner / ⁊and that anoon
now dame qd he / bi god ⁊and bi seint Iohn
ye ben a noble prechour / in this caas
I was abovte to wedde a wiff allaas
what shulde I bye it / on my flesshe so dere
yit had I lever wedde noon to yere
abyde qd she my tale is not bigonne
nay thow shalt drynken / of another tonn
or that I go / shal sauour wers than ale
and whan I haue tolde forth my tale
of tribulacioıı̄un that is in mariage
of which I am expert / in myn age
this is to seie / my silff hath ben the whippe
than maistow chese / whether thow wilt sippe
of thilke tonne / that I shal abroche
be war of hit / or thow to nygh approche
for I shal telle ensamples / mo than ten
who so that wil not / be war bi other men
by him shulle other men corrected be
these same wordis writeth Protholome
rede in his Almageste / ⁊and take it there
dame I wol pray yow / if your wille were
seide this Pardoner / as ye bigan
telle forth your tale spare for no man
and teche vs yongemen / of your practike
gladly qd she / sith it may yow like
but that I pray / to al this companye
if that I speke / after my fantesie
as taketh nought agreff / of that I seye
for myn entente / is not but for to pleye ;
Now sirs than shal I telle yow my tale
as eủere moty drynke wyn or ale
I shal sey soth / tho housbondes that I hadde
as thre of hem were goode / ⁊and two were badde
the thre were goode men / riche ⁊and olde
vnneth myghten thei / the statute holde
in which thei were bounden vn to me
ye wot wel what I meene of this ꝑparde
as god me helpe / I laugh whan I thynke
how pitously a nyght / I made hem swynke
but bi my fay / I tolde of hit no store
thei hadde me yeve here londe / ⁊and here tresore
me nedede nought / do lenger diligence
to wynne here love / ⁊and do hem reủerenc
they loued me so wel bi god above
that I ne tolde no deynte of here love
a wise woman wol besy hir eủere in oon
to gete hir love / ye there as she hath noon
but sith I hadde hem / holly in myn honde
and that thei hadde / yeve me al here londe
what shulde I take kepe hem for to please
but if it were my ꝓprofyte / ⁊and myn ease
I sette hem so a worke / bi my fay
that many a night thei songen welaway
the Bacoıı̄un was not fette for hem I trowe
that som men han in Essex at Donmowe
I goủerned hem so wel after my lawe
that eche of hem / ful blisful was ⁊and fawe
to bringe me gay thingis / fro the feyre
knyvis ryngis ⁊and purses welfeyre
for god it wote I chidde hem spitously
now herkeneth how I bar me ꝓpropurly
¶ ye wise wivis / that can vnderstonde
thus shulde ye speke ⁊and bere hem wronge on honde
for halff so boldly / ther can no man
swere ⁊and lye / as a womman can
I sey not this / bi wommen that ben wise
but it be whan they hem mys avise
a wise wiff if that she can hir goode
shal bere hem on honde the kowe is woode
and take witnesse / of hir owne mayde
of hir assente / but herkeneth how I saide
sir olde keynarde / is this thin aray
whi is my neyghborus wiff so gay
she is honoured oủeral where she goth
I sitte at hom I haue no thrifty cloth
what doistow / at my neighboris hous
is she so feire / artow so amorous
what rownestow / with oure maide bndicite
sir olde lechour / latte thi iapes b
and if I haue a gossipp / or a frende
withouten gilt / ye chiden as a fende
if that I walke or pley vn to his hous
thow comyst hom / as dronken as a mous
and prechist on thi benche / with evel preff
thow seist to me / it is a gret myscheff
to wedde a pore wōmman / for costage
and if that she be riche / of grete ꝑparage
than seistow that it is a tormentrie
to suffre hir pride / ⁊and hir malencolye
and if that she be faire thow verray knave
thow seist that eủery holore wol hir haue
she may nowhile in chastite abide
that is assailed / vppon eủery side
thow seist som folk / desire vs for riches
som for our shapp / ⁊and som for our fayrnes
and som for she can / outher synge or daunce
thus seistow wernard god yeve the myschaunce
som for hir hondis / ⁊and hir armes smale
thus goth al to the deuel bi thi tale
thow seist men may not kepe a castel wal
it may so longe assailled be oủeral
and if that she be foule / thow seist that she
coueiteth eủery man that she may se
for as a spaynel / she wil on him lepe
til that she fynde somman that wil hir chepe
ne noon so grey gos / goth ther in the lake
as seistow / that wil be withouten make
and seist it is an harde thing for to welde
a wight that noman wil his thankes helde
thus seistow lorel whan thow goist to bedde
and that no wise man nedith for to wedde
ne noman that entendith vn to heuen
with wilde thonder dynte / ⁊and fire leuen
mote thi wikked necke / be to broke
thow seist that droppyng houses ⁊and eke smoke
and chidyng wivis maken men to fle
owte of here owne houses a bndicite
what eyleth such an olde man for to chide
thow seist we wivis / wol our vicis hide
til we be faste / ⁊and than we wil hem shewe
wel may this be / a proủerbe of a shrewe
thow seist that oxen assis hors ⁊and hoıı̄undis
they ben assaied / at diủers stoundis
basons lavors / or that men hem bye
sponys stoolis / ⁊and swich housbondrie
and so ben pottis clothis ⁊and other arayes
but of wommen / ben maked noon assayes
til thei be wedded / olde dotard shrewe
and than seistow we wol our vicis shewe
thow seist also / that hit displesith me
but if thow wolt preise my beaute
and but thow poure alwey vppon my face
and clepe me feire dame in eủery place
and but thow make a feste on thilke day
that I was born / ⁊and make me fresshe ⁊and gay
and but thow do to my norice honour
and to my chambre withinne my bour
and to my faders folke / ⁊and his alyes
thus seistow olde barel / ful of lyes
and yit of our apprentice Iankyn
for his crispe heere shynyng as gold fyn
and for he squyerith me vp ⁊and doun
yit hastow kaught / a fals susspecioun
I wil him not / though thow were dede to morowe
but telle me this / whi hidistow with sorowe
thi keys of thi cheste / awey fro me
it is my good as wel as thin ꝑparde
what wenystow make an ydiot of our dame
now bi that lord that called is seint Iame
thow shalt not both though thow were woode
be maist̉er of my body / ⁊and of my good
that on thow shalt for go maugre thin eyen
what helpith hit on me tenquere ⁊and spien
I trowe thow woldist loke me in thi cheste
thow sholdist sey wiff / go where yow leste
taketh your disporte / I wil leue no talis
I knowe yow for agood wiff dame Alis
we loue no man / that takith kepe or charge

For wedlok is so esy / ⁊and so clene

Thus seide this olde knyght / that was so wise
And c̉erteynly / as soth as god is kynge

And namely whan a man is olde ⁊and hore

For hir sadnesse / ⁊and hir benygnite

And praide hem to laboure / in this nede

For than he seide / his spirit was at ease

This is to seyne / in erthe / ⁊and eke in heuen

And for he wolde his longe tale abregge

But seide sir / so ther be noon obstacle

Ye may repente / of wedded man is liff

And ellis god forbede / but he sente

And therfore sir / the best rede I can

ꝑparauenture she may be / youre purgatorie

But fynally / I comyn is the day

Fulfild of beaute / ⁊and of plesaunce

Al moste he swelt ⁊and swouned / there he stood

But there I lete him wepe I now ⁊and pleyne

Oo Ianuarie dronken / in plesaunce
Of mariage / se how thy Damyan
Thi nowne squyer / ⁊and thi born man
Entendith for to don the vilonye

For in this world nys worse pestilence
Than homly foo / alday in thi psence
ꝐPerformed hath the sonne / his arke dyurne

His fressh May / his paradise / his make
He lullith hir / ⁊and kisseth hir ful ofte

And seide thus / allas I mot trespace

This wol be don at leyser / ꝑparfitely
Hit is no force how longe / that we pleye

For in oure actis / we may do no synne

For eủery labour / somtyme mot haue reste
Or ellis longe may he not endure
This is to seyn / no livis creature

I sey o sely Damyan / allas

Telle thi wo / she wol alwey sey nay

God be thin helpe / I can no better sey
This sike Damyan / in Venus fyre
So brennyth that he deyeth for desire
For which he putte his liff / in auenture
No lenger myght he / in this wise endure

Vn to this faire ⁊and fressh lady May ¶
And in a purs of silke henge on his sherte

A bride shal not eten / in the halle
Til daies foure / or thre at the leste

The fourthe day complete / from noon to noon
Whan that the high masse / was I doon
In halle sitt / this Ianuarie / ⁊and May
As fressh as is the bright somes day

Remembrith him / vppon this Damyan
And seide / seint mary / how may this be

Is he ay sike / or how may this betide
His squyers which that stoden be side
Excused him / bi cause of his sikenesse
Which letted him / to do his besynesse
Noon other cause / myght make him tarie
That me forthinkith / qd this Ianuarie
He is a gentil squyer / bi my trouthe

His squyere / for hit was / a gentil dede

Whan ye han ben in chambre / out of this halle
That alle ye gon / to se this Damyan
Doth him disporte / he is agentil man
And tellith him / that I wil him visite
Haue I nothing / but rested me alite
And spede yow faste / for I wol abide
Til that ye slepe / right bi my side
And with that worde / he gan to him calle
A squyer / that was Marchal / of his halle
And tolde him c̉erteyn wordis / what he wolde

This Damyan / whan he his tyme say
In secrete wise his purs / ⁊and eke his bil

Who studieth now / but faire fressh May
And a doun bi olde Ianuarie / she lay

He wolde of hir he seide / han some plesaunce

And lest these pcious folke / be with me wroothe

Til euesonge ronge / ⁊and that thei moste arise

But soth is this / how this fresshe May
Hath take suche impssion that day
On pite of this sike Damyan

c̉erteyne thoughte she / whom that this thing displese

To loue him best / of any creature
Though he no more had / than his sherte
Lo pite renneth sone / in gentil herte

In women is / whan thei hem wel avise
Some tiraunt ther is / as ther ben many oon

Whiche wolde haue lete him sterve / in the place
Wel rather / than han graunted him that grace
And hem reioisen / in here cruel pride
And nought rekke to ben an homecide
¶ This gentil May / fulfilled of al pite

And subtilly this lre / doun she thriste

Some clerkis halden / that felicite
Stante in delite / ⁊and therfore c̉erteyne he

O sodeyne happ o thow fortune vnstable

That he nas ielous / eủer more in oon
Whiche ielousie / hit was so outragious
That neither in halle / ne in noon other hous
Ne in noon other place / neủer the mo
He nolde suffre hir / for to ride ne go
But yiff that he hadde / honde on hir alway
For which ofte wepith / feire fressh May
That lovith Damyan / so benyngnely
That she moot outher deien sodeynly
Or ellis she moot han him / at hir leste
She waitith whan hir herte / wolde breste
Vppon that other side / eke Damyan
Bicomen is the sorowfullest man ¶
That eủer was / for neither night ne day
Ne myghte he speke o worde / to fressh May
As to his purpos / of no such matere
But if that Ianuarie / moste hit here
That had an honde / vppon hir eủer mo
But natheles / bi writyng to ⁊and fro
And privi signys / wiste he what she mente
And she knewe eke the fyne / of his entente
O Ianuarie / what myght hit the avayle
Though thow myghtest se / as fer as shippis saile
For as good hit is / blynde disseived be
As to be disseived / whan a man may se
Lo Argus / that hadde an hundred eighen
For al that he couthe poure / or prien
Yit was he blynt / ⁊and god woot so ben mo
That wenyn wisly / that hit nys not so
Passe oủer is an ease / ⁊and sey no more
This fresshe May / of which I spake of yore
In warm wexe hath enpreynted the cleket
That Ianuarie bare / of the smale wiket
Bi whiche in to his gardeyne / ofte he wente
And Damyan / that knewe / al hir entente
The cleket conterfeted / ful pvily
Ther is no more to sey / but hastily
Some wonder / bi this cleket shal bityde
Whiche ye shulle hire / ⁊and ye wolle abide
¶ O noble Ovide / ful soth is seide god woote
What slight is hit / though it be longe ⁊and hoote
That he nyl fynde hit out / in some mane
Bi Piramus ⁊and Thesbe / may men lere
Though they were kept / ful streight oủeral
Thei ben acorded / rownyng thorugh a wal
Ther is no wight couthe fynde / suche a sleighte
But now to purpos / er that dayes . viijte .
Were passed or the monthe of Iuyl bifille
That Ianuarie hath caughte / so grete a wille ¶
Thorugh eggyng of his wiff / him for to pleye
In his gardeyne / ⁊and no wight but they tweye
That in a morowe / vnto this May seide he
Rise vp my wiff my loue / my lady fre
The turtlis vois is I herde / my douve swete
The wynter is goon / with al his reignes wete
Com forthe with thin eighen columbyne
Ful feirer ben thi brestis / than is wyne
The gardeyne is enclosed / al aboute
Com forth my white spouse / oute of doute
Thow hast me wounded in myn herte o wiff
No spot in the nas / in al thi liff
Com forth ⁊and late vs take oure disporte
I chese yow for my wiff / ⁊and my comforte
Suche olde levde wordis / vsed he
On Damyan a signe made she
That he shulde go bifore / with his cliket
This Damyan / than opened the wiket
And in he sterte anoon / in suche mane
That no wight myght hit se ne here
And stille he sitte vnder abussh aloon
This Ianuarie as blynde is as a stoon
With May in his honde / ⁊and no wight moo
In to his fresshe gardeyn / ben thei goo
And clapt to the wiket / sodeynly
Now wiff qd he / here nys but ye ⁊and I
That arte the creature / that I best loue
For bi that lord / that sitte vs alle aboue
I had leuer to deien / on a knyff
Than yow offende / my trewe dere wiff
For godis sake thenke / how I yow chees
Nought for no couetise doutelees
But only for the loue I had to the
And though that I be olde / ⁊and may not se
Be to me trewe / ⁊and I wol telle yow whi
Thre thinges certis shal ye wynne therby ¶
First loue of criste / ⁊and to youre silff honoure
And al myn heritage / both town ⁊and toure
I yeve hit yow / makith charters as yow liste
This shal be don to morowe / er sonne vp riste
So wisly god my soule brynge at blisse
I pray yow first in couenaunt ye me kisse
And though that I be ielous / wite me nought
Ye ben so depe enprented / in my thought
That whan I considre / yowre beaute
And therwithal / the vnlikly elde of me
I may not c̉ertis / though I sholde dye
For bere to ben out of youre companye
For verry loue this is / withouten doute
Now kisse me wiff / ⁊and lete vs roome aboute
This fresshe May / whan she these wordis herde
Benyngnely to Ianuarie she answerde
But first ⁊and forward / she bigan to wepe
I haue qd she a soule for to kepe
As wel as ye / ⁊and also myn honour
And of my wiffhede / thilke tendre flour
Whiche that I haue assured / in youre honde
Whan the preste to yow / my body bonde
Wherfore I wol answere / in this mane
With the leue of yow / my lord so dere
I pray to god / that neủer dawe that day
That I ne sterve as foule / as woman may
If eủer I do vn to my kyn that shame
Or ellis I enpeire so / my name
That I be fals ⁊and if I do that lakke
To stripe me / ⁊and putte me in a sakke
And in the next revere / do me drenche
I am agentil woman / ⁊and no wenche
Whi speke ye thus / but men ben eủer vntrewe
And women han repreff of yow / ay newe
Ye can noon other contenaunce / I leve
But speke to vs of vnthriste ⁊and repve ¶
And with that worde she saw where Damyan
Sat in the busshe / ⁊and knele he bigan
And with hir fynger / signes made she
That Damyan shulde clymbe / vppon a tre
That charged was with fruyte / ⁊and vp he wente
For verryly he knewe / al hir entente
And eủery signe / that she couthe make
Wel bet than Ianuarie / hir owne make
For in a lett̉er she had tolde him al
Of this matere / how he werchen shal
And thus I lete him sitte / in the pery
And Ianuarie ⁊and May / rownyng ful mery
¶ Bright was the day / ⁊and blew the firmament
Phebus hath of gold / his stremes sente
To gladen eủery floure / with his warmnesse
He was that tyme / in Gemynes / as I gesse
But litil fro his tyme / of declynacion
Of Cancer / ⁊and of Iouis exaltacion
And so bifil / in that bright morwe tide
That in the gardeyne / on the ferther side
Was Pluto that is kyng / of al feirie
And many a lady / in his companye
Folwyng his wiff / the quene Proserpyna
Whiche that he ravisshed out of ꝓproserpina
While that she gadered flouris / in a mede
In Claudyan / ye may the stories rede
How in his grisly carte he hir sette
This kyng of feirie / than adoun him sette
Vppon a benche of torvis / fresshe ⁊and grene
And right anoon thus seide he to his quene
My wiff qd he / ther may no wight sey nay
The exꝑperience pvith hit / eủery day
The treson whiche that women / don to man
Ten hundred thousande / telle I can
Notable of youre vntrowthe / ⁊and brotilnes
Of Salamon richest / of al riches ¶
Fulfilled of sapience / ⁊and of worldly glorie
Ful worthi ben thi wordis / to memorie
To eủery wight that witt ⁊and reson can
Thus preisith he yit / the bounte of man
Amonges athousande men / yit fonde I oon
But of women alle / fonde I neủer noon
Thus seith the kyng that knowith your wikkednes
And Ihc filius Sirak as I ges
Ne spekith of yow / but silde reủerence
A wilde fire / ⁊and a corupt pestilence
So falle vppon youre bodies / yit to nyght
Ne se ye nat / this honourable knyght
Bicause allas that he is blynde ⁊and oolde
His owne man / shal make him Cokewolde
Lo where he sitte / the lechoure in the tre
Now wol I graunte / of my mageste
Vnto this olde worthi / blynde knyght
That he shal han ayen / his eighen sight
Whan that his wiff / wolde do him vilonye
Than shal he knowe al hir harlotrie
Both in repreff of hir / ⁊and other moo
Ye shalt qd Proserpina / ⁊and wol ye soo
Now bi my moders siris soule / I swere
That I shal yeven hir / sufficiaunt answere
And alle women after / for hir sake
That though thei ben / in any gilt I take
With face bolde thei shulle hem silff excuse
And bere hem doun / that wolde hem accuse
For lak of answere / noon of hem shal deyen
Al had ye seyne athing / with both youre eyghen
Yit shul we women / so visage it hardely
And wepe ⁊and swere / ⁊and chide subtilly
So that ye men / shul be / as levde as gees
What recketh me / of youre auctoritees
¶ I woot wel this Iewe / this Salamon
Fonde of vs women foolis many oon ¶
But though that he / ne fonde no good woman
Ther hath I fonde / many another man
Women ful trewe / goode ⁊and v̉ertuous
Witnes of hem / that dwellen in cristis hous
With martirdom / thei preved here constaunce
The Romayne gestis / maken remembraunce
Of many a verry / trewe wiff also
But sir ne be not wroth / al be hit so
Though that he seide / he fonde no good woman
I pray yow takith the sentence of the man
He mente thus / that in soủereyne bounte
Nys noon but god / neither he ne she
Ey verry god / that nys but oon
What make ye so meche of Salamon
What though he made a temple godis hous
What though he were riche / ⁊and glorious
So made he a temple / of fals godis
Who myght do a thing / that more forboode is
ꝐParde als faire as ye / his name implastre
He was a lechour / ⁊and an ydolastre
And in his elde / he verry god forsooke
And if god ne hadde / as seith the booke
I sparid him for his fadris sake / he sholde
Haue loste his reigne / rather than he wolde
I sette nought of al the vilonye
That ye of women write a boterflye
I am a woman / nedis mot I speke
Or ellis swelle til myn herte breke
For sithen he seide / that we ben iangeleresses
As eủer mot I brouke bothe my tresses
I shal not spare / for no curtesie
To speke him harm / that wolde vs vilonye
Dame qd this Pluto / be no lenger wroothe
I yeve hit vp / but sith I swore myn oothe
That I wolde graunte him / his sight agayn
My worde shal stonde / that warne I the c̉ertayn ¶
I am a kyng / hit sitte me not to lye
And I a quene qd she of the feyrie
Hir answere shal she haue / I vnder take
Lete vs no mo wordis / here of make
For soth / I wol no lenger yow contrarie
Now lete vs turne ageyne to Ianuarie
That in the gardeyne / with his fressh May
Syngeth ful meryere / than the popyngay
¶ Yow loue I beste / ⁊and shal ⁊and other noon
So longe aboute the aley is / is he goon
Til he was comyn / ageyns the Perye
Where as this Damyan / sitteth ful merye
An high a monge the fressh levis grene
This fressh May / that is so bright ⁊and shene
Gan for to sike / ⁊and seide allas my side
Now sir qd she for aught that may bitide
I moste haue / of the perys / that I se
Or I mot dye / so sore longeth me
To eten of the smale peris grene
Helpe for hir loue / that is of heuen quene
I telle yow wel / a woman in my plighte
May haue to fruyte / so grete an appetite
That she may dye / but she hit haue
Allas qd he / that I nad here a knaue
That coude clymbe / allas allas qd he
That I am blynde / ye sir no fors qd she
But wolde ye vouchesaff / for godis sake
The pery withinne youre armes to take
For wel I woot / that ye mystrute me
Than shulde I clymbe / wel I now qd she
So I my fote myght sette / vppon youre bak
For soth qd he / in me shal be no lak
Myght I yow helpen / with myn herte bloode
He stoupith down / ⁊and on his bak she stoode
And caughte hir bi a twiste / ⁊and vp she goothe
Ladyes I pray yow / be ye not wroothe ¶
I can not glose / I am a rude man
And sodeynly / anoon this Damyan
Gan pulle vp the smok / ⁊and in he thronge
And whan that Pluto saw / that grete wronge
To Ianuarie he gaff ageyne / his sight
And made him se / as wel as eủer he myght
And whan that he / had his sight agayne
Ther was neủer man of thing / so fayne
But on his wiff / his thought was eủer mo
Vp to the tre / he caste his eyghen two
And saw how Damyan / his wiff had dressed
In suche mane / hit may not ben expressed
But if I wolde speke / vncurteysly
And vp he gaff / a roryng ⁊and a cry
As doth the moder / whan the childe shal dye
Oowte helpe allas / harrow he gan crye
O stronge lady stoure / what doist thow
And she answerde / sir what eylith yow
Haue pacience ⁊and resoıı̄un / in youre mynde
I have yow holpen / on both youre eyghen blynde
Vp perel of my soule / I shal not lyen
As me was tavght / to hele with youre eyghen
Was nothing bet / to make yow se
Than strogle with a man / vppon a tre
God woot I did hit / in ful good entente
Stride qd he / ye algate in hit wente
God yeve yow both / on shames deth to dien
He did the so / I sigh it with myn eyghen
And ellis be I honged / by the hals
Than is qd she / my medicyne al fals
For c̉erteynly / if that ye myghten see
Ye wolde not seye / tho wordis vnto me
Ye han som glymsyng / ⁊and no ꝑparfite sight
I se qd he as wel / as eủer I myght
Thonked be god / with both myn eyghen two
And bi my trouthe me thoughte / he did the so ¶
Ye mase mase goode sir / qd she
This thanke haue I / for I haue made yow se
Allas qd she / that eủer I was so kynde
Now dame qd he / lete al passe out of mynde
Com down my lef / ⁊and if I haue myssaide
God helpe me so / as I am euel apaide
But bi my fader soule / I wende haue seyne
How that this Damyan / had bi the leyne
And that thi smok / had leyne vppon thi brest
Ye sir qd she / ye may wene as yow lest
But sir a man that wakith out of his slepe
He may not sodeynly / ne wel taken kepe
Vppon a thing / ne sen hit ꝑparfitly
Til that he ben a dawed / verrily
Right so a man / that longe hath blynde I be
Ne may not sodeynly / so wel I se
First whan his sight / is newe com ageyne
As he that hath / a day or two I seyne
Til that youre sight / I stabled be a while
Ther may ful many a sight / yow bigile
Beth war I pray yow / for bi heuen kyng
Ful many a man wenyth / to se a thing
And hit is al another / than hit semeth
He that mysconceivith / mys demeth
And with that worde / she lepe doun fro the tre
This Ianuarie / who is glad but he
He kissith hir / ⁊and clippith hir / ful ofte
And on hir wombe / he stroketh hir ful softe
And to his paleys hoom / he hath hir lad
Now goode men I pray yow / to be glad
Thus endith here my tale / of Ianuarie
God blesse vs / ⁊and his moder seynt Marie . Amen .

Here endith the Marchauntis tale of Ianuarie

Here endith the Marchauntis tale of Ianuarie

Ey godis mcy / seide oure ost tho
Now such a wiff / I pᵃy god kepe vs fro ¶
Lo whiche slighthis / ⁊and sotilteis
In women ben / for thei be besy as beis
To vs sely men / for to disseive
And fro a soth / eủer wol thei weive
Bi this marchauntis tale / hit pvith wele
But douteles as trewe as any stele
I haue a wiff / though she pore be
But of hir tonge / a labbyng shrewe is she
And yit she hath an hepe / of vicis mo
Therof no force / lete al such thingis go
But woot ye what / in consail be hit seide
Me rewith sore / I am to hir I teyde
For ⁊and I sholde reken / eủery mane vise
Whiche that she hath / I wis I were to nyse
And cause whi / hit sholde reported be
And tolde to hir / bi some of this mayne
Bi whom it nedith not / to declare
Syn women / conne outere suche cheffare
And eke my witt / suffisith not ther to
To tellen al / therfore my tale is do
Squyer com nere / if that youre wille be
And sey somwhat of loue / for c̉ertis ye
Konne theron / asmech as any man
Nay sir qd he / but I wol sey as I can
With herty wil / for I wol not rebelle
Ageyne youre lust / a tale wol I telle
Haue me excused / if that I speke a mys
My wil is good / ⁊and lo my tale is this .

Here endith the Squyers prolog And
next folwying bigynneth his tale .

(base) Incipit fabula Armigeri
(base) AT Sarray in the land of Tartarye
(base) Ther dwelte a kyng that werreyed Russye
(base) Thurgh which ther deyde many a doghty man
(base) This noble kyng was clepid Kambyuskan
(base) Which in his tyme was of so greet renoun
(base) That ther nas nowher in no Regioun
