div.l: (base) So excellent a lord in alle thyng
(base) Hym lakked noght that longed to a kyng
(base) As of the secte of which that he was born
(base) He kepte his lay to which that he was sworn
(base) And ther to he was hardy wys and riche
(base) Pietous and Iust and eueremoore yliche
(base) Sooth of his word benigne and honurable
(base) Of his corage as any Centre stable
(base) Yong fressh and strong in armes desirous
(base) As any Bachiler of al his hous
(base) A fair persone he was and fortunat
(base) And kepte alwey so wel Roial estat
(base) That ther nas no wher swich another man
(base) This noble kyng this Tartre Cambyuskan
(base) Hadde two sones on Elfeta his wyf
(base) Of whiche the eldeste highte Algarsyf
(base) That oother sone was clepid Cambalo
(base) A doghter hadde this worthy kyng also
(base) That yongest was and highte Canacee
(base) But for to telle yow al hir beautee
(base) It lyth nat in my tonge nyn my konnyng
(base) I dar nat vndertake so heigh a thyng
(base) Myn englyssh eek is insufficient
(base) It moste been a Rethor excellent
(base) That koude his colours longyng for that Art
(base) If he sholde hire discryuen euery part
(base) I am noon swich I moot speke as I kan
(base) And so bifel that whan this Kambyuskan
(base) Hath twenty wynter born his dyademe
(base) As he was wont fro yeer to yeer I deme
(base) He leet the feste of his Natiuitee
(base) Don crien thurgh out Sarray his Citee
(base) The laste Idus of March after the yeer
(base) Phebus the sonne ful iolyf was and cleer
(base) For he was ny his exaltacioun
(base) In Martes face and his mansioun

div.l: (base) In Aries the Coleryk hote signe
(base) Ful lusty was the weder and benygne
(base) For which the foweles agayn the sonne shene
(base) What for the sesoun and the yonge grene
(base) Ful loude songen hir affeccions
(base) Hem semed han geten hem proteccions
(base) Agayn the swerd of wynter kene and cold
(base) This Cambyuskan of which I haue yow told
(base) In Roial vestyment sit on his deys
(base) With dyademe ful hye in his paleys
(base) And halt his feste solempne and so riche
(base) That in this world ne was ther noon it liche
(base) Of which if I shal tellen al tharray
(base) Thanne wolde it ocupie a Someres day
(base) And eek it nedeth nat to deuyse
(base) At euery cours the ordre of hir seruyse
(base) I wol nat tellen of hir straunge sewes
(base) Ne of hir Swannes ne of hir heroun sewes
(base) Eek in that land as tellen knyghtes olde
(base) Eke in that lande men recche of it but smal
(base) Ther is som mete that is ful deyntee holde
(base) That in this land men recche of it but smal
(base) Ther nys no man that may reporten al
(base) I wol nat tarien yow for it is pryme
(base) And for it is no fruyt but los of tyme
(base) Vnto my firste I wol haue my recours
(base) And so bifel that after the thridde Cours
(base) Whil that this kyng sit thus in his nobleye
(base) Herknynge his Mynstrals hir thynges pleye
(base) Biforn hym at the bord deliciously
(base) In at the halle dore al sodeynly
(base) Ther cam a knyght vpon a steede of bras
(base) And in his hand a brood Mirour of glas
(base) Vpon his thombe he hadde of gold a ryng
(base) And by his syde a naked swerd hangyng
(base) And vp he rydeth to the heighe bord
(base) In al the halle ne was ther spoke a word

div.l: (base) For merueille of this knyght hym to biholde
(base) Ful bisily they wayten yonge and olde
(base) This straunge knyght that cam thus sodeynly
(base) Al armed saue his heed ful richely
(base) Salueth kyng and queene and lordes alle
(base) By ordre as they seten in the halle
(base) With so heigh reuerence and obeisaunces
(base) As wel in his speche as in his contenaunces
(base) That Gawayn with his olde curteisye
(base) Thogh he were come agayn out of Fairye
(base) Ne koude hym nat amende with a word
(base) And after this biforn the hye bord
(base) He with a manly voys seyde his message
(base) After the forme vsed in his langage
(base) Withouten vice of silable or of lettre
(base) And for his tale sholde seme the bettre
(base) Acordant to his wordes was his cheere
(base) As techeth art of speche hem that it leere
(base) Al be that I kan nat sowne his style
(base) Ne kan nat clymben ouer so heigh a style
(base) Yet seye I this that as to commune entente
(base) Thus muche amounteth al that euere he mente
(base) If it so be that I haue it in my mynde
(base) He seyde the kyng of Arabe and of Inde
(base) My lige lord on this solempne day
(base) Salueth yow as he best kan and may
(base) And sendeth yow in honour of youre feste
(base) By me that am al redy at youre heste
(base) This Steede of bras that esily and weel
(base) Kan in the space of o day naturel
(base) This is to seyn in twenty foure houres
(base) Wher so yow list in droghte or ellis shoures
(base) Beren youre body in to euery place
(base) To which youre herte wilneth for to pace
(base) Withouten wem of yow thurgh foul or fair
(base) Or if yow list to flee as hye in the Ayr

div.l: (base) As dooth an Egle whan hym list to soore
(base) This same Steede shal bere yow eueremoore
(base) Withouten harm til ye be ther yow leste
(base) Though that ye slepen on his bak or reste
(base) And turne agayn with writhyng of a pyn
(base) He that it wroghte koude many a gyn
(base) He wayted many a constellacioun
(base) Er he hadde doon this operacioun
(base) And knew ful many a seel and many a bond
(base) This Mirour eek that I haue in myn hond
(base) Hath swich a myght that men may in it see
(base) Whan ther shal fallen any aduersitee
(base) Vnto youre regne or to your sel also
(base) And openly who is youre freend or fo
(base) And oueral this if any lady bright
(base) Hath set hir herte on any maner wight
(base) If he be fals she shal his trayson see
(base) His newe loue and al his subtiltee
(base) So openly that ther shal no thyng hyde
(base) Wher fore agayn this lusty someres tyde

div.l: (base) And reson wolde eek that he moste go
(base) For his honour as ofte happeth so
(base) Wherfor I wold not ben ayein his honour
(base) That I made vertu of necessitee
(base) And took it wel syn that it moste be
(base) As I best myghte I hidde from hym my sorwe
(base) And took hym by the hand Seint Iohn to borwe
(base) And seyde thus lo I am youres al
(base) Beeth swich as I to yow haue been and shal
(base) What he answerde it nedeth nat reherse
(base) Who kan seyn bet than he who kan doon werse
(base) Whan he hath al wel seyd thanne hath he doon
(base) Therfore bihoued hire a ful long spoon
(base) That shal ete with a feend thus herde I seye
(base) So at the laste he moste forth his weye
(base) And forth he fleeth til he cam ther hym leste
(base) Whan it cam hym to purpos for to reste
(base) I trowe he hadde thilke text in mynde
(base) That alle thyng repeiryng to his kynde
(base) Gladeth hymself thus seyn men as I gesse
(base) Men louen of propre kynde Newfangelnesse
(base) As bryddes doon that men in Cages feede
(base) For theigh thow nyght and day take of hem hede
(base) And strawe hir Cages faire and softe as sylk
(base) And yeue hem sugre hony breed and Milk
(base) Yet right anon as that his dore is vppe
(base) He with his feet wol sporne doun his cuppe
(base) And to the wode he wole and wormes ete
(base) So newfangel been they of hir mete
(base) And louen nouelries of propre kynde
(base) No gentilesse of blood may hem bynde
(base) So ferde this gentil tercelet allas the day
(base) Thogh he were gentil born and fressh and gay
(base) And goodlich for to seen and humble and free
(base) He saw vpon a tyme a kyte flee
(base) And sodeynly he loued this kyte so
(base) That al his loue is clene fro me ago

div.l: (base) And hath his trouthe falsed in this wise
(base) Thus hath the kyte my loue in hir seruyse
(base) And I am lorn withouten remedye
(base) And with that word this Faukon gan to crye
(base) And swowned eft in Canacees barm
(base) Greet was the sorwe for the haukes harm
(base) That Canacee and alle hir wommen made
(base) They nyste how that they myghte the Faukon glade
(base) But Canacee hom bereth hire in hir lappe
(base) And softely in plastres gan hir wrappe
(base) Ther as she with hir beek hadde hurt hir selue
(base) Now kan nat Canacee but herbes delue
(base) Out of the grownd and maken saues newe
(base) Of herbes preciouse and fyn of hewe
(base) To heelen with this hauk fro day to nyght
(base) She dooth hir bisynesse and al hir myght
(base) And by hir beddes heed she made a Muwe
(base) And couered it with veluettes blue
(base) In signe of trouthe that is in wommen sene
(base) And al withoute the Muwe is peynted grene
(base) In which were peynted alle thise false fowles
(base) As been thise tydyues terceletz and Owles
(base) Right for despit were peynted hem bisyde
(base) And Pyes on hem for to crye and chyde
(base) Thus lete I Canacee hir hauk kepyng
(base) I wol namoore as now speke of hir ryng
(base) Til it come eft to purpos for to seyn
(base) How that this Faukon gat hir loue ageyn
(base) Repentant as the storie telleth vs
(base) By mediacion of Cambalus
(base) The kynges sone of which I to yow tolde
(base) But hennes fort I wol my proces holde
(base) To speke of auentures and of batailles
(base) That neuere yet was herd so greet meruailles
(base) First wol I telle yow of Cambyuskan
(base) That in his tyme many a Citee wan

Here endith the squyer his tale And nexte
bigynneth the man of lawe his prolog ⁊cetc
Ovre Oste saw wel / that the bright sonne
The arke of his artificial day had ronne
The forthe ꝑparte / ⁊and halff an houre ⁊and more
Al though he were not / most expert in lore
He wiste hit was / the xviij day
Of Appril / that is the messager of May
And saw wel / that the shadowe of eủery tre
Was as in lengthe / the same quantite
As was the body erecte / that caused hit
And therfore bi the shadowe / he toke his witt
That Phebus which that shone / so clere ⁊and bright
Degrees was xlv clomben on hight
And for that day / as in that latitude
Hit was x at the clokke / he gan conclude
And sodenly he plight his hors aboute
Lordinges qd he / I warne yow al this route ¶
The ferthe ꝑparty of this daye is gon
Now for the loue of god ⁊and of seint Iohn
Lesith no tyme / as fer forthe as ye may
Lordinges the tyme wastith night ⁊and day
And stelith from vs / what pⁱriuyly sleping
And what thorugh necligence ⁊and our̉e wakyng
As doth the streme that turneth neủer ageyne
Descendyng fro the montayne / in to the pleyne
Wel can Senec / ⁊and many a Philosophre
Biwailen tyme / more than gold in cofre
For los of catel / may recoủered be
But losse of tyme / shendith vs qd he
It wil not come ageyne / withouten drede
No more than wol Malkyns maidenhede
Whan she hath it lost / in hir wantonnes
Lat vs not movlen thus / in ydelnes
Sir man of lawe qd he so haue ye blis
Tel vs a tale now as forward is
Ye be submitted / thorugh youre fre assent
To stonden in this caas at my iugement
Acquyteth yow now / of youre heheste
Than haue ye don youre devoyre at the leste
Oste qd he dꝑpardeux ich assente
To breke forward / is nought myn entente
Beheste is dette ⁊and I wol holden feyne
Al my beheste / I can no better seyne
For suche lawe / as aman yevith another wight
He sholde him silff vsen hit of right
Thus wil oure texte but natheles c̉erteine
I can right now no thrifty tale seine
That Chaucers though he can but lewdely
On metres ⁊and in rymyng craftyly
Hath seide hem in suche Inglissh as he can
In olde tyme as knowith many a man
And if he haue nought / leve brother
In o booke / he hath seide hem / in a nother ¶ꝓpro
For he hath tolde of lovers vp ⁊and dovn
Moo than Ovide made of mension
In his Epistelis that ben ful oolde
What sholde I tellen hem / sen thei ben tolde
¶ In youthe he made / of Ceys ⁊and Alkyon
And sithen hath he spoken of eủerychon
These noble wivis / ⁊and these louers eke
Who so that wil / his large volume seke
Cleped the seintis legent / of Cupide
There may ye se / the large woundis wide
Of Lucres / ⁊and of Babiloyne / Thhisbe
The swerde of Dido / for the fals Eue
The tree of Phillis / for hir Demephon
The pleinte of Diainyre / ⁊and of Ermyon
Of Adriane / ⁊and of I siphilee
The bareyne yle / stondyng in the see
The dreynt Leandre / for his Erro
The teres of Eleyne / ⁊and eke the woo
Of Brixseide / ⁊and of Ladomea
The cruelte of the quene / Medea
The litil children / hongyng bi the hals
For thi Iason that was of loue fals
Of Epymystra / Penolope / ⁊and Alceste
Youre wifhode commendyng with the beste
But c̉erteynly no worde writith he
Of thilke wikked ensample / of Canace
That louede hir owne brother synfully
Of whiche cursed stories / I sey fy
Or ellis of Tiro Appollonyus
How that the cur sed kyng Antiochus
Birafte his dought̉er / of hir maidenhede
That is so orrible a tale / for to rede
Whan he hir threwe vppon the pauement
And therfore he of ful avisement
Nolde neủer write in noon of his sermons
Of suche vnkynde abhomynacions ¶
Ne I ne wol noon reherse / if that I may
But of my tale how shal I doıı̄un this day
Me were lothe to be likened douteles
To muses that men clepen Piarides
Methamorphoseos / woote what I meene
But natheles / I rekke nought a beene
Though I come after him / with haue we bake
I speke in prose / ⁊and lete him rymes make
And with that worde / he with a sobre chere
Bigan his tale / as ye shal after here

O Hateful harme / condicion of pouert
With thrust / with coolde / wᵗith hungre so cōnfoundid
To asken helpe the shameth / in thin hert
If thow noon axe / with nede thow art so woundid
That verry nede vnwrappith / al thi woundes hid
Maugre thin hede / thow most for indigence
Or steele / or begge / or borowe / thi dispence
Thow blamest crist / ⁊and seist ful bittirly
He mys dꝑpartith richesse / temporal
Thi neighbour / thow witest synfully
And seist / thow haste to litil ⁊and he hath al
ꝐParfey seist thow / sumtyme he reken shal
Whan that his tayle / shal brenne in the glede
For he nought helpith / the nedeful in here nede
Herken what is the sentence / of the wise
Bett is to dien than to haue indigence
Thi silff neighbour / wol the dispise
If thow be pore / fare wel thi reuerence
Yit of the wise man / take this sentence
Alle the dayes of pore men / ben wikke
Be war therfore / or thow come in that prikke
Yff thow be pore / thi brother hateth the
And alle thi frendes / fle fro the allas
O riche marchauntis ful of welbeye ¶
O noble ⁊and prudent folke / as in this cas
Youre bagges ben not filled / with ambes aas
But with sise synke / that renneth in your̉e chaunce
At cristes masse / ful mery may ye daunce
¶ Ye seken londe ⁊and see / for youre wynnynges
As wise folke / that knowen al the astate
Of regnes ye ben faders of tithinges
And talis both of pees / ⁊and debate
I was right now of a tale desolate
Ner that a marchaunt / gon is many a yere
Me taughte a tale / which thyeth ye shul here
¶ In Surre vmwhile / dwelled a companye
Of chapmen riche / ⁊and therto sadde ⁊and trewe
That widewhere senten / there spicerye
Clothis of gold / ⁊and satyn riche of hewe
Here cheffare was so thrifty / ⁊and so newe
That eủery wight hath deynte to chaffare
With hem / ⁊and eke to sellen hem here ware
¶ Now fel hit that the maistres / of that sorte
Haue shapen hem / to Rome for to wende
Were hit for chapmanhode / or for disporte
Non other messager / wolde thei theder sende
But cam hem silff to Rome / this is thende
And in suche place / as thoughte hem avantage
For here entente / thei take here herbigage
¶ Soiorned haıı these marchauntis / in that toun
A certeyne time / as fil to here plesaunce
But so bifel that the excellent renoun
Of the Emꝑperouris doughter / dame Custaunce
Reported was / with eủery circumstaunce
Vn to this surrien marchauntis / in such wise
Fro day to day / as I shal yow devise
¶ This was the comune voice / of eủery man
Oure Emꝑperour of Rome / god him se
A doughter he hath / that sithen the world bigan
To reken as wel hir goodnes / as beaute ¶
Was neủere suche another as is she
I pray to god in honour / hir sustene
And wolde she were of al Europe the quene
¶ In hir is high beaute / withoute pride
Youthe withouten greff or folye
To alle hir werkes vertu is hir gyde
Humblesse hath sleyne in hir / al tirannye
She is a myrour / of al curtesie
Hir herte is verry chambre of holynesse
Hir honde ministre of fredam ⁊and almesse
¶ And al this voice was soth as god is trewe
But now to purpos / lete vs torne ageyne
This machauntis haıı don fraught here shippes newe
And whan thei haıı / this blisful maide seyne
Hom to surrey ben thei wente a yeyne
And don here nedes / as thei haıı don yore
And liven in wel / I can sey yow no more
¶ Now fel hit that these marchauntis stoden in grace
With him that was the Souldan of Surrye
For whan thei cam from any strange place
He wolde of his benigne curtesie
Make hem good chere / ⁊and besily aspie
Tidinges of sondry regnes / for to lere
The wonderest that thei myghte se ⁊and here
¶ Amonges other thinges specially
These marchauntis haue him tolde / of dame Custaunce
So grete noblisse in ernest / curiousely
That this Souldan / hath caughte so grete plesaunce
To haue hir figure / in his remembraunce
And al his lust / ⁊and al his besi cure
Was to loue hir / while that his liff may dure
¶ Perauenture / in that large booke
Whiche that I clepe the heuen / I wreten was
With sterris / whan that he his birthe tooke
That he for loue / sholde haue his deth allas
For in the sterris clerer / than is the glas ¶
Is wreten god woote / who so coude it rede
The deth of eủery man / withouten drede
¶ In sterris many a wynt̉er there biforn
Was wreten the dethe / of Ector ⁊and Achilles
Of Pompe / Iulyus / or thei were born
The striff of Thebes / ⁊and of Hercules
Of Sampson Turnius / ⁊and of Socrates
The dethe / but men is wittis ben so dulle
That no wight can rede hit / at the fulle
¶ This Souldan / for his privi consaile sente
And shortly of this matier / for to pace
He hath to hem declared / his entente
And seide hem c̉erteyne / but he myghte haue grace
To haue Custaunce / withinne alitil space
He nas but dede / ⁊and charged hem on highe
To shapen for his liff / som remedie
¶ Diủerse men / diủerse thinges seiden
The argumentis / casten vp ⁊and doun
Many a subtil reson / forthe thetherther leyden
Thei speken of Magik / ⁊and of abusioun
But fynalli / as in conclusioun
Thei can not sen in that / noon avantage
Ne in noon other wey / saue in mariage
¶ Than saw they therinne / suche difficulte
Bi wey of reson / for to speke as pleyne
Bi cause that ther was / suche diủersite
Bitwene there both lawis / as thei seine
Thei trowen that no cristen pⁱrince / wolde feyne
Wedden his childe / vnder here lawes swete
That hem was taught / bi Mahoıı̄un the ꝓprophete
¶ And he answerde / rather than I lese
Custaunce / I wil be cristened douteles
I mot ben hirs / I may noon other chese
I pᵃy yow holde youre argumentis / in pees
Saueth my liff ⁊and beth nought recheles
To gete hir / that hath my liff in cure ¶
For in this woo I may not longe endure
¶ What nedith gretter dilatacion
I sey bi tretyse / ⁊and bi embassiatrie
And bi the popis mediacion
And al the chirche / ⁊and al the chiualrie
That in distruccion / of mavmetrie
And in encrese / of cristes lawe dere
Thei ben accorded / so as ye shul here
¶ How that the Souldan / ⁊and his baronage
And alle his lieges / sholde I cristened be
And he shal haue Custaunce / in mariage
And c̉erteine gold / I not what quantite
And ther to founde thei / sufficiant suerte
This same accorde / was sworn on either side
Now faire Custaunce / almyghti god the gide
¶ Now wolde som man / waiten as I gesse
That I sholde telle / al the purviaunce
That the Emꝑperour / of his grete noblesse
Hath shapen for his dought̉er / dame Custaunce
Wel may men knowe / that so grete ordynaunce
May noman tellen / in a litil clause
As was arraied / for so high a cause
¶ Cardynals ⁊and busshopus / be shape wᵗith hir to wende
Lordis ⁊and ladies / ⁊and knyghtes of renoun
And other folke I nowe / this is the ende
And notified it is / thorughoute the toun
That eủery wight / with grete deuocioun
Sholde pray to criste / that he this mariage
Resceive in gre / ⁊and spede this viage
¶ The day is come / of hir deptynge
I sey that woful day fatal / is come
That ther may be / no lenger tariynge
But forward thei hem drese / alle ⁊and some
Custaunce that with sorow is al oủer come
Ful pale arisith / ⁊and dressith hir to wende
For wel she seith ther is noon other ende ¶
¶ Allas what wonder is it though she wepte
That shal be sente to so strange nacione
Fro frendes that so tenderly hir kepte
And to be bounden / vnder subieccione
Of oon she knowith not / his condicione
Housbondes ben alle gode / ⁊and haue ben yore
That knowen wivis I dar sey yow no more
¶ Fader she seide / thi wrecched childe Custaunce
Thi yonge doughter / fostred vp so softe
And ye my moder / my soủereyne plesaunce
Oủer althing / outtake criste on lofte
Custaunce youre childe / hir coumaundith ofte
Vn to youre grace / for I shal to Surrye
Ne shal I neủer sen yow more / with eyghe
¶ Allas vnto the Barbre nacion
I most anoon / syn hit is youre wille
But crist that starff / for oure redempcion
So yeve me grace / his hestis to fulfille
I wrecched woman / no force though I spille
Women ben born to thraldom / ⁊and penaunce
And to ben vnder men is goủernaunce
¶ I trewe at Troy / whan brake the wal
Or ylion that brende Thebes / the cite
Ne Rome for the harme / of Hanybal
That Romayns hath venquesshed / times thre
Nas herde suche tendre weping / for pite
As was in the chambre / for hir dꝑpartinge
forth she moot whether she wepe or synge
¶ O frosty mornyng / cruel firmamente
With thi dym nal / which that croudist ay
And hurlist al fro the est / to the occidente
And naturelly wolde holde / another way
Thi croudyng sitteth the heuen / in such array
At the bigynnyng / of this fers viage
That cruel Mars hath slayne / this mariage
¶ Infortunate ascendent / tortuous ¶
Of whiche the lorde is helpeles falle allas
Out of his angle / into the derkest hous
O Mars as in this caas
O feble mone / vnhappy be thi paas
Thow knettest the / there thow art nought resceived
There thow were wel / fro thens artow now weived
¶ Imprudent Emꝑperour̉e of Rome allas
Was ther no Philosophre / in al thi toun
Is no tyme bet than other / in such cas
Of viage is ther noon eleccioun
Namely to folke / of highe condicion
Nat whan a rote / is of a birthe I knowe
Allas ye ben to levde / or to slowe
¶ To shippe is brought / this woful faire maide
Solempnely / with eủery circumstaunce
Now ihu criste / be with yow alle she saide
There is no more / but farewel faire Custaunce
She peyneth hir to make / good contenaunce
And forth I lete hir sayle / in this mane
And turne I wol ageyne / to my matere
¶ The moder of the Souldan / welle of vicis
Espiede hath hir sones pleyne entente
How he wol lete / his olde sacrificis
And right anoon she for hir consaile sente
And thei come to knowen / what she mente
And whan assembled was / this folke infere
She sette hir doun / ⁊and seide as ye shul here
¶ Lordes she seide / ye knowe eủerychon
How that my sone inpoynte is for to lete
The holy lawes of oure Alkaron
Yeven bi godis messager Makomete
But oon avowe / to grete god I hete
The liff shal rather / out of my body sterte
Or Makametis lawe / go out of myn herte
¶ What sholde vs tiden / of this newe lawe
But thraldom / to oure bodies ⁊and penaunce ¶
And afterward in helle / to be drawe
For we renyede Mahon / oure creaunce
But lordes wil ye maken assuraunce
As I shal seyne / assentyng to my lore
And I shal make vs sauff / for eủermore
¶ Thei sworen ⁊and assenten / eủery man
To live with hir / ⁊and deye / ⁊and bi hir stonde
And eủerych in the best wise he can
To strengthen hir / shal alle his frendis Fonde
And she hath this emprise / take on honde
Whiche ye shal hire / that I shal devise
And to hem alle she spak / in this wise
¶ We shulle first feyne vs / cristendom to take
Colde water shal not greve vs / but alite
And I shal such afeste / ⁊and reuel make
That as I trowe / I shal the Souldan quyte
For though his wiff be cristened neủer so white
She shal haue nede / to wasshe a wey the rede
Though she a fonte ful of wat̉er / with hir lede
¶ O soudonesse / rote of iniquite
Virago thow Semyrian the secounde
O serpent / vnder femenite
Like to the serpent / depe in helle I bounde
O feyned woman / al that may confounde
Vertu ⁊and innocence thorugh thi malice
Is bred in the as nest of eủery vice
¶ O sathan envious / syn thilke day
That thow were chased / from oure heritage
Wel knowest thow to women / the olde way
Thow madist Eue bringe vs in suage
Thow wolt fordon / this cristen mariage
Thin instrument / so wel away the while
Makist thow woman whan thow wolt bigile
¶ This Souldanesse whom I thus blame ⁊and warye
Lete pⁱrivily hir consail gon there waye
What sholde I in this tale lenger tarye ¶
She rideth to the Souldan on a day
And seide / she wolde renye hir lay
And cristendom of prestis hondes fonge
Repentyng hir / she hethen was so longe
¶ Biseching him / to don hir that honoure
That she myghte haue the cristen folke to feste
To plese hem / I wol do my laboure
The Souldan seith / I wol do at youre heste
And knelyng thonkith hir / of that requeste
So glad he was / he nyst what to seye
She kissed hir sone / ⁊and hom she goth hir weye
¶ Arrived ben these cristen folke / to londe
In Surrye with agrete solempne route
And hastily this Souldan sente his sonde
First to his moder / ⁊and to al the regne aboute
And seide his wiff was comen / oute of doute
And praide hir for to rn / ayenst the quene
The honour of his regne to sustene
¶ Grete was the pres / ⁊and riche was the araye
Of Surreyens ⁊and Romayns / mette infere
The moder of the Souldan / riche ⁊and gaye
Resceivith hir / with also glad a chere
As any moder myghte hir doughter dere
And to the nexte cite / there biside
A soft pas / solempnely / thei ride
¶ Nought trow I / the tryumphe of Iulius
Of whiche that Lucan / makith such a booste
Was royaller / ne more curious
Than was thassemble / of this blisful hooste
But this skorpion / this wikked gooste
This Souldanesse / for al hir flaterynge
Cast vnder this / ful mortally to stynge
¶ The Souldan cometh him silff / soone aft̉er this
So royally / that wonder was to telle
And welcometh hir / with alle ioye ⁊and blis
And thus in merthe ⁊and ioye I lete hem duelle ¶
The fruyte of eủery tale / is for to telle
Whan tyme cam men thought it for the beste
That reuel stynte / ⁊and men gon to reste
¶ The tyme cam / this olde Souldanesse
Ordeyned hath this feste of whiche I tolde
And to the feste / cristen folke hem dresse
In genal / both yonge ⁊and olde
There may men feste / ⁊and roialte biholde
And deyntees mo / than I can devise
But al to dere thei boughte hit / or thei rise
¶ O sodeyne wo / that eủer art successour
To worldly blis / spreynte is with bitt̉ernes
The ende of oure ioye / ⁊and oure wordly labour
Wo ocupieth the fyne / of oure gladnes
Herken this I consaile for thi securenes
Vppon thi glad day / haue in mynde
The vnwar wo or harme / that cometh behynde
¶ For shortly to tellen / at o worde
The Souldan / ⁊and the cristen eủerychone
Ben al to hewe / ⁊and stiked / at the borde
But it were only dame Custaunce alone
This olde Souldanesse / this cursed crone
Hath with hir frendes / don this cursed dede
For she hir silff / wolde al the contre lede
¶ Ne there nas Surreyne noon / that was conủerted
That of the consaile / of the Souldan woote
That he nas al to hewen / or he asterted
And Custaunce haıı thei take / anoon fote hoote
And in a shipp stereles / god hit woote
Thei haue hir sette / ⁊and bad hir lerne to saile
Oute of Surrey / ayenward to ytaile
¶ A c̉erteyne tresoure / that she theder ladde
And soth to seyne / vitaille grete plente
Thei haue hir yeven / ⁊and clothis eke she hadde
And forth she sailith / in the salte se
O my Custaunce ful of benignite ¶
O Emꝑperouris yonge doughter dere
He that is lorde / oủer fortune be thi stere
¶ She blissith hir ⁊and with aful piteous voice
Vn to the croys of crist / thus seide she
O clere o welful auter / holy croice
Rede of the lambes blode / ful of pite
That whisse the world / fro the olde iniquite
Me fro the fende / ⁊and from his clawis kepe
That day that I shal drenchen in the depe
¶ Victorious tre / proteccion of trewe
That onely worthi were / for to bere
The kynge of heuen / with his woundes newe
The white lambe / that hurte was with a peresperespere
Flemer of fendes / oute of heuen ⁊and here
On whiche thi lynes / feithfully extenden
Me kepe ⁊and yeve myghte / my liff to amenden
¶ Yeres ⁊and dayes / fleteth this creature
Thorughoute the se of Grece / in to the straite
Of Marrok / as it was hir auenture
On many a sory mele may she baite
After hir deth / ful ofte may she waite
Er that the wilde wawes / wolde hir drive
Vn to the place / there she shal arive
¶ Men myghte axen / why she was not sleyne
Eke at the feste / who myghte hir body saue
I answere to that demaunde ayeyne
Who saued Danyel in the orrible caue
There eủery wight saf he / maist̉er or knaue
Was with the lioıı̄uns frete / or thei asterte
No wight but god / that he bare in his herte
¶ God leste to shewe / his wonderful miracle
In hir / for she sholde se his myghti werkis
Criste that is / to eủery harme triacle
Bi c̉erteyne meenes ofte as knowen clerkis
Doth thing for c̉erteyne ende / that ful derke is
To mannes witte / that for oure ignoraunce ʳ¶

¶ Now sen she was not / at the feste slawe
Who kept hir fro drenching / in the see
Who kept Ionas / in the fisshis mawe
Til he were spouted vp / at Nineve
Wel may men knowe / hit was no wight but he
That kept the peple Ebraik / from drenchinge
With drie fete / thorughout the see passinge
¶ Who hadde the iiij spirites of tempeste
That power̉e haıı to noyen londe / ⁊and see
Both north ⁊and south ⁊and also west ⁊and Este
Anoyeth nether see / ne londe / ne tre
Sothly the commaunder of that was he
That fro the tempest / ay hshishis woman kepte
As wel whan she woke / as whan she slepte
¶ Where myghte this woman mete ⁊and drynke haue
Thre yere ⁊and more / how lasteth hir vitaile
Who fedde the Egipcian Marie / in the caue
Or in deserte / noon but crist saunce faile
Five thousand folke / it was a grete mervaile
With loues five / ⁊and fisshis two to fede
God sente his foison / at hir grete nede
SHe drivith for the / in oure Occian
Thorughoute the wilde se / til at the laste
Vnder a castel / that nempne I ne can
Fer in Northhumbrelond / the wawes hir caste
And in the sonde / hir shipp steked so faste
That thens nolde it nought / al a tyde
The wil of criste was / that she shulde abide
¶ The constable of this castel / doun is fare
To sen this wrakke / ⁊and al the shipp he soughte
And this wery woman / ful of care
He fonde also the tresoure that she broughte
And in hir langage / mcy she bisoughte
The liff oute of the body for to twynne
Hir to delyuer of woo that she was Inne ¶
¶ A maner latine corrupte was hir speche
But algates therby was she vnderstonde
The constable whan him leste no lenger seche
This wooful woman / brought he to the londe
She kneled doun / ⁊and thonked cristis sonde
But what she was she wolde to noman seye
For foule ne feire / though she sholde deye
¶ She seide she was / so mased in the see
That she forgate hir mynde / bi hir trouthe
The constable of hir hath so grete pite
And eke his wiff / that thei wepen for routhe
She was so diligente withouten slouthe
To sue ⁊and plese eủerych in that place
That alle hir louen / that loken in hir face
¶ The Constable ⁊and dame Hermygeld his wiff
Were payneins / ⁊and that contre eủery where
But Hermegeld loued hir as hir liff
And Custaunce hath so longe soiorned there
In orisoıı̄uns with many a bitter tere
Til Ihus haue conủerted / thorugh his grace
Dame Hermegeld wiff to the Constable of that place
¶ In al that londe no cristen dorst route
Al cristen men / ben fled fro that contre
Thorugh paynenis that conquerid al aboute
The plages of the northe / bi the londe ⁊and the see
To wales fledde the cristianite
Of olde bretons duelling in this Ile
There was here refute for the meene while
¶ But yit nere cristen bretons so exiled
That there nas some in here privite
Honoured crist ⁊and hethen folke begiled
And nyghe the Castel suche there duelte thre
That oon of hem was blynde ⁊and myghte not se
But it were with thilke eyghen of his mynde
With whiche men sen / after thei ben blynde
¶ Bright was the sonne as in the somes day ¶
For which the Constable ⁊and his wiff also
And Custaunce / haue I take the right way
Toward the se / aforlonge wey or two
To pleyen ⁊and romen to ⁊and fro
And in this walke / the blynde men thei mette
Croked ⁊and olde with eyghen faste I shette
¶ In the name of criste / cried this blynde bretoıı̄un
Dame Hermegeld yeue me my sighte ageyne
This lady wex affraide / of the soun
Leste hir housbonde / shortly for to seyne
Wolde hir for ihu cristis loue / haue sleyne
Til Custaunce made hir bolde / ⁊and bad hir wirche
The wil of criste / as dought̉er of his chirche
¶ The Constable wex abasshed of that sighte
And seide what amountith / al this fare
Custaunce answerde / hit is cristis myghte
That helpith folke / oute of the fendis snare
And so forforthe / she gan oure feith declare
That she the Constable / or hit were eeve
Conủerted hath / ⁊and on criste made him bileve
¶ This Constable was not lord / of that place
Of which I speke / there he Custaunce fonde
But kept hit strongly / many a wynt̉er space
Vnder Alla / kyng of Northhumbrelonde
That was ful wise ⁊and worthi / of his honde
Ageine the scottis / as men may wel here
But turne I wil ageyne to my matere
Sathan that euer vs waiteth to begile
Saw of Custaunce / al hir ꝑperfeccioıı̄un
And caste anoon / how he myghte quite hir while
And made a yonge knyght / that duelte in that toun
Loue hir so hoote / of foule affeccioun
That verryly him thoughte he sholde spille
But he of hir / onys myghte haue his wille
¶ He wowith hir / but hit availith nought
She wolde do no synne bi noweye ¶
And for dispite / he compassed in his thought
To make hir on shameful deth to deye
He waiteth whan the Constable was a weye
And privily on a nighte he crepte
In to Hermegeldis chambre whiles she slepte
¶ Wery for waked ihinhn there orisoıı̄uns
Slepte Custaunce / ⁊and hermegeld also
This knyght thorugh sathanas is temptacioıı̄uns
Al softely he is to the bed I go
And kitte Hermegeldis throte atwo
And leide the blody knyff / bi dame Custaunce
And wente his weye / there god yeve him mischaunce
¶ Sone after cometh the Constable hom ageyne
And eke Alla / that was kyng / of the londe
And saw his wiff / dispitously sleyne
For which ful ofte he wepte / ⁊and wronge his honde
And in the bed / the blody knyff he fonde
Bi dame Custaunce / allas what myghte she seye
For verry wo / hir witt was al aweye
¶ To kyng Alla was tolde al this mischaunce
And eke the tyme / ⁊and where ⁊and in what wise
That in a shipp was founden this Custaunce
As ye here aforne / haue herde devise
The kynges herte of pite gan agrise
Whan he saw so benigne a creature
Falle in desese / ⁊and in mysauenture
¶ For as the lambe toward his deth is brought
So stant this innocent / bifore the kyng
This fals knyght that hath this treson wrought
Berith hir on honde that she hath do this thing
But natheles there was grete mornyng
Amonge the peple / ⁊and seiden thei can not gesse
That she had don / so grete a wikkednesse
¶ For thei haue seyne hir / eủere so vertuouse
And lovyng Hermegeld right as hir liff
Of this bare wittenesse eủerych in that house ¶
Saue he that slough Hermegeld with his knyff
This gentil kyng hath caught a grete motiff
Of this wittenes ⁊and thoughte he wolde enquere
Depper in this caas / the trouthe for to lere
¶ Allas Custaunce thow naste no champion
Ne fighte canst thow not so welaway
But he that for oure redempcion
Bounde sathan ⁊and lyth yit there he lay
He be thi stronge champion / this day
For but if criste / open miracle kithe
Withouten gilt thow shalt be sleyne ful swithe
¶ She sett hir doun on knees / ⁊and thus she seidesaideseaide
Immortal god that sauedist Susane
From fals blame / ⁊and thow mciful maide
Marie I meene doughter of seint Anne
Biforne whos childe angels singe Osanne
If I be giltles of this felonye
My socour be or ellis shal I dye
¶ Haue ye not seyne sum tyme a pale face
Amonge apres / of him that hath be ladde
Toward his deth where him get no grace
And suche a colour in his face hath hadde
That men myghte knowe his face that was bistadde
Amonge alle the faces in that route
So stante Custaunce / ⁊and loketh hir aboute
¶ O quenys lynage in prosꝑperite
Duchesses ⁊and ladies eủerychone
Haue som routhe on hir adủersite
An Emꝑperours doughter stant alone
She hath no wight to whom to make hir moone
O blode roial that stondist in this drede
Fer ben thi frendis at thi grete nede
¶ This Alla kyng hath suche compassioun
As gentil herte is fulfilled of pite
That from his eyhen ran the water doun
Now hastily do feche a booke qd he ¶
And if this knyght wol swere how that she
This woman slough yit wil we vs avise
Whom that we wolde that shal be oure Iustice
¶ A breton booke wreten / with the Euuangelises
Was fette / ⁊and on this booke he swore anone
She gilty was / ⁊and in the mene whiles
An honde him smote / vppon the necke bone
That doun he fil atones / as a stone
And both his eyghen borste oute of his face
In sight of eủery body / in that place
¶ A voice was herde / in genal audience
And seide thow hast disclaundred gilteles
The doughter of holy chirche / in high psence
Thus hast thow don / ⁊and yit I holde my pees
Of this mvaile / agast was al the pres
As mased folke / thei stoden eủerychone
For drede of wreche / saue Custaunce alone
¶ Grete was the drede ⁊and eke the repentaunce
Of hem that hadden / wronge suspecion
Vppon this sely innocente Custaunce
And for this miracle / in conclusion
And bi Custaunces / mediacion
The kyng ⁊and many another in that place
Conủerted was / thonked be cristes grace
¶ This fals knyght / was sleyne for his vntrouthe
By iugement of Alla / hastily
And yit had Custaunce / of his deth grete routhe
And after this / Ihus of his mcy
Made Alla wedden / ful solempnely
This holy maiden / that is so bright ⁊and shene
And thus hath criste made Custaunce a quene
¶ But who was woful if I shal not lye
Of this wedding / but Donegild ⁊and nomo
The kyngis moder / ful of tirannye
Hir thoughte hir cursed herte braste atwo
She wolde not hir sone / had doıı̄un so ¶
Hir thought adispite that he sholde take
So strange acreature / vnto his make
¶ Me lest not of the chaff / ne of the stre
Make so longe a tale / as of the corne
What sholde I tellen / of the roialte
Of the mariage / or which cours goth to forne
Who blowith in a trompe / or in an horne
The fruyte of eủery tale / is for to seie
Thei ete ⁊and drinke / ⁊and daunce / ⁊and singe / ⁊and pleie
¶ Thei gon to bedde / as hit was skil ⁊and right
For though that wivis ben / ful holy thinges
Thei most take in pacience / at night
Suche maner necessaries / as ben plesinges
To folke that haue wedded hem / with rynges
And leye alitil / there holynes a side
As for the tyme / it may non other betide
¶ On hir he gate / aman childe anoon
And to a buschip / ⁊and his Constable eke
He toke his wiff to kepe / whan he is goon
To scottelonde ward / his foomen for to seke
Now faire Custaunce / that is so humble ⁊and meke
So longe is gon with childe / til that stille
She holt hir chambre / abidyng cristis wille
¶ The tyme is come / aman childe she on bere
Mauricius at the fonte / thei him calle
This Constable doth forth come a messagere
And wrote to his kyng / that cleped was Alle
How that this blisful tidinges / was bifalle
And other thinges spedful / for to seye
He taketh the letter / ⁊and forth he goth his weye
¶ This messager / to don his auantage
Vn to the kynges moder / rideth swithe
And salueth hir ful faire / in his langage
Madame qd he / ye may be glad ⁊and blithe
And thonken god / an hundred thousand sithe
My lady the quene hath childe withoute doute ¶
To ioy ⁊and blisse / of al this regne aboute
¶ Lo here the lettres selid / of this tithinge
That I mote bere / with al the haste I may
If ye wil ought / vn to youre sone the kynge
I am youre seruaunt / both night ⁊and day
Dame Donegild answerde / at this tyme nay
But here al night I wil / that thow take thi reste
To morow wil I sey the / what me leste
¶ This messager dranke sadly / ale ⁊and wyne
And stolen were his lettres privily
Out of his box / while he slepte as a swyne
And conterfetid was / ful subtily
And other lres wreten / ful synfully
Vnto the kyng directe / of this matere
Fro his Constable / as ye shal after here
¶ The letter spak / how the quene delyủered was
Of so horrible a fendely creature
That in the Castel / noon so hardy nas
That any while dorste / therinne endure
The moder was an Elff / bi auenture
I come by charmes / or bi sorcerie
And eủery wight hateth / hir o companye
¶ Woo was the kyng / whan he this letter had seyne
But to no wight / he tolde his sowesorwesorwe sore
But of his owne honde he wroote / ageyne
Welcome be the sonde of crist / for eủer more
To me that am now / lerned in his lore
Lord welcome be thi lust / ⁊and thi plesaunce
My lust I put al in thin ordynaunce
¶ Kepith this childe / al be hit foule or feire
And eke my wiff / vnto myn hom comynge
Criste whan him list / may sende me an heire
More agreable than this / to my likynge
This lre he seleth / privily wepynge
Which to the messager was taken sone
And forth he goth ther is no more to done ¶
¶ O messager fulfils of dronkennesse
Stronge is thi brethe / thi lemes faltern ay
And thow bewriest / al sekernesse
Thi mynde is lorne / thow Iangelest as a Iay
Thi face is torned / into a newe aray
There dronkenesse regneth / in any route
There is no consaile hid / withouten doute
¶ O Donegild I haue noon englisshe digne
Vn to thi malice / ⁊and thi tirannye
And therfore to the fende / I the resigne
Lat him enditen / thi trayterye
Fy mannysshe fy o nay bigod I lye
Fy fendely spirit / for I dar wel telle
Though thow here walke / thi spirit is in helle
¶ This messager cometh fro the kyng agayne
And at the kyngis moders courte he lighte
And she was of this messager / ful fayne
And plesed him in al that eủer she myghte
He dranke ⁊and wel his girdil vnder pighte
He slepith ⁊and he snowrith in his gise
Al night til the sone gan rise
¶ Efte were his lettres stolen eủerychon
And conterfetid lres / in this wise
The kyng commaundith his Constable anoon
Vp peyne of hangyng / or on high Iewise
That he ne sholde suffre hir / in nowise
Constaunce / withinne his regne to abide
Thre dayes / ⁊and a quarter of a tide
¶ But in the same shipp / as he hir fonde
Hir ⁊and hir yonge sone / ⁊and al hir gere
He sholde putte / ⁊and croude fro the londe
And charge hir / that she neủer efte come there
O my Custaunce / wel may thi goste haue fere
And slepyng in thi drem / ben in penaunce
Whan Donegild / caste al this ordynaunce
¶ This messager on morowe / whan he wooke ¶
Vn to the Castel / halt the nexte way
And to the Constable / he the lett̉er tooke
And whan that he / this pitous lre say
Ful ofte he seide allas / ⁊and welaway
Lord criste qd he / how may this lre endure
So ful of synne / is many a creature
¶ O myghti god / if that it be thi wille
Sith thow art rightful Iuge / how may it be
That thow wolt suffren / innocentis to spille
And wikked folke / regnen in prosꝑperite
O good Custaunce / allas so wo is me
That moot be / thi tormentour or deye
On shames deth / ther is noon other weye
¶ Wepen both yonge ⁊and olde / in al that place
Whan that the kyng / this cursed lre sente
And Custaunce / with a dedly pale face
The ferthe day / toward hir shipp she wente
But natheles / she takith in good entente
The wil of crist / ⁊and knelyng in the stronde
She seide lord / ay welcome be thi sonde
¶ He that me kepte / fro the fals blame
While I was on the londe / amonges yow
He can me kepe / from harm ⁊and eke fro shame
In salt see / al though I se not how
As stronge as eủer he was / he is right now
In him truste I / ⁊and in his moder dere
That is to me / my saile ⁊and eke my stere
¶ Hir litil child / lay weping in hir arme
And kneling pitously to him she seide
Pees litel sone / I wol do the noon harme
With that the couerchief / of hir hede she breide
And oủer his litil eyghen / she it leyde
And in hir arme / she lullith it ful faste
And in to heuen / hir eyghen vp she caste
¶ Moder qd she / ⁊and maiden seint Marie
Soth is that thorugh womannes eggement ¶
Mankynde was lorn / ⁊and dampned ay to dye
For which thi childe / was on a croys I rent
Thi blisful eyghen / saw al his turment
Than is there / no comꝑperison bitwene
Thi wo / ⁊and any wo / man may sustene
¶ Thow saw thi sone slayne / bifore thin eighen
And yit now livith / my litil child ꝑparfaye
Now lady bright / to whom alle woful crien
Thow glorie of womanhode / thow faire maye
Thow haven of refute / bright sterre of the daye
Rewe on my childe / that of thi gentillesse
Rewest on eủery reweful / in destresse
¶ O litil child allas / what is thi gilt
That neủer wroughtest synne yit ꝑparde
Whi wil thin harde fader / haıı the spilt
O mercy dere Constable / qd she
As lat my litil child / duelle here with the
And if thow darst not / kepen him for blame
So kisse him onys / in his fadres name
¶ Ther with she loketh bacward / to the londe
And seide farewel housbonde / routheles
And vp she rist / ⁊and walketh doun the stronde
Toward the ship / hir folwith al the pres
And eủer she praieth hir child / to holde his pees
And takith hir leve / ⁊and with an holy entente
She blisseth hir / ⁊and in to ship she wente
¶ Vitailled was the ship / it is no drede
Habundauntly for hir / ful longe space
And other necessaries / that sholde nede
She had I now / heried be godis grace
For wynde ⁊and weder / almyghti god purchace
And bringe hir hom / I can no better seye
But in the see / she drivith forth hir weye
Alla the kyng / comth hom sone after this
Vn to his Castel / of the which I tolde
And axeth where his wiff / ⁊and his child is ¶
The Constable gan a boute his herte colde
And pleinle al the mane / to him tolde
As ye haıı herde / I can telle it no better
And shewith the kyng his seal ⁊and his letter
¶ And seide lord as ye commaunded me
Vp peyne of deth so haue I don c̉erteyne
This messager turmented was til he
Moost biknowen ⁊and tellen / plat ⁊and pleyne
From night to night / in what place he hath leyne
And thus bi wit / ⁊and subtil enqueryng
Ymagened was / bi whom this harm gan spryng
¶ The honde was knowe / that the lre wroot
And al the venym / of this cursed dede
But in what wise / c̉erteinly I noot
The effecte is this / that Alla out of drede
His moder slow / that may men pleynly rede
For that she traitour was / to hir ligeaunce
Thus endith olde Donegild / with meschaunce
¶ The sorow that this Alla / night ⁊and day
Maketh for his wiff / ⁊and for his child also
Ther is no tonge / that it telle may
But now wil I / vn to Custaunce go
That fletith in the see / in peyne ⁊and wo
Fyve yere ⁊and more / as liked cristis sonde
Or that hir ship / approched to the londe
¶ Vnder an hethen Castel / at the laste
Of which the name / in my texte not I fynde
Custaunce ⁊and eke hir̉e child / the see vp caste
Almyghti god that saueth / al mankynde
Haue on Custaunce / ⁊and hir child som mynde
That fallen is / in hethen honde efte sone
In poynte to spille / as I wol telle yow sone
¶ Down fro the Castel / comth ther many a wight
To gavren on this ship / ⁊and on Custaunce
But shortly fro the Castel / on a night
The lordis steward / god yeve him meschaunce ¶
A theeff that had renyede oure creaunce
Come in to the ship alone / ⁊and seide he sholde
Hir lemman be / where so she wolde or nolde
¶ Wo was this wrecched woman / tho bigoon
Hir child criede / ⁊and she criede pitously
But blisse ful marie / halp hir right anoon
For with hir strogelyng / wel ⁊and myghtily
The theeff fel oủer the bord / al sodeynly
And in the see he dreynte / for vengiaunce
And thus hath crist vnwemmed / kept Custaunce
¶ O foule lust of luxurie / lo thin ende
Not only that thow feyntest / man is mynde
But verryly thow wolt / his body shende
The ende of thi werke / ⁊and of thi lustes blynde
Is compleynyng / how many oon may men fynde
That nought for werke sumtyme / but for thentent
To don this synne / ben eyther sleyne or shent
¶ How may this wayke woman / haıı the strengthe
Hir to defende / ageyne this renegat
O golyas vnmesurable / of lengthe
How myghte Dauid / make the so mat
So yonge / ⁊and of armure / so desolat
How dorst he loke / vppon thi dredful face
Wel may men seen / it was but god is grace
¶ Who yaff Iudith / corage or hardynesse
To slen him Olefernus / in his tent
And to delyủere / out of wrecchednesse
The peple of god / I sey for this entent
That right as god / sprit ⁊and vigor sent
To hem ⁊and saued hem / out of meschaunce
So sent he myght / ⁊and vigour to Custaunce
¶ Forth goth hir ship / thorughout the narwe mouth
Of Iubalter / ⁊and septe drevyng ay
Sumtyme west / ⁊and somtyme North ⁊and south
And sumtyme Est / ful many a wery day
Til cristis moder / that blissed faire may ¶
Hath shapen / thorugh hir endeles goodnesse
To make an ende / of al hir hevynesse
Now late vs stynte of Custaunce / but a throwe
And speke we / of the Romayne Emꝑperour
That out of Surrey / hath bi lres knowe
The slaughter of cristen folke / ⁊and dishonour
Don to his doughter / bi a fals traitour
I mene the cursed wikked souldannesse
That at the feste lete slen / both more ⁊and lesse
¶ For which this Emꝑperour hath sent anoon
His Senatour / with royal ordynaunce
And other lordis / god woot many oon
On Surreyens to taken / high vengeaunce
Thei brennen slen / ⁊and bryngen hem to meschaunce
Ful many a day / but shortly this is thende
Homward to Rome / thei shapen hem to wende
¶ This Senatour repairith with victorie
To Romeward saillyng / ful royally
And mette the ship / drivyng as seith the storie
In whiche Custaunce sitt / ful pitously
No thing ne knewe he / what she was ne why
She was in suche aray / ne she nyl seye
Of hir estate / though she sholde deye
¶ He bringeth hir to Rome ⁊and to his wiff
He yaff hir / ⁊and hir yonge sone also
And with the Senatour / she lad hir liff
Thus can oure lady / bryngen out of wo
Wooful Custaunce / ⁊and many another mo
And longe tyme / duelled she in that place
In holy workes eủer / as was hir grace
¶ The Senatours wiff / hir Aunte was
But for al that / she knewe hir neủer the more
I wil no lenger tarien / in this caas
But to kyng Alla / of whiche I spak of yore
That for his wiff wepith / ⁊and siketh sore
I wil retorne / ⁊and lete I wil Custaunce
Vnder the Senatours goủernaunce ¶
Kyng Alla / which that had his moder slayne
Vppon a day fil in suche repentaunce
That if I shortly tellen shal ⁊and playne
To Rome comth / to resceive his penaunce
And putt him in the popes ordinaunce
In high ⁊and lowe / ⁊and ihu crist bisoughte
For yeve his wikked workes / that he wroughte
¶ The fame anoon / thorugh Rome town is borne
How Alla kyng / shal comen in pilgremage
Bi herbijours / that wenten him biforne
For which the Senatour / as was vsage
Roode him a yeine / ⁊and many of his lynage
As wel to shewen / his high magnificence
As to don any kyng / a reủerence
¶ Grete chere doth this noble Senatour
To kyng Alla / ⁊and he to him also
Eủeryche of hem / doth other grete honour
And so bifil / that on a day or two
This Senatour / is to kyng Alla go
To feste / ⁊and shortly if I shal not lye
Custaunces sone / in his companye
¶ Some men wolde seyne / at the request of Custaunce
This Senatour hath lad this child / to feste
I may not tellen / eủeryche circumstaunce
Be as be may / there he was at the leste
But soth is this / that at his modres heste
Biforn Alla / duryng the mete space
The child stode / lokyng in the kyngꝭes face
¶ This Alla kyng / hath of the child grete wonder
And to the Senatour / he saide anoon
Whos is that faire child / stondeth yonder
I not qd he bigod / ⁊and bi seint Iohn
A moder he hath / but fader hath he non
That I of woot / ⁊and shortly in a stounde
He tolde Alla / how that this child was founde
¶ But god woot qd this Senatour also
So vertuous aliver in my liff ¶
Ne saw I neủere as she / ne herde of mo
Of worldly women / maide ne of wiff
I dar wel sayn / she had leuer a knyff
Thorughout hir breste / than ben a woman wikke
Ther is noman couth brynge hir / to that prikke
¶ Now was this childe / as lik vn to Custaunce
As possible as is a creature to be
This Alla hath the face / in remembraunce
Of dame Custaunce / ⁊and ther on mused he
If that the childis moder / were aught she
That is his wiff / ⁊and pⁱrivily he sighte
And spedde him fro the table / that he myghte
¶ Perfay thought he / the fantome is in myn hede
I oughte to deme / of rightful Iugement
That in the salt see / my wiff is dede
And afterward he made / his argument
What woot I if that crist / hath heder sent
My wiff bi see / as wel as he hir sente
To my contre / fro thens that she was wente
¶ And after noone / hom with the Senatour
Goth Alla for to seen / this wonder chaunce
This Senatour doth Alla / grete honour
And hastily he sende / after Custaunce
But trusteth wel / she lust nought to daunce
Whan that she wiste / where fore was that sonde
Vnnethe vppon hir feet / she myghte stonde
¶ Whan Alla saw his wiff faire he hir grette
And wepte that it was rewthe for to se
For at the firste look he on hir sette
He knewe wel verrily / that it was she
And for sorowe as dombe stant / as a tre
So was hir herte shette in hir distresse
Whan she remembred his vnkyndenesse
¶ Twies she swowned / in his owne sight
He wepe ⁊and him excuseth / pitously
Now god qd he / ⁊and his halowis bright ¶
So wisly on my soule as haue mercy
That of youre harm as giltles am I
As is Maurice my sone / so lik youre face
Ellis the fende me fecche / out of this place
¶ Longe was the sobbyng / ⁊and the bitter peine
Or that there wooful hertis / myghte ceesse
Grete was the pite / for to hire hem pleyne
Thorugh whiche pleyntes / gan here wo encrese
I pray yow alle / my labour to relesse
I may not tellen here wo / vn til to morowe
I am so wery for to speke of there sorowe
¶ But fynally whan that the soth is wiste
That Alla giltles was / of hir woo
I trowe an C tymes / haıı thei kiste
And suche blisse is there / bitwixe hem two
That saue the ioye / that lasteth eủer mo
Ther is noon like / that eny creature
Hath seyne or shal / whiles the world may dure
¶ Tho praide she hir housbond mekely
In relieff of hir longe pitous pyne
That he wolde pray hir fader specially
That of his mageste / he wolde enclyne
To fouch sauff / somday with him todyne
She praide him eke / he sholde bi no weye
Vn to hir fader / no worde of hir seye
¶ Som men wolde sey / how that the child Mauryce
Doth this message / vn to this Emꝑperour
But as I gesse / Alla was nought so nyce
To him that was / of so soủereyne honour
As he that is / of cristen folke the flour
Sente any child / but it is bet to deme
He wente him silff / ⁊and so it may wel seme
¶ This Emꝑperour / hath graunted gentilly
To come to dyner / as he him bisought
And wel rede I / he lokede besily
Vppon this child / ⁊and on his doughter thought ¶
Alla goth to his In / and as him ought
Arraied for his feste / in eủery wise
As ferforth as his konnyng may suffice
¶ The morowe com / ⁊and Alla gan him dresse
And eke his wiff / this Emꝑperour for to mete
And forth thei ride / in ioye ⁊and in gladnesse
And whan she say hir fader / in the strete
She lighte a down / ⁊and fallith him to fete
Fader qd she / youre yonge child Custaunce
Is now ful clene / out of youre remembraunce
¶ I am youre doughter Custaunce / qd she
That whilom ye sente / vn to SurreyeSurryeSurreye
It am I fader / that in the salt see
Was put alone / ⁊and dampned for to dye
Now good fader / mcy I yow crye
Sende me no more / vn to hethenesse
But thonke my lorde here / of his kyndenesse
¶ Who can the pitous ioye / tellen al
Bitwixe hem thre / syn thei ben thus I mette
But of my tale / make an ende I shal
The day goth faste / I wil no lenger̉e lette
This glad folke / to dynere thei hem sette
In ioye ⁊and blisse / at mete I lete hem dwelle
A thousand fold wel more / than I can telle
¶ This child Mauryce / was sithen Emꝑperour
Made bi the Pope / ⁊and leued cristenly
To cristis chirche / he dide grete honour
But I late al hshishis storie / passen by
Of Custaunce is my tale / specially
In olde Romayne gestis / may men fynde
Mauricis liff / I bere it nought in mynde
¶ This kyng Alla / whan he his tyme say
With his Custaunce / his holy wiff so swete
To Engelond ben thei come / the right way
Where as thei live in ioye / ⁊and in quiete
But litil while it lasteth / I yow hete ¶
Ioye of this world / for tyme wil nought abide
Fro day to night / it chaungeth as the tide
Who leued eủere / in suche delite a day
That he ne meved was / either in conscience
Or ire or talent / or somkyn affray
Envie or pride / or passion or offence
I ne say but for this ende / this sentence
That litil while in ioye / ⁊and in plesaunce
Lasteth the blisse of Alla / with Custaunce
For deth that takith / of highe ⁊and lowe his rente
Whan passed was a yere / even as I gesse
Out of this world / this kyng Alla he hente
For whom Custaunce / hath ful grete hevynesse
Now lat vs prayen god / his soule blesse
And dame Custaunce / fynally to seye
Toward the town of Rome / goth hir weye
To Rome is come / this holy creature
And fyndeth hir frendes / hole ⁊and sounde
Now is she scaped / al hir auenture
And whan she hir fader / hath I founde
Down on hir knees / falleth she to grounde
Wepyng for tendernesse / in herte blithe
She herieth god / an C thousand sithe
In vertu ⁊and holy almesdede
Thei leuen alle / ⁊and neủer a sondre wende
Til deth dꝑparte hem / this liff thei lede
And fareth now wel / my tale is at an ende
Now ihu crist / that of his myghte may sende
Ioye after wo / goủerne vs in his grace
And kepe vs alle / that ben in this place

Here endith the man of lawe his tale And
next folwith the Shipman his prolog

And next folwyng he bigynneth his tale ⁊cetc .
A Marchaunte whilom duelt at seint Denys
that riche was for whiche men helde him wis
a wiff he had of excellent beaute
and compenable ⁊and revolous was she
whiche is a thing that causith more dispence
than worthe is al the chere ⁊and reủerence
that men hem don at festes or at daunces
suche salutacions ⁊and countenaunces
passen as don the shadow on a wal
but woo is him / that payen moot for al .
the cely housbonde algates he mot paye
he mote vs clothe ⁊and eke vs araye
al for his owne wourship ful richely
in whiche araye we dauncen Iolilye
¶ And if that he nought paie ꝑparauenture
or ellis list not suche dispence endure
but thenketh it is wasted ⁊and I loste
than mote another payen for oure coste
or lene vs golde ⁊and that is ꝑperilous
this noble marchaunt / helde a noble hous
for whiche he had alday suche repaire
for his largenesse 7 his wiff was faire
that wonder is but herkneth to my tale
amonges alle his gestes grete ⁊and smale .
ther was a monke a faire man ⁊and abolde
I trowe that . xxxᵗⁱ . wynter he was olde
that eủer in on was drawyng to that place
this yonge monke that was so feire of face
aqueynted was so with this good man
sithen that the first knewlech bigan
that in his hous as familier was he
as it is possible any frende to be
and for als moche as the good man
and eke this monke of which that I began
were both two born in oon village
the monke him cleymeth / as for cosynage
and he ageyne seith not ones nay
but was as glad therof as foule of day
for to his herte it was a grete plesaunce
thus ben thei knyt / with eterne alliaunce
and eche of hem gan other for to assure
of brothered whilis there liff may dure
fre was dan Iohn / ⁊and namely of dispence
as in that hous ⁊and ful of diligence
to don plesaunce ⁊and also grete costage
he nought forgate to yeve the leeste page
in al that hous / but after here degre
he yaff the lord / ⁊and sithen al the meyne
whan that he cam / som mane honest thing
for whiche thei were as glad / of his comyng
as foule is fayne / whan the sonne vp riseth
no more of this as now / for hit suffiseth .
But so bifel / this marchaunt on a day
shope him to make redy his array
toward the town of Brugge / for to fare
to byen there / a porcion of ware
for which he hath / to Parys sente anoon
a messager / ⁊and praide hath dan Iohn
that he sholde come / to seint Denys ⁊and pleye
with him / ⁊and with his wiff / a day or tweye
or he to Brugges wente / in alle wise
this noble monke / of whiche I yow devise
hath of his Abbot / as him list licence
bi cause he was aman / of high prudence
and eke an Officer / oute for to ride
to se here granges / ⁊and here bernes wide
and to seint Denys / he cometh anoon
who was so welcome / as my lord dan Iohn
oure dere cosyn / ful of curtesie
with him he brought / a Iubbe of Malmesie
and eke another / ful of good vernage
and volatile / as ay was his vsage
and thus I lete hem ete / ⁊and drinke / ⁊and pleye
this marchaunt ⁊and his monke a day or tweye
the thride day / this marchaunt vp a riseth
and on his nedis / sadly him avisith
and vp in to his countyng hous goth he
to reken with him silff / wel may be
of thilke yere / how that hit with him stoode
and how that he / dispended had his goode
and if that he encresed were / or noon
his bookes ⁊and his bagges / many oon .
he leith biforn him / on his countyng borde
ful riche was his tresour / ⁊and his horde
for which ful faste / his counter he shette
and eke he wolde / that noman him lette
of his acountis / for the mene tyme
and thus he satt / til hit was passed pⁱrime
dan Iohn was risen / in the morow also
and in the gardeyne walketh to ⁊and fro
and hath his thinges seide / ful deuoutly
this good wiff cam walking pⁱrivily
in to the gardeyne there as he walketh softe
and him salueth / as she hath don ofte
amaiden child / cam in hir companye
whiche as she liste / may goủerne ⁊and gye
for yit vnder the yarde / was the maide
o dere cosyn myn / dan Iohn she saide
what eylith yow / so rathe for to rise
nece qd he / hit ought I now suffice
fyve houris to slepe / in oon nighte
but hit were / for an olde palled wighte
as ben these olde wedded men / that lye ⁊and dare
as in a forme sittith / a wery hare
were al for straughte / with houndis grete ⁊and smale
but dere nece / whi be ye so pale
I trowe certis / that oure good man
hath yow forlabourd / syn the night bigan
that ye had nede / to resten hastyly
and with that worde / he lough meryly
and of his owne thought / wex al rede
this faire wiff / gan to shake hir hede
and seide thus / ye god woot al qd she
nay cosyn myn / hit stante not so with me
for bi that god / that yaff me soule ⁊and liff
in al the reme of Fraunce / is ther no wiff
that lasse luste hath / to that sory pleye
for I may synge allas / ⁊and wel aweye .
that I was born / but to no wight qd she
dar I not telle / how that hit stante with me
where fore I thenke / out of this londe to wende
or ellis of my selff / to make an ende
so ful am I / of drede ⁊and of care
this monke bigan / vppon this wiff to stare
and seide allas my nece / god forbede
that ye for eny sorow / or any nede
for do youre silff / but telle me youre greff
ꝑparauenture I may / in youre myschieff
counsaile or helpe ⁊and therfore . telleth me
al youre annoye for it shal secre be
for on my portos / here I make an oothe
that neủer in my liff / for leeff or lothe
ne shal I of no counsail / yow biwrie
the same ageyne to yow / qd she I seie
bi god ⁊and bi this portos / I yow swere
though men me wolde / al in to pecis tere
ne shal I neủer for to go to helle
biwrie on word / of that that ye me telle
nought for no cosynage / ne for allaiunce
but verrily for loue / ⁊and affiaunce
thus ben they sworne / ⁊and here vppon thei kyste
and eche of hem tolde other / what hem liste
Cosyn qd she / if I had a space
as I haue noon / ⁊and namely in this place
than wolde I telle / a legent of my liff
that I haue suffred / sithen I was a wiff
with myn housbonde / al though he be youre cosyne
nay qd this monke / bi god / 7 bi seint Martyne
he nys no more cosyn / vn to me
than is the leef / that hongyth on this tre
I clepe him so by seint Denys of Fraunce
to haue the more cause / of acqueyntaunce
of yow / which I haue loued specially
aboven alle women / sekerly .
this swere I now on my profession
telleth youre greff / lest that he come adoun
and hastith yow / ⁊and go youre wey anoon
my dere loue qd she / O dan Iohn
ful leef were me / this counsail to hide
but out it moot / hit may no lenger abide
¶ Myn housbond is to me / the worste man
that eủer was / sithen the world bigan
but sithe I am a wiff / hit sitte nought me
to telle no wight / of oure pⁱriuete
neither abedde / ne in noon other place
god shulde I sholde telle hit for his grace
a wiff ne sholde not seyne / of hir housbonde
but al honour / as I can vnderstonde
saue vn to yow thus meche I telle shal
as helpe me god / he nys not worth at al
in no degre / the valow of a flye
but yit me greueth most / his nygardie
and wel ye woot / that women naturally
desiryn thinges / als wel as I
thei wolde that ther housbondes / sholde be
hardy ⁊and wise / riche ⁊and ther to fre
and buxum to his wiff / 7 fresshe a bedde
but bi that lord / that for vs alle bledde
for his honour / my silff for to arraye
on sonday next / I moot nedis paye
an hundred Fraunkes / or ellis am I lorne
yet were me lever / that I were vnborne
than me were don sclaunder / or vilonye
and if myn housbonde eke / hit myghte aspie
I nere but I lost / ⁊and therfore I yow preye
lene me this sōmme / or ellis mot I deye
dan Iohn I seie / leue me / this hundred Frankes
ꝑparde I wil not fail yow / me thankes
if that yow list to don / that I yow pray
for at a c̉erteyne day I wil yow pay
and do to yow / what plesaunce 7 suice
that I may do / right as ye can devise
and but I do / god take on me vengeaunce
as foule as eủer had / Genylion of Fraunce
¶ This gentil monke answerde / in this mane
now trewly / my nowne lady dere
I haue on yow qd he / so grete arouthe
that I yow sure / 7 plight yow my trouthe
that whan youre housbonde is / to Flaundres fare
I wol delyủere yow / out of this care
for I wol bringe yow / an hundred Frankes
and with that worde / he caught hir bi the shankes
and hir enbrased harde / 7 kiste hir ofte
goth now youre wey qd he still ⁊and softe
and lete vs dyne as sone / as eủer we may
for bi my chilaundre / hit is pⁱrime of this day
goth now 7 be as trewe as I shal be
now ellis god forbede sir / qd she
and forth she goth / as Ioly as a pye
and bade the cokis / that thei sholde hem highe
so that men myghte dyne / ⁊and that anoon
vp to hir housbond / this wiff is goon
and knokketh at his counter / boldely
que la qd he / peter it am I
qd she / what how longe wil ye faste
how longe tyme wil ye / reken 7 caste
youre somes youre bokis / ⁊and youre thinges
the deuel haue ꝑpart / on al suche rekenynges
ye haue I now qd she / of godis sonde
com doun to day / ⁊and lete youre bagges stonde
ne be ye not a shamed / that dan Iohn
shal fastyng al this day / elenge gon
what lat vs hire masse / 7 go we dyne
wiff qd this man / litil can ye divyne
the corious besynes / that we haue
for of vs chapmen as wis god me saue .
and bi that lord / that cleped is seint yve
scarsely amonges tuelve tweyne thrive
contenuelly lastyng / vn to oure age
we may wel make chere / ⁊and good visage
and drive forth the world / as hit may be
and kepen oure estate / in pⁱriuyte
til we be dede / or ellis that we pleye
on pilgremage / or gon oute of the weye
and therfore haue I grete necessite
vppon this queynte world / to advise me
for eủer more / we mot stonde in drede
of happe ⁊and fortune / in oure chapmanhede
to Flaundres wil I go / to morowe or day
and come ageyne / as sone as eủer I may
for whiche my dere wiff / I the biseke
as be to eủery wight buxum ⁊and meke
and for to kepe oure good / be coriouse
and honestly goủerne wel oure house
thow hast I now / in eủery mane wise
that to a thrifty housholde / may suffice
ye lakke noon arraye / ne no vitaile
of siluer in youre purs / ye shal non faile
and with that worde his counter dore he shette
and doun he goth / no lenger wolde he lette
and hastily / a masse was there seide
and spedily the tablis werre I leide
and to the dyner / faste thei hem spedde
and richely this monke / the chapman fedde
and after dyner / dan Iohn soberly
this chapman toke aꝑparte pⁱriuily
and seide him thus / cosyn hit stante so
that wel I se / to Brugges / wol ye go
god ⁊and seint Austyn / spede yow ⁊and gyde
I pray yow cosyn / wisely that ye ride
goủerneth yow also / of youre diete
attemꝑparally / ⁊and namely in this hete .

div.l: And next sueth the Monkis ꝓprolog .
Whan ended was this tale of Mellibe
And of Prudence . ⁊and hir benignite
Oure Oste seide / as I am feithful man
And bi that precious corpus Madrian
I had leuer than a barel of ale
That good leff my wiff / had herd this tale
For she is nothinge / of such pacience
As was this Mellibeus wiff / prudence
Bi cokkes bones / whan I bete my knavis
She bringeth me the grete clobbed stavis
And crieth sle / the dogges eủerychon
And breke of hem / both bak ⁊and bon
And if that any neighbor / of myne
Wol not in chirche / to my wiff enclyne
Or be so hardy / to hir to trespace
Whan she cometh home / she rampith on my face
And crieth fals coward / wreke thi wiff
Bi corpus bones / I wol haue thi knyff
And thow shalt haue my distaff ⁊and go spynne
Fro day to night / thus wol she bigynne
Allas she seith / that eủer was I shape
To wedde a mylke soppe or a coward ape
That wol ben oủerladde / with eủery wight
Thow darst not stonde bi thi wivis right
This is my liff / but if I wolde fighte
And out at the dore anoon / I mote me dighte
Or ellis I am lost / but if that I
Be like a wilde lyon / foole hardy
I wote wel she wol / do me sle som day
Som neighbor / ⁊and than go my way
For I am ꝑperilous / with knyff on honde
Al be it that I dar nought / hir withstonde
For she is bigge in armes / bi my feith
That shal he fynde / that hir mysdoth or seith
But late vs passe awey / fro this matire
¶ Mi lorde sir monke qd he / beth mery of chere
For ye shul telle a tale trewely
Lo Rouchestre stondith here faste by
Ride forth myn owne lord breke not our game
But bi my trouth / I knowe nat youre name
Whether shal I calle you / my lord dan Iohn
Or dan Thomas / or dan Albon
Of what hous be ye / by youre fader kynne
I vowe to god / thow hast a ful faire skynne
Hit is a gentil pasture / there thow goste
Thow art nat like a penaunte / or a goste
Vppon my feith / thow art some officere
Some worthi sextyne / or some selerere
For bi my fader soule / as to my dome
Thow art a maister / whan thow art at home
No pore cloistrer / ne no novise
But a goủernour̉e worthi ⁊and wise
And therwithal of braunes ⁊and of bonys
A wel faryng ꝑpersone / for the nonys
I pray to god yeve him confusion
That first the brought / in to religion
Thow woldest haue ben / a tredefoule aright
Haddest thow as grete leve as thow hast myght
To ꝑperforme al thi luste / in engendrure
Thow haddest bigeten / many a creature
Alas whi werest thow / so wide a cope
God yeve me sorow / but ⁊and I were a pope
Not only thow / but eủery mighti man
Though he were shore / ful highe vppon his pan
Sholde haue a wiff for al this world is lorne
Religion hath take vp / al the corne
Of tredyng / ⁊and we burel men ben shrympis
Of feble treis / ther comen wrecched ympis
This maketh that oure heyres ben so sklendur
And feble / that thei may not wel engendre
This maketh that / oure wivis / wil assaie
Religious folke / for thei may bett̉er paie
Of venus payment / than may we
God woote no lusshebornes paie ye
But be not wrothe my lord / though that I pleie
Ful ofte in game / a soth I haue herde seie
This worthi monke / toke al in pacience
And seide / I wil do al my diligence
As fer as souneth / in to honeste
To telle yow a tale / or two or thre
And if yow lest / to herken hederwarde
I wol yow seie the liff / of seint Edwarde
Or ellis Tregedies / first wol I telle
Of which I haue an hundred / in my selle
Tregedie is for to telle / a c̉erteyne storie
As olde bookes / maken vs memorie
Of hem that stoode / in grete ꝓprosꝑperite
And ben I falle / out of high degre
In to myserie ⁊and enden wrecchedly
And thei ben versified comenly

In prose eke ben endited many oon
And eke in metre in many sondry wise
Lo this oughte yow I nowe suffice
Now herkeneth / if yow leste for to here
But first I yow biseche / in this matire

After here ages as men wreten fynde
But telle hem some bifore / ⁊and some behynde

Be as be may I wol hir nought a cusen
But on his bak this sherte he wered al nakede
Til that his flessh was of the venym blakede
And whan he saw noon other remedie
In hoote colis he hath him selff rakede
For with no venym deigned / he to dye ;
¶ Thus starff this worthi mighti Ercules
Lo who may truste on fortune eny throwe
For him that foloweth al this world or pres
Or he be ware / is ofte Ileyde ful lowe
Ful wise is he that him selff can knowe
Be warre for whan that fortune luste to glose
Than waiteth she / hir man to oủerthrowe
By suche awey / as he wolde leste suppose ;
The myghti Trone the precious store
The glorious sceptre / ⁊and royal mageste
That had the kyng Nabugodonosore
With tonge vnnethe / may discreved be
He twies wanne Ierusalem / that Cite
The vessellis of the temple / with him he ladde
At Babiloyne / was his soủerayne see
In which his glorie / ⁊and his delite he hadde ;
¶ The feyrest children of the blood royal
Of Ierusalem he lete do gilde anoon
And made eủeryche of hem / to ben his thral
Amonges alle other / Danyel was oon
That was the wiseste childe of eủerychoon
For he the dremes of the kyng expouned
Where as in Caldey / clerk was there noon
That wiste to what fyne / his dremes sowned ;
¶ This proude kyng lete make / a stature of golde
Sixti cubites longe ⁊and sevene in brede
To which ymage / he bothe yonge ⁊and olde

Or in furneyes ful of flammes rede

But neủere wolde assente to that dede
Danyel / ne his yonge felawes tweye ;
¶ This kyng / of kynges proude was ⁊and elate
He wende that god that sitte in mageste
Ne myghte him not bireve of his estate
And sodenly he loste his dignite
And like abeste / him semed for to be
And ete hey as an oxe ⁊and lay ther̉e owte
In rayne with wilde bestes walked he
Til c̉erteyne tyme was comen a bowte ;
¶ And like an Egles fetheres were his heeris
His naylis / like a briddis clawes were
Til god relesed him / a c̉erteyne yeeris
And yaff him witte / ⁊and than with many a tere
He thonked god / ⁊and neủere his liff in fere
Nolde don amys / ne more to trespace
And or that tyme / he leide was on his bere

His sone which that highte Baltasarre
That helde the regne / after his fadris day
He bi his fader / couthe not be warre
For proude he was of herte / ⁊and of array
And eke an ydolastre was he ay
His high estate / assured him in pride
But fortune caste him doun / ⁊and there he lay
And sodenly his regne gan devide ;
¶ A Feste he made vn to his lordes alle
Vppon a tyme / ⁊and made hem blith to be
And thanne his officers / he gan to calle
Goith bringeth forth the vesselles qd he
Which that my fader / in his prosꝑperite

And to our highe godis thonke we
Of honours / that oure eldres with vs laffte ;
¶ His wiff / his lordes / ⁊and his concubynys
Ay dronken / whiles ther̉e appetites laste

And saw an hande armeles / that wrote ful faste
For feere of which / he quoke / ⁊and siked soore
This honde that Balthazar made so sore agaste
Wrote / Mane / Techel . Phares . ⁊and no more ;
¶ In al that londe / Magician was ther noon
That couth expoune / what this lre mente
But Danyel expouned hit anoon
And seide kyng / god vn to thi fader sente
Glorie ⁊and honour / regne / tresoure / ⁊and rente
And he was proude / and nothing god ne dradde
And therfore god / grete wreche vp on him sente
And him beraft / the regne / that he hadde ;
¶ He was out cast / of mannys companye
With Asses was his habitacioıı̄un

¶ Eke thow that art his sone / ⁊and proud also
And knowest al these thinges verryly
And rebel to god ⁊and art his foo
Thow drank eke of his vessels boldely
Thi wiff eke / ⁊and thi wenches synfully
Dronke of the same vessels / sondry wynys

¶ This honde was sente fro god / that on the wal
Wrote Mane. Techel . Phares / truste to me
Thy regne is don / thow weldist it not al
Divided is thi regne / ⁊and hit shal be
To Medes / ⁊and to Perses yeven qd he
And thilke same nikght the kyng was slawe
And Darius ovupied his degre
Though he therto had neither right ne lawe ;
¶ Lordynges hereby / ye may ensample take
How that in lordship is no sekernesse
For whan fortune / wol aman for sake
She bereth awey his regne / ⁊and his richesse
And eke his frendes / bothe more ⁊and lesse
For whan aman hath frendes thorugh fortune
Mys happe wol make hem enemyes as I gesse
This proủerbe is soth / ⁊and ful comune ;
Cenobia of Palamery the quene
As writen Persiens / of hir noblesse
So worthi was in armes / ⁊and so keene
That no wight passed hir / in worthynesse
Ne in lynage / ne in other gentilnesse
Of the kynges blood of Pers / is she dissended
I sey she nadde not / moste fairnesse
But of hir shapp / she might not be amended ;
¶ Fro childehode I fynde / that she fledde
Office of woman / ⁊and vn to woode she wente
And many a wilde hertis blood she shedde
With arowes brode / that she to hem sente
She was so swiffte / that she anoon hem hente
And whan that she was elder̉e / she wolde kille
Lyons ⁊and lyberdes / ⁊and beeres al to rente
And in hir armes welde hem / at hir wille ;
¶ She durst wilde bestis dennys seke
And renne in the mountayns al the nighte
And slepe vnder a bussh ⁊and she coude eke
Wrastlen bi verry force ⁊and mighte
With eny man were he neủere so wighte
Ther mighte nothing in hir armes stonde
She kept hir maidenhode / from eủery wighte
To no man deyned she to be bonde ;
¶ But at the laste / hir frendes han hir maryed
To a nobill a prince of that contre
Al were it so / that she him longe taryed
And ye shal vnderstonde how that he
Hadde such fantacyes as hadde she
But natheles whan they were knette in fere
Thei leveden in ioye ⁊and in felicite
For eche of hem hadde other leve ⁊and dere ;
¶ Save o thing that she nolde neủere assente
By no wey that he sholde bi hir lye
But ones / for it was hir pleyne entente
To haue a childe / the worlde to multiplye
And as sone / as she mighte aspye
That she was not with childe / with that dede
Than wolde she suffre him / to do his fantecye
Eft sone / ⁊and not but ones oute of drede ;
¶ And yiff she were with childe / at thilke caste
No more sholde he pleye / that game
Til fynally . xl . dayes were paste
Than wolde she suffre him / ones do the same
Al were this Prince wilde or tame
He gate no more of hir / but thus she seide
It was to wyves lecherye ⁊and shame
In other caas / if that men with hem pleide ;
¶ Two sones / bi this Prynce had she
The which she kepte in v̉ertu / ⁊and in lettrure
But now vn to oure tale / torne we
I sey that so wourshipful a creature
And wise therwith ⁊and large with mesure
So penyble in the werre / ⁊and curteys eke
Ne more labour myghte in werre endure
Was noon though al this worlde men sholde seke ;
¶ Hir riche array / myghte not be tolde
As wel in vessel / as in clothinge
She was cladde al in perrey / ⁊and in golde
And eke ske laffte not / for noon huntynge
To haue of sondry tonges / folke knowynge
Whan that she leyser hadde ⁊and for to endtende
