How she in v̉ertu mygthe al hir liff dispende ;
¶ And shortly of this storie for to entrete
As doughty was hir housbonde / as was she
That they conquered / manye regnes grete
In the orient / with many a faire Cite
Appertynente / vn to the mageste
Of Rome / ⁊and with stronge honde helde hem faste
Ne neủere myghte there foomen / don hem fle
As longe as liff laste ;
¶ There batayles who so lest to rede
Ageyene Soper the kyng / ⁊and other moo
And how that al the processe / fel in dede
Why she conquered / ⁊and what title hadde ther too
And after of hir myscheff / ⁊and of hir woo
How she was biseged / ⁊and I take
Lete hem vn to my maister Petrake goo
That writeth I now of this / I vndertake ;
¶ Whanne was dede / she myghtily
The regnes helde / ⁊and with hir ꝓpropre honde
Ageyn hir foos she faughte / trwely
That ther nas kyng / ne pⁱrince / in al that londe
That he nas glad / yiff he that grace fonde
That she ne wolde vppon his londe werreye
With hir thei made alliaunce bi honde
To ben in pees / ⁊and lete hir ryde ⁊and pleye ;
¶ The Emꝑperour̉e of Rome Claudeus
Ne him biforn the Romayne Galyene
Ne durst neủere be so coragious
Ne noon Eremyne ne noon Arabyene
Ne Surreyne ne noon Egipciene
Withinne the feldes that durst with hir fighte
Leste that she wolde with hir hondes hem slene
Or with hir meyne put hem to flighte ;
¶ In kynges abite wente hir sones two
As heires of hir regnes alle
And Hermanno ⁊and
Here names were / as ꝑperciens hem calle
But ay hath fortune / in hir hony galle
This myghti quene may no while endure
Fortune oute of hir regne / made hir falle
To wrecchednesse / ⁊and to mysauenture
¶ Aurylyus whan that the goủernaunce
Of Rome come in to his hondes tweye
He shope vppon this quene to do vengeaunce
And with his legioıı̄uns he toke his weye
Toward Cenobye / ⁊and shortly to seye
He made hir fle / ⁊and at the laste hir hente
And fetred hir / ⁊and eke hir children tweye
And wan the londe / ⁊and home to Rome he wente ;
¶ Amonge other thinges / that he wan
Hir chare that wroughte was / with golde ⁊and perre
This grete Romayne / this Avrilian
Hath with him ladde / for that men sholde se
Biforn his Tryumphe / walketh she
With gilte cheynes / on hir necke hongynge
Crowned she was / as afft̉er hir degre
And ful of perre / charged was hir clothinge ;
¶ Allas fortune / she that whilum was
Dredful to kynges / ⁊and to Emꝑperouris
Now gavreth al the peple / on hir allas
And she that helmed was / in starke stouris
And wan bi force townes stronge ⁊and touris
Shal on hir hede now were a wetremyte
And she that bare the sceptre ful of flouris
Shal bere a distaff hir costis for to quyte ;
Al though that Nero / were vicious
As eny fende / that lith ful lowe a doun
Yit he as tellith vs Swetenyus
This wide world hadde / in subieccioun
Both Est / ⁊and west / North / ⁊and Septentreoun
Of Rubies Sapheres / ⁊and perlis white
Were al his clothis enbrowded / vp ⁊and doun
For he in gemmys / gretly gan delite ;
¶ More delicate / ne more pompious of array
More proude was neủere Emꝑperour̉e than was he
Thilke cloth / that he had wered oo day
Afft̉er that tyme he nolde it neủere se
Nettes of golde threde / had he grete plente
To fisshen in Tybre / whan him luste to pleye
His lustes were al lawe / in his decre
For fortune as his frende him wolde obeye ;
¶ He Rome brente / for his delicacie
The Senatouris he slough / vppon a day
To here how men wolde wepe / ⁊and crie
And slough his brother / ⁊and by his suster lay
His moder made he / in pitevous array
For he hir wombe slitte / to biholde
Where he concevied was / so welaway
That he so lite / of his moder tolde ;
¶ No tere out of hise eyghen / for that sighte
Ne cam / but seide / afeire woman was she
Grete wonder is / how that he coude or myghte
Be domysman / of hir dede beaute
The wyne to bringen than comaunded he
And drank anoon / noon oother woo he made
Whan myghte is ioyned / vn to cruelte
Allas to depe / wol the venym wade ;
¶ In youthe a maister hadde this Emꝑperoure
To teche him lettrue ⁊and curtesie
For of moralite he was the floure
As in his tyume / but if bookes lye
And while his maist̉er had of him maistrie
He made him so connynge / ⁊and so souple
That longe tyme it was or tirannye
Or eny vice on him durste vncouple ;
¶ This Seneca / of which that I devise
Bicause that Nero had of him / suche drede
For he for vices / wolde him ay chastise
Discretly as by worde / ⁊and not bi dede
Sir wolde he seyn / an Emꝑperour̉e mot nede
Be vertuous / ⁊and hate tirannye
For which in a bathe / he made him to blede
On both his armes / til he moste dye ;
¶ This Nero had eke of a custumaunce
In youthe / ageyns his maist̉er for to rise
Which afterward him thoughte / a grete greuaunce
Therfore he made him dye / in this wise
But natheles this Seneca / the wise
Ches in a bathe to dye / in this manere
Rather than to haue / mo other turmentise
And thus hath Nero / slayne his maist̉er dere ;
¶ Now fel it so / that fortune leste no lenger
The high pride of Nero / to cherise
For though he were stronge / yit was she strenger̉e
She thoughte thus / bi god I am to nyce
To sette aman that is fulfilled / with vice
In high degre / ⁊and an Emꝑperour̉e him calle
Bi god oute of his seete / I wol him trice
Whan he leste weneth / sonneste shal he falle ;
¶ The peple roos vppon him / on a nyghte
For his defaute / ⁊and whan he it aspiede
Oute at his dores anoon / he hath him dighte
Allone / ⁊and there he wende / han ben alyede
He knokked faste / ⁊and ay the more he criede
The faster shitte they / the dores alle
Tho wiste he wel / he had him selff mys gyede
And wente his wey / no lenger durst he calle ;
¶ The peple criede / ⁊and rombled vp ⁊and doun
That with his eris herde he / how thei seide
Where is this traytour̉e / this fals Neroun
For feere almost / oute of his witte he breyde
And to his godes / pitevously he preyde
For socour / but hit myghte not be tide
For drede of this him thoughte / that he deyde
And ran in to a gardeyn / him selff to hyde ;
¶ And in this gardeyn fonde he / cherles tweye
That seten bi a fire ful grete ⁊and reede
And to these cherles two / he gan to preye
To slen him / ⁊and to gerde of his heede

Of which fortune lovgh / ⁊and made a game ;
Was neủere a Capitayn / vnder a kynge
That regnes mo / putte in subieccioun
Ne strenger was in the felde / in al thinge
As in his tyme / ne gretter of renoun
Ne more pompious / in high psumpcioun
Than Olyferne / which fortune ay kiste
So licorously / ⁊and ladde him vp ⁊and doun
Til that his hede was off / er that he wiste ;
¶ Not oonly that this world / hadde him in awe
For lesyng of richesse / or of liberte
But he made eủery man / renye his lawe
Nabugodonosor / was lord / seide he
Noon other god / sholde honoured be
Ageyns his heeste / no wighte durste trespace
Save in Bethulia / astronge Cite
Where Eliachym a preste was / of that place ;
¶ But take kepe / of the dethe / of Olyferne
Amydde his hoost / he dronke lay a nyghte
Withinne his tente / large as is a berne
And yit for al his pompe / and al his myghte
Iudith a womman / as he lay vp righte

Ful pⁱrivily she stale / from eủery wighte

What nedith it to speke / of kynge Antiochus
To telle his highe / ⁊and royal mageste
His highe pride / his workes venemus
For suche another / was neủere noon as he
Redith what he was / in Machabe
And redith the proude wordes / that he seide
And whi he fel / from highe prosꝑperite
And in an hill / how wrecchedly he deyde ;
¶ Fortune him had / enhaunsed so in pride
That verryly he wende / he myghte atteyne
Vn to the sterres / vppon eủery side
And in balaunce to weye / eche monteyne
And alle the floodes of the see / restreyne
And godes peple / hadde he moste in hate
Hem wolde he sle / in turment ⁊and in peyne
Wenyng that god / ne myghte his pride abate ;
¶ And for that Nichamoure / ⁊and Tymothe
With Iewes were venquysshed / myghtily
Vn to the Iewes / such an hate hadde he
That he bade grete his chare / ful hastily
And swore ⁊and seide / ful dispitously
Vnto Ierusalem / he wolde efft sone
To wreke his Ire on hit / ful cruelly
But of his purpos / he was lette ful sone ;
¶ God for his manace / him so sore smote
With invisible woundes / ay incurable
That in his gottes / carff hit so ⁊and bote
That his peynes / were importable
And certeynly the wreche was resonable
For many mennys gottes dide he peyne
But from his purpos cursed ⁊and dampnable

¶ But badde anoon / apparayle his hoste
And sodenly or he was of hit ware
God daunted al his pride / ⁊and al his boste
For he so sore fel / oute of his chare
That all his lemes ⁊and his skyn to tare
So that he myghte neither goo / ne ride
But in a chayre / men aboute him bare
Al for brused / both backe ⁊and side ;
¶ The wreche of god him smote so cruelly
That thorugh his body / wikked wormes crepte
And therwithal he stanke so orribly
That noon of al his meyne / that him kepte
Whether that he wooke / or ellis slepte
Ne myghte not the stenche of him endure
In this myscheff he wayled / ⁊and eke wepte
And knewe god for lord / of eủery creature ;
¶ To al his hooste / ⁊and to him selff also
Ful fulsome was the stenche / of his careyne
Noman myghte him bere / too ne fro
And in this stenke / ⁊and in this orrible peyne

The storie of Alexandre / is so comune
That eủery wighte / that hath discresioun
Hath herde somwhat / or al / of his fortune
This wide worlde / as in conclusioun
He wan bi strengethe / or for his high renoun

The pride of man / ⁊and beste / he leyde adoun
Where so he cam / vn to the worldes ende ;
¶ Comparison myghte neủere yit noon be maked
Bitwexe him ⁊and another conqueroure
For al this world for dredfe of him / hath quaked
He was of knyghthode / ⁊and of fredom floure

Save wyn / ⁊and wemmen / nothing myghte a swage

¶ What prise were it to him / though that I tolde
Of Darius / ⁊and an hundred thousand moo
Of kynges / Dukes / princes / ⁊and Erles bolde
Which he wonquered / ⁊and brought hem / in to woo

¶ Twelue yere he regned / as seith Macabe

That first was kynge of Grece the contre
O worthi gentil Alexandre / qd he allas
That eủer sholde falle / in such a caas
Empoysened of thyn owne folke / thow were

And yit for the ne wepte she / neủere a tere ;
¶ Who shal yeve me teres / to compleyne
The deth of gentilnesse / ⁊and of franchise
That al this world welde / in his demeyne

So ful was his corage / of highe emprise
Allas who shal me helpe / to endite
Fals fortune ⁊and poyson / to dispice
The which two / of al this wo I wyte ;
By wisdom manhode / ⁊and gret laboure
From humble bed / to royal mageste

That wan al the occident / by londe ⁊and see
By strengthe of hond / or bi trete
And vn to Rome made hem tributarye
And sithen of Rome / Emꝑperour̉e was he

¶ O myghti Cesar that in Thessalye

That of the oriente / hadde al the cheualrye
As fer as the day bigynneth / to dawe
Thorugh thi knyghthode haste hem take ⁊and slawe

¶ But now alitil while / I wol biwayle
This Pompey / this noble goủernoure

¶ To Rome ageyne / repeirith Iulius
With tryumphe / laureate ful highe
But on a tyme / Brutus Casseus
That eủer hadde / of his estate envye
Ful privily hath made conspiracie
Ayenst this Iulyus / in subtil wise
And caste the place / in which he shulde dye

¶ This Iulius / to the Capitole wente

This fals Brutus / ⁊and his other foon

¶ So manly was this Iulius of herte
And so wel loued estately honeste
That though his dedly woundes sore smerte
His mantel oủer his hepes caste he
For noman shulde se / his privite
And as he lay deying / on a traunce
And wiste verrily / that ded he muste be

¶ Lucane vn to this storie / I recomende
And to Sweton / ⁊and to Valerius also

Noman truste / vppon hir favoure longe

This riche Cresus / whilom kyng of Lyde
Of which Cresus / Cirus sore hym dradde
Yit was he caughte / amyd al his pride
And to be brente / men to the fire him ladde
And such arayn / doun fro the welken shadde
That slough the fire / ⁊and made him to escape
But to be ware / no grace yit he hadde

¶ Whan he escaped was / he can not stente
For to bigynne / a newe werre agayne

Of which he was so proude / ⁊and eke so fayne

¶ Vppon a tre he was / as him thoughte
Where Iubiter him wisshe / bothe bak ⁊and side
And Phebus eke / a faire towayle hym broughte
To drye him with / ⁊and therfore wexe his pride
And to his doght̉er that stode him biside
Which that he knewe in highe science habounde
He bade hir telle what hit signefide
And she his dreme bigan right thus expounde ;
¶ The tre qd she the galowes is to meene
And Iubit̉er bitokeneth snowe ⁊and reyne
And Phebus with his towel so clene
Tho ben the sonne stremes for to seyne
Thow shalt an honged be fader certeyne
Rayne shal the wasshe ⁊and sonne shal the drye
Thus warned she him ful plat ⁊and pleyne
His dought̉er / that called was Phanye ;
¶ An honged was Cresus / the proude kynge
His royal trone myghte him not avayle
Tragedie is noon other mane thinge
Ne can in syngynge crye ne biwayle
But for that fortune / alday wol assayle
With vnwar stroke / the regnes that ben proude
For whan men trusteth hir / than wol she fayle ;
And coủere hir bright face with a cloude ;
O noble Petro glorie of Spayne
Whom fortune helde so highe in mageste
Wel oughten men / thi pitous deth complayne
Oute of thi londe / thi brother made the fle
And aft̉er at a sege / bi subtilite
Thow were bitrayede / ⁊and lad vn to his tente
Where as he / with his owne honde slough the
Succeding in thi regne / ⁊and in thi rente ;
¶ The felde of snowe / with the Egle of blak therinne
Caughte with the lymerodde / coloured as the glede
He brewe this cursednes / ⁊and al this synne
The wicked neste was werker / of this nede
Nought Charlis Olyủere / that toke ay hede
Of trouthe ⁊and honour / but of Armoreke
Genylion Olyủere / corupte with mede
Broughte this worthi kynge / in such a wreke ;
O worthi Petro / kynge of Cipre also
That Alexaundre wanne / bi high maistrie
Ful many an hethen wroughtest thow ful wo
Of whiche thin owne liges hadde envie
And for nothing / but for thi Chivalrie
Thei in thi bed han sley the / bi the morowe
Thus can fortune / hir whele goủerne ⁊and guye
And out of Ioye / bringe men in to sorowe ;
OF Melane grete Barnabo Viscounte
God of delite ⁊and skourge of Lumbardye
Whi sholde I not thin infortune a counte
Seth in estate / thow clomben were so highe
Thi brother sone that was thi double allye
For he thi nevewe was ⁊and thi sone in lawe
Withinne his pⁱrison / made the to dye
But whi ne how wote I / that thow were slawe ;
OF hugh Erle of Pyse the Langoure
Ther may no tonge telle for pite
But litel oute of Pyse ther stonte a toure
In which toure in prison put was he
And with him ben his litil children thre
The eldeste skarsly / five yere was of age
Allas fortune / it was grete cruelte
Suche briddes for to putte / in a kage ;
¶ Dampned was he to dye in that prisoıı̄un
For Roger which that Bosshop was of Pise
And on him made a fals suggestioıı̄un
Thorugh which the peple gan on him arise
And putte hem to pⁱrison / in such awise
As ye han herde / ⁊and mete ⁊and drynke he hadde
So smal / that it may vnnethe suffice
And therwithal / hit was ful pore ⁊and badde ;
¶ And on a day bifil / that in that houre
Whan that his mete / wonte was to be broughte
The Gayler shitte the dores / of the toure
He herde hit wel / but he sawe it noughte
And in his herte anoon ther fel a thoughte
That thei for hungre / wolde do him dyen
Allas qd he allas / that I was wroughte
Therwith the teres fel from his eyghen ;
¶ His yonge sone / thre yere was of age
To him seide / fader whi do ye wepe
Whan wol the Gayler / brynger oure potage
Is ther no morsel of brede / that ye do kepe
I am so hungry / that I may not slepe
Now wolde god / that I myghte slepen eủere
Than sholde noon hunger / in my wombe crepe
Ther is nothing / than brede that me were leủere ;
¶ Thus day bi day / the childe gan to crye
Til in his fadris barme / a doun it lay
And seide farewel fader / I mote dye
And keste his fader / ⁊and deyde the same day
And whan his woful fader / dede him say
For wo his armes two / he gan to bite
And seide / allas fortune / ⁊and welaway
Thi fals whele / my wo al / may I wite ;
¶ His children wende / that hit for hungre was
That he his armes gnow / ⁊and not for wo
And seide fader / do not so allas
But rather ete the flessh / vppon vs two
Oure flessh thow yaff vs / take our̉e flessh vs fro
And ete I nough / right thus to him thei seide
And aft̉er that / withinne a day or two
Thei leyde hem doun / in his lappe ⁊and deide ;
¶ Him selff dispeyred eke / for hungre starffe
Thus ended is / this myghti kynge / of Pise
From highe estate / fortune away him carffe
Of this tragedie / it oughte I now suffice
Who so wol hire hit / in a lenger wise
Redeth the grete Poete / of ytayle
That hight Daunte / for he can hit devise
Fro poynte / to poynte / not oo worde wol he fayle ;
HOo sir qd the knyght / no more of this
That ye han seide / is right I now I wis
And meche more / for litil hevynesse
Is right I now / for mechel folke I gesse
Youre talis don vs / no disporte ne game
Therfore Sir Monke / or dan Peris bi your name
I pray yow hertly / telle vs somwhat ellis
For sekerly / nere clynkyng of youre bellis
That on youre bridel honge / on eủery side
Bi heuen kyng / that for vs alle dide
I sholde or this / han fallen doun for slepe
Al though the slough / had neủer ben so depe
Than had youre tale / al be tolde in veyne
For certenly / as these clerkes seyne
Where as a man / may haue noon audience
Nought helpith hit to telle / his sentence
And wel I woote / the substaunce is in me
If any thing / shal wel reported be
Sir sey somwhat of huntynge / I yow preye
Nay qd this monke / I haue no luste to pleye
Now lete another telle vs / as I haue tolde
Than spak oure Oste / with rude speche ⁊and bolde
And seide / vn to the Nonnes prest anoon
Com nere thow prest / com heder thow sir Iohn
Telle vs somthing / that may oure hertis glade
Be mery ⁊and blith / though thow ride on a Iade
What though thin hors / be both foule ⁊and lene
If he wol serue / rekke the not a beene
Loke that thin herte / be mery eủer mo
Yis sir qd he / to his Oste / so mooty go
But I be mery / I wis I wol be blamede
And right anoon / his tale hath he attamede
And thus he seide / to vs eủerychon
This swete prest / this goodly man sir Iohn

l.hi: ere endith the Nonnys prest his ꝓprolog
And next folwyng begynneth his tale

div.l: A poure widowe / somdel stopen in age
Was whilom dwellynge / in a narowe cotage
Biside a grove / stondynge in a dale
This widowe of which I telle yow / my tale
Syn the day / that she was last a wiff
In pacience ladde she / a ful symple liff
For litil was hir catel / ⁊and hir rente
But with housbondrie / ⁊and such as god sente
She fonde hir selff / ⁊and hir doughtren two
Thre large sowis hadde she / ⁊and nomo
Thre keyne ⁊and eke a shepe / that hight Malle
Ful sotty was hir boure / ⁊and eke hir halle
In whiche she ete mony a sclender mele
Of poynaunt sause / hir nedith neủer a del
No deynte morsel / passed thorugh hir throte
Hir dyete was accordyng / to hir cote
Replecion made hir neủere sike
Attempre dyete / was al hir phisike
And excercise / ⁊and hertis suffisaunce
The goute lette hir / nothyng to daunce
Ne replexioıı̄un shente not hir hede
Ne wyn dranke she / neither white ne rede
Hir bord was serued most / with white ⁊and blak
Mylke ⁊and bron bred / in whiche she fonde no lak
Seint bacon / ⁊and somtyme a ney or tweie
For she was / as hit were a maner deye
A gardeyne she had / enclosed al aboute
With stikes / ⁊and a drie diche withoute
In whiche she had a Cokke / that hight Chaunteclere
In al the londe of crowyng / nas his pere
His vois was merier / than the mery orgoon
On masse dayes / that in the chirche goon
Wel sekerer was the crowyng / in his logge
Than is a clokke / or any Abbey orlogge
By nature he crewe / eche ascensioun
Of the Equynoxial / in that toun . ¶preste
For whan degrees .xv. were descended
Than crewe he / that hit myghte not be amended
¶ His Combe was redder / than the fyne coral
And enbatailed / as it were a castel wal
His bele was blak / ⁊and as the geet it shoon
I like azure were his legges / and his toon
His naylis whitter / than the lylye floure
And I like bornysshed gold / was his coloure
This gentil cokke / had in his goủernaunce
Seven hennes / for to don / al his plesaunce
Which were his sisters / ⁊and his ꝑparamoures
And wonder like to him / as of coloures
Of which the feirest hewed vnder hir throte
Was cleped faire damesel ꝑpartelote
Curteys she was / discrete ⁊and debonaire
And compenable / ⁊and bare hir silff so faire
Sithens thilke day / that she was . vij . olde
That truly she hath / the herte in holde
Of Chauntecler / loken in eủery lith
He loued hir so / that wel was him ther with
But suche a Ioye hit was / to hire hem synge
Whan that the bright sonne / bigan to sprⁱnge
In swete accorde / my leff is fare on londe
For thilke tyme / as I haue vnderstonde
Bestes ⁊and briddes / coude speke ⁊and synge
And so bifel / that in the dawnynge
As Chauntecler / amonges his wivis alle
Sat on his ꝑperche / that was in the halle
And next him sat / this faire pertelote
This Chaunteclere / gan gronen in his throte
As a man / that in his dreme / is drecched sore
And whan that ꝑpartelote / thus herde him rore
She was agast / ⁊and seide herte dere
What eylith yow to grone / in this manere
Ye ben a verry slepere / fy for shame
And he answerde ⁊and seide thus / madame ¶The nonnys
I pray yow / that ye take it nought agreff
Bi god me mette / I was in such myscheff
Right now / that yit myn herte is sore a fright
Now god qd he / my sweuen recche aright
And kepe my body . out of foule prison
Me mette / that I romed vp ⁊and don
Withinne oure yerde / where as I saw abeste
Was like an hounde / ⁊and wold haue made areste
Vppon my body / ⁊and wold haue had me dede
His colour was / bitwix white ⁊and rede
And tipped was his tayle / ⁊and both his erees
With blak / vnlike the remenaunt of his heerees
His snowtte smal / with glowyng eyghen tweye
Yit of his looke / for feere almost I deye
This caused me my gronyng douteles
Awey qd she / fy on yow herteles
Allas qd she / for bi that god aboue
Now haue ye loost myn herte / ⁊and al my loue
I can not loue a coward / bi my feith
For certis what so eny woman seith
We alle desiren / if hit myghte be
To haue housbondes / hardy / wise / ⁊and fre
And secre / ⁊and no negarde / ne no foole
Ne him that is agast / of eủery toole
Ne noon avaunttour / bi that god aboue
How durste ye sey for shame / vn to youre loue
That any thing / myghte make yow afeerd
Haue ye no man is herte / ⁊and han abeerd
Allas ⁊and conne ye ben agast / of swevenys
Nothing god woot / but vanite in sweven is
Swevens engendren / of repleciouns
And offte of fume / ⁊and of complexiouns
Whan humoures ben to habundant / in awight
Certis this drem / which ye han mett to nyght
Cometh of the grete suꝑperfluyte
Of youre rede colera parde . ¶prest
Whiche causith folke to dreden / in here dremes
Of arowis / ⁊and of fyres / with rede lemes
Of rede bestes / that wolden hem bite
Of contak / ⁊and of whelpes grete ⁊and lite
Right as the humour of malicolie
Causith many a man / in his slepe to crie
For feere of beeres / ⁊and of booles blake
Or ellis blake deuellis / wold hem take
Of other humoures couthe I telle also
That werken many a man in slepe ful wo
But I wol pas as lightly / as I can
Lo Caton / whiche that was so wise aman
Seide he not thus / ne do no force of dremes
Now sir qd she / whan we fle fro the bemes
For godis loue / as taketh some laxatiff
Vp perel of my soule / ⁊and of my liff
I consail yow the beeste / I wol not lie
That bothe of colour / ⁊and of malicolie
Ye purge yow / ⁊and for ye shul nat tarie
Though in this toun / be noon appoticarie
I shal my silff / to herbes techen yow
That shal be youre hele / ⁊and youre prow
And in youre yerde / two herbes shal I fynde
The whiche haue / of hiere proꝑparte bi kynde
To purgen yow by nethe / ⁊and eke aboue
Foryetith nought this / for godis owne loue
Ye ben ful colerike / of complexion
Ware ye of the sonne / in his ascension
Ne fynde yow replete / of humours hote
For if he do / I dar wel ley a grote
That ye shul haue / a feuer terciane
Or an agw / that may be youre bane
A day or two / ye shul haue digestives
Or wormes / or ye take youre laxatives
Of laureal / Centaure / ⁊and of fumytere
Or ellis of Ellebre / that growith there . ¶The nonnys
Of Captuse / or of Gaytre berijs
Or herbe Ive / growing in oure yerd that mery is
Pek hem vp as thei growe / ⁊and ete hem Inne
Be mery housbond / for your fader kynne
Dredith no dreme / I can sey yow no more
¶ Madame qd he / gromcy of youre lore
But natheles / as touching Daun Caton
That hath of wisdom / such a grete renoıı̄un
Though he bad no dremes for to drede
Bigod men may / in olde bookes rede
Of many a man / more of auctorite
Than eủer Caton was / so mote I the
That al the reủerse seyn / of his sentence
And haue wel founden / bi exꝑperience
That dremes ben significacions
As wel of Ioye / as of tribulacions
That folke enduren / in this liff psente
It nedith not to make of this / noon argumente
The verry preff / shewith hit in dede
Oon of the grettest auctours / that men rede
Seith thus / that whilom two felawes wente
On pilgremage / in ful good entente
And happid so / thei comen in to a toun
Where as ther was / such congregacioun
Of peple / ⁊and eke of streite herbigage
That they ne fonde / as meche as on cotage
In whiche thei both / myghte I logged be
Wherefore thei mosten / of necessite
As for that night / deꝑparten companye
And eche of hem goth / to his Ostelerye
And toke his loggyng / as it wolde falle
That oon of hem was logged / in a stalle
Ferre in ayerd / with oxen of the ploughe
That other man was logged / wel I noughe
As was his auenture / or his fortune
That vs goủerneth alle / as in comune . ¶prest
And so bifil / longe or hit were day
This man mette in his bedde / there as he lay
How that his felawe / gan on him calle
And seide allas / for in an oxes stalle
This night shal I be murdred / there I lye
Now helpe me dere brother / or I dye
In al haste com to me / he seide
This man out of his slepe / for fere abreide
But whan that he was waked / of his slepe
He turned him / ⁊and toke of this no kepe
Him thoughte his dreme / nas but a vanite
Thus twies in his sleping / dremed he
And at the thride tyme / yit his felawe
Cam as him thoughte / ⁊and seide I am now slawe
Biholde my blody woundes depe / ⁊and wide
Arise vp erly / in the morow tide
And at the west gate of this toun / qd he
A carte ful of donge / there shaltow se
In whiche my body is hid / ful pⁱrivily
Do that Carter areste / boldely
My gold caused my mordre / soth to sayne
And told him eủery poynt / how he was slayne
With a ful petous face / pale of hewe
And trust wel this dreme / he fonde ful trewe
For on the morow / as sone as it was day
To his felawes In / he tooke the way
And whan he cam / to this oxis stalle
Aft̉er his felawe / he bigan to calle
The hostelere answerd him anoon
And seide / sir youre felaw is goon
As sone as day / he wente out of this toun
This man gan falle / in grete susspecioun
Remembryng on his dremes / that he mette
And forth he goth / no lenger wold he lette
Vn to the west gate of the toun / ⁊and fonde
A donge Carte / as he wente to donge the londe . ¶The nonnys
That was arrayed / in the same wise
As ye han herde / the dedeman devise
And with an hardy herte / he gan to crie
Vengeaunce ⁊and iustice / of this felonye
My felawe mordred is / this same nyght
And in this Carte he lieth / gaping vpright
I crie oute on the mynystres / qd he
That sholde kepe ⁊and rule / this Cite
Harow allas / here lieth my felawe sleyne
What shulde I more / vn to this tale seyne
The peple out sterte / ⁊and caste this carte to grounde
And in the myddis of the donge / they founde
The dedeman / that mordred was al newe
O blisful god that art / so iuste ⁊and trewe
Lo how thow biwreyest mordred alway
Mordre wol out / that se we day bi day
Mordre is so odious / ⁊and so abhomynable
To god that is so iust / ⁊and so resonable
That he wol not suffre / it hid to be
Though hit abide a yere / or two / or thre
Mordre wol out / this is my conclusioun
And right anoon / the mynystres of the toun
Han hente the Carte / ⁊and so sore him pynede
And eke the hosteler / so sore engynede
That thei biknewe / here wikkednes anon
And were an honged / bi the necke bon
Here men may se / that dremes ben to drede
And certis in the same booke / I rede
Right in the same next chapitre / aft̉er this
I gabbe not / so haue I ioye or blis
¶ Two men that wolde han passed / oủer the se
For c̉erteyne cause / in to a ferre contre
If that the wynde / ne had ben contrarie
That made hem in a Cite / for to tarie
That stode ful mery / vppon a haven side
But on a day / agayne the even tide . ¶prest
The wynde gan change / ⁊and blew as hem leste
Ioly ⁊and glad thei wenten / vn to reste
And casten hem / ful erly for to saile
But herken how that . oo man / fel in grete mvaile
That oon of hem / in sleping as he lay
Him mette a wonder dreme / ayenst the day
Him thoughte / aman stode / bi his beddis side
And him commaunded / that he shulde abide
And seide him thus / if thow to morowe wende
Thow shalt be dreynte / my tale is at anende
He woke ⁊and told his felawe / what he mette
And praide him / his viage for to lette
As for that day he praide him / to abide
His felawe that lay / bi his beddis side
Gan for to laughe / ⁊and scorned him ful faste
No dreme qd he / may so myn herte agaste
That I wol lette / for to do my thinges
I sette nought a strawe / bi thi dremynges
For sweuens ben but vanitees / ⁊and iapes
Men dreme alday / of owlis ⁊and of apes
And of many a maase / therwith al
Men dreme of thing / that neủer be ne shal
But sithen I se / that thow wolt here abide
And thus forslowthen / wilfully the tide
God woot hit rewith me / ⁊and haue goodday
And thus he tooke his leve / ⁊and went his way
But er that he hadde / halff his cours I sailed
Not I nought whi / ne what meschaunce it eyled
But casuelly the shippes botme rente
And shipp ⁊and man / vnder the wat̉er wente
In sight of other shippes / him be side
That with him sailed / at the same tide
And ther fore feire ꝑpartelote so dere
Bi suche ensamples olde / may ye lere
That no man shulde be / to recheles
Of dremes / for I sey the douteles . ¶The nonnys
That many a dreme / ful sore is for to drede
¶ Lo in the liff / of seint kenelme / I rede
That was kenulphes sone / the noble kyng
Of merturike / how kenelme mette a thing
Alitel or he was mordred / on a day
His mordre / in his avision he say
His norice him expowned eủerydel
His sweuen / ⁊and bad him to kepe him wel
Fro treson / but he was but seven yere olde
And therfore litel tale hath he tolde
Of eny dreme / so holy was his herte
Bigod I had leuer / than my sherte
That ye had herde his legende / as haue I
Dame ꝑpartelote / I sey yow trewely
Macrobeus that writt / the avision
In Affrike / of the worthi Cipion
Affermeth dremes / ⁊and seith that thei bene
Warnyng of thinges / that men aft̉er sene
And fer ther more I pray yow / loketh wel
In the olde testament / of Danyel
If he helde dremes / eny vanite
Rede eke of Ioseph / ⁊and there shul ye se
Whether dremes ben / somtyme I say not alle
Warnyng of thinges that shul aft̉er falle
¶ Loke eke of Egipte / the kyng daun Pharao
His baker / ⁊and his boteler also
Where thei ne felte noon effecte / in dremes
Who so wol seke actes / of sondry Revmes
May rede of dremes many a wonder thing
¶ Lo Crisus / which that was of Lyde kyng
Mette he not he satte / vppon a tre
Which signefied / he shulde an honged be
¶ Lo here Adromacha / Ectoris wiff
That day that Ector / shulde lese his liff
She dremed on the same night biforne
How that the liff of Ector / shulde be lorne ¶prest
If thilke day he wente / in to bataile
She warned him / but it myght not availe
He wente for to fighte / natheles
But he was sleyne / of Achilles
But that tale is al to longe / to telle
And eke it is nygh day / I may not dwelle
Shortly I sey / as for conclusion
That I shal haue / of this avision
Adủersite / ⁊and I sey ferthermore
That I ne telle / of laxatives no store
For thei ben venemous / I woot it wele
I hem diffie / I loue hem neủeradele
Now lete vs speke of merthe / ⁊and steynte al this
Madame ꝑpartelete / so haue I blis
Of oo thing god hath sente me / large grace
For whan I se the beaute / of youre face
Ye ben so scarlet rede / aboughte your eyghen
Hit makith al my drede / for to dyen
For also seker / as Inprincipio
Mulier est hominis confusio
Madame the sentence of this latyn is
Woman is mannys ioye / ⁊and his blis
For whan I fele on nyghtꝭes / youre soffte side
Al be hit that I may not / on yow ride
For that oure ꝑperche is made so narow allas
I am so ful of ioye / ⁊and of solas
That I diffie both sweuen / ⁊and dreme
And with that worde / he fligh doun fro the beme
For it was day / ⁊and eke his hennes alle
And with a chukke / he gan hem for to calle
For he had founde a corne / lay in the yerde
Roial ye was / ⁊and no more aferde
He fethered ꝑpartelote / twenty tyme
And drade as ofte / or it were pⁱrime
He lokith as hit were / a grym lyoun
And on his toes / he romed vp ⁊and doun ¶The nonnys
Him deigned not / to sette his fete / to grounde
He chukked whan he hath a corne I founde
And to him than ran / his wives alle
Thus royal is he / as a prince in his halle
Leve I this Chaunteclere / in his pasture
And after wol I telle / of his auenture .
Whan that the Monthe / in which the world bigan
That hight Marche / whan god first made man
Was complete / ⁊and passed were also
Sethen Marche bigan .xxxᵗⁱ. dayes ⁊and two
Bifel that Chaunteclere / in al his pride
His .vij. wives walkyng / him beside
Caste vp his eyghen / to the bright sonne
That in the signe of Taurus / had I ronne
Twenti degrees ⁊and on / ⁊and som what more
And knewe bi kynde / ⁊and bi noon other lore
That hit was pryme / ⁊and crew with blisful steuen
The sonne he seide is clomben / vppon heuen
Fourti degrees ⁊and on / ⁊and more I wis
Madame ꝑpartelote / my worldis blis
Herkeneth how these blisful briddis singe
And se the fressh flouris / how thei springe
Ful is myn herte of reuel / ⁊and solas
But sodeynly him fel / a sorowful caas
For eủer the latter ende of Ioye / is woo
And comunely / ofte tyme it fallith soo
And if a Rothour / coude faire endite
He in Cronycle myghte safly write
As for a souerayne notabilite
Now eủery wise man / herken to me
This storie is as trewe / I vnder take
As is the booke / of launcelote de lake
That women helde / in ful grete reủerence
Now wol I torne agayne / to my sentence
A Col fox ful of slight / ⁊and iniquite
That in the grove had woned / yeres thre . ¶prest /
By high ymaginacion / aforn caste
The same nyght / thorugh the hegge stiges braste
In to the yerd / ther Chauntecler the faire
Was wonte ⁊and eke his wives / to repaire
And in abed of wortes / stille he lay
Til hit was passed vndern / of the day
Waityng his tyme / on Chauntecler to falle
As gladly don / these homycides alle
That in awaite ligen / to murdre men
O fals mordrer / roukyng in thi den
O newe scariote / o newe Genylion
O fals dissimulour / o greke Synoun
That broughte Troy / al outt̉erly to sorowe
O Chaunteclere / a cursed be that morowe
That thow in to the yerd fligh / fro the bemes
Thow were ful wel warned / bi thi dremes
That thilke day was ꝑperilous / vn to the
But what that god afore woot / mot nedis be
After the opynyon / of certeyne clerkis
Witnes of him / that any clerke is
That in scole / is grete altercacion
In this matire / ⁊and grete disputacion
And hath ben / of many an thousand man
But I ne can not bulte hit / to the bran
As can the holy doctour / Augustyne
Or Boece / or the busshop Bradwardyne
Whether that godis worthi / a forewetyng
Streyneth me nedely / for to do a thing
Nedely clepe I / symple necessite
Or ellis if the fre choise / be graunted me
To do that same thing / or to do it nought
Though god forewoot hit / or I was wrought
Or if his wetyng / streyneth neủeradel
But bi necessite / condicionel
I wol not haue to don / in suche matire
My tale is of a Cocke / as ye shullen here . ¶The nonnys
That toke his counsaile / of his wiff with sorowe
To walken in the yerd / vppon the morowe
That he had mette the dreme / that I yow tolde
Wommens counsail / ben ful ofte colde
Wommens counsail / brought vs first to woo
And made Adam / from paradise to goo
There as he was ful mery / ⁊and wel at ease
But for I woot not / whom I myghte displease
If I counsail of women / wold blame
Passe oủer for I seide hit / in my game
Rede auctours where thei trete of suche matire
And what thei seyne of women ye may here
These ben the Cokkes wordes / ⁊and not myne
I can non harm / of no woman divyne
¶ Faire in the sonde / to bath hir merily
Lith ꝑpartelote / ⁊and alle hir sustres by
Ageyne the sonne / ⁊and Chauntecler so fre
Songe meriere / than the Meremaide in the see
For Phisialogus saith witterly
How that thei syngen wel / ⁊and merily
And so bifel / how that he cast his eyghe
Amonges the wortes / vppon abotterflighe
He was war of this fox / that lay ful lowe
Nothing list him thanne / for to crowe
But cried anoon cok cok / ⁊and vp he sterte
As a man that was affrayed / in his herte
For naturally abest / desireth to fle
Fro his contrarie / if he may hit se
Though he neủer erst / had sei hit with eyghe
This Chauntecler / whan he him gan aspie
He wolde haue fled / but the fox anoon
Seide gentil sir allas / wheder wol ye goon
Ben ye affrayed of me / that am youre frende
Certis I were worse than a fende
If I to yow wold harm / or vilonye
I am not come / youre counsail to espie /¶Prest .
But trewly the cause / of my comynge
Was only to herken / how that ye synge
For trewly ye han as mery a steuen
As any āngel hath / that is in heuen
Therwith ye haue in musike / more felynge
Than had Boece / or eny that can synge
My lord youre fader / god his soule blesse
And eke youre moder / of hir gentilnesse
Han in myn hous I ben / to my grete ease
And certis sir / right fayn wolde I yow please
But for men speke of syngynge / I wol seye
So mot y broke wel / myn eyghen tweye
Saue yow I herde neủer man so synge
As dide youre fader / in the mornynge
Certis hit was of herte / al that he songe
And for to make his vois / the more stronge
He wolde so peyne him / that with both his eyghen
He moste wynke / so loude he dide crien
And stonden on his tiptos / therwith al
And strecche forth his necke / longe ⁊and smal
And eke he was / of such discrescion
That ther nas no man / in no region
That him in songe or wisdom / myghte pas
I haue wel radde in Daun Burnel there as
Amonge his vers / how that ther was a cokke
For a prestis sone yaff him a knokke
Vppon his legg / while he was yonge ⁊and nyce
He made him for to lese his benefice
But c̉erteyn ther is no comꝑperisoun
Bitwixe the wisdom / ⁊and discrescioun
Of youre fader / ⁊and of his subtilite
Now syngeth sir / for seint charite
Lete se conne ye / youre fader counterfete
This Chauntecler his wynges gan to bete
As man that coude his treson nat aspie
So was he ravisshed / with his flaterie . ¶The nonnes
Allas ye lordis / many a fals flaterour
Is in youre Courte / ⁊and many a lesingour
That plesen yow wel more / bi my feith
Than he that sothfastnes / vn to yow seith
Redith Ecclesiast / of flaterie
Beth war ye lordis / of hir trecherie
This Chauntecler stode highe / vppon his tois
Strecching his necke / ⁊and helde his eyghen clois
And gan to crowe loude / for the nonys
And Daun Russel the Fox / sterte vp at onys
And bi the gorget / hente Chaunteclere
And on his backe / toward the woode him bere
For yit was ther noman / that him sewede
O destenye / that maist not be eschewede
Allas that Chauntecler / fligh fro the bemes
Allas his wiff / roughte nought of dremes
And on a Friday fel / al this meschaunce
O Venus that art goddes / of plesaunce
Syn that thi suaunte was this Chaunteclere
And in thi suyce / dide al his powere
More for delite / than the world to multiplie
Whi woldest thow suffre him / on thi day to die
O Gaulfride dere maister soủerayne
That whan thi worthi kyng / Richard was slayne
With shotte compleynedist his deth / so sore
Whi ne hadde I now thi sentence / ⁊and thi lore
The Friday for to chide / as dide ye
For on a Friday / shortly sleyne was he
Than wold I shewe yow / how that I coude pleyne
For Chauntecleris drede / ⁊and for his peyne
Certis suche crie / ne lamentacioun /
Was neủer made of ladies / whan that Ylioun
Was wonne / and Pirrus with his streight swerde
Whan he hent kyng Priam / bi the berde
And slow him / as seith vs Eneyedos
As maden alle the hennes / in the cloos ¶prest
Whan thei had seyne of Chauntecler the sighte
But soủereynly Dame ꝑpartelote shrighte
Wel lodder than dide Asdrubales wiff
Whan that hir housbond / had lost his liff
And that the Romayns / had brente Cartage
She was so ful of turment / ⁊and of rage
That wilfully / into the fyre she sterte
And brente hir silff / with a stedfast herte
O wooful hennys / right so criden ye
And when that Nero / brente the Cite
Of Rome / criden the Cenatours wivis
For that here housbondes / shulde lese there livis
Withouten gilt / this Nero hath hem sleyne
Now wol I turne / to my tale ageyne
This cely widowe / ⁊and hir doughtres two
Herden the hennes crien / ⁊and maken wo
And out at the dore / sterten thei anoon
And saw the Fox / toward the grove goon
And bare on his backe / the cokke away
And criden out ⁊and harow / ⁊and wel away
A . ha the Fox / ⁊and after him thei ran
And eke with stavis / many a nother man
Ran Colle oure dogg / Talbot ⁊and eke Garlande
And Malkyn with a distaff / in hir hande
Ran Cow ⁊and Calff / ⁊and eke the verray hogges
Sore a ferde / for berkyng / of the dogges
And shovtyng of the men / ⁊and women eke
They ran so / hem thoughte there herte breke
They yolleden as fendis don in helle
The dogges criden / as men wolde hem quelle
The gees for fere / fleu oủer the trees
Oute of the hyve / cam the swarme of bees
So hidous was the noise / a benedicite
Certis Iak Straw / ⁊and his meyne
Made neủer shovtes / halff so shille
Whan that thei wolde / eny flemyng kylle ¶The nonnes .
As thilke day was made / vppon the Fox
Of bras thei broughte bemes / ⁊and of box
Of horn ⁊and bon / in whiche thei blew ⁊and povpede
And therwithal / thei shriched ⁊and hovpede
Hit semed as thei heuen / shulde falle
Now good men I pray yow / herkeneth alle
LO how fortune turneth sodeynly
The hope ⁊and eke the pride / of hir enemy
This cokke that lay / vppon the Foxes bakke
In al his drede / vn to the Fox spakke
And seide / sir if I were as ye
Yit wolde I seie / as wis god helpe me
Turne ageyne / ye proude chorles alle
A verray pestilence / vppon yow falle
Now am I come / vn to this woodis side
Maugre youre hede / the cokke shal here abide
I wol him ete in feith / ⁊and that anoon
The Fox answerde ⁊and seide / hit shal be doon
And as he spak that worde / al sodeynly
This cokke brake fro his mouthe / delyuerly
And highe vppon a tre / he fleigh anoon
And whan the Fox saugh / that he was goon
Allas qd he / O Chaunteclere allas
I haue qd he / doon to yow trespas
In as meche / as I made yow aferde
Whan I yow hente / ⁊and broughte out of the yerde
But sir I dide hit / in no wicked entent
Com doun ⁊and I shal telle yow / what I ment
I shal sey soth to yow / god helpe me so
Nay than qd he / I shrewe vs both two
And first I shrewe my silff / both bloode ⁊and bonys
If thow bigile me / eny ofter than onys
Thow shalt no more / with thi flaterie
Make me synge / ⁊and wynke with myn eighe
For he that wynketh / whan I he sholde se
Al wilfully / god lete him neủer I the . ¶prest
Nay quod the Fox / god yiff him myschaunce
That is so vndiscrete / of goủernaunce
That Iangelith / whan he shuld haue pees
Lo what it is / to be rechelees
And necligent / ⁊and trust on flaterie
But ye that holden this tale a folie
As of a Fox / of a cokke / ⁊and of an hen
Takith the moralite / good men
For seint Poule seith / al that wreten is
To oure doctⁱne / it is writen I wis
Taketh the fruycte / ⁊and lete the chaff be stille
Now good god / if that hit be thi wille
As seith oure lorde / so make vs alle good men
And bringe vs / to his highe blis Amen .

div.l: (base) ⁊and bigynneth the Secund Nonnes Tale of Seynt Cecile with oute a ꝒProloge
(base) The Ministre and the norice vnto vices
(base) Which that men clepeth in englissh ydelnesse
(base) That porter at the gate is of delices
(base) To eschuen and by hir contrarie hire oppresse
(base) That is to seyn by leueful bisynesse
(base) Wel oghte we to doon al oure entente
(base) Lest that the feend thurgh ydelnesse vs hente
(base) For he that with his thousand cordes slye
(base) Continuelly vs wayteth to biclappe
(base) Whan he may man in ydelnesse espye
(base) He kan so lightly cacche hym in his trappe
(base) Til that a man be hent right by the lappe
(base) He nys nat war the feend hath hym in honde
(base) Wel oghte vs werche and ydelnesse withstonde
(base) And thogh men dradden neuere for to dye
(base) Yet seen men wel by reson doutelees
(base) That ydelnesse is roten slogardye
(base) Of which ther neuere comth no good nencrees
(base) And seen that slouthe hir holdeth in a lees
(base) Oonly for to slepe and ete and drynken

div.l: (base) And to deuouren al that othere swynken
(base) And for to putte vs from swich ydelnesse
(base) That cause is of so greet confusioun
(base) I haue here doon my feithful bisynesse
(base) After the legende in translacioun
(base) Right of thy glorious lyf and passioun
(base) Thow with thy gerland wroght of rose and lilie
(base) Thee mene I mayde and martir Seinte Cecilie
(base) And thow that flour of virgines art alle
(base) Of whom that Bernard list so wel to write
(base) To thee at my bigynnyng I first calle
(base) Thow confort of vs wrecches do mendite
(base) Thy maydens deeth that wan thurgh hir merite
(base) The eternal lyf and of the feend victorie
(base) As man may after reden in hir Storie
(base) Thow mayde and moder doghter of thy sone
(base) Thow welle of mercy synful soules cure
(base) In whom that god for bountee chees to wone
(base) Thow humble and heigh ouer euery creature
(base) Thow nobledest so ferforth oure nature
(base) That no desdaign the makere hadde of kynde
(base) His sone in blood and flessh to clothe and wynde
(base) With Inne the Cloistre blisful of thy sydis
(base) Took mannes shap the eternal loue and pees
(base) That of the tryne compas lord and gyde is
(base) Whom erthe and see and heuene out of relees
(base) Ay heryen and thow virgyne wemmelees
(base) Bar of thy body and dweltest mayde pure
(base) The creatour of euery creature
(base) Assembled is in thee Magnificence
(base) With mercy goodnesse and swich pitee
(base) That thow that art the sonne of excellence
(base) Nat oonly helpest hem that prayen thee
(base) But ofte tyme of thy benygnytee

(base) Thow goost biforn and art hir lyues leche

div.l: (base) Now help thow meke and blisful faire mayde
(base) Me flemed wrecche in this desert of galle
(base) Thynk on the womman Cananee that sayde
(base) That whelpes eten somme of the crommes alle
(base) That from hir lordes table been yfalle
(base) And thogh that I vnworthy sone of Eue
(base) Be synful yet accepte my bileue
(base) And for that feith is deed withouten werkis
(base) So for to werken yif me wit and space
(base) That I be quyt from thennes that moost derk is
(base) O thow that art so fair and ful of grace
(base) Be myn Aduocate in that heighe place
(base) Ther as withouten ende is songe Osanne
(base) Thow cristes moder doghter deere of Anne
(base) And of thy light my soule in prison lighte
(base) That troubled is by the contagioun
(base) Of my body and also by the wighte
(base) Of erthely lust and fals affeccioun
(base) O hauene o refut o sauacioun
(base) Of hem that been in sorwe and in distresse
(base) Now help for to my werk I wol me dresse
(base) Yet praye ich yow that reden that I write
(base) Foryeue me that I do no diligence
(base) This ilke storie subtilly to endite
(base) For bothe haue I the wordes and sentence
(base) Of hym that at the Seintes reuerence
(base) The storie wroot and folwen hir legende
(base) And pray yow that ye wol my werk amende
(base) As ferforth as god wyl me grace sende
(base) First wolde I yow the name of Seinte Cecilie
(base) Expowne as men may in hir storie se
(base) It is to seyn on englissh heuenes lilie
(base) For pure chastnesse of virginitee
(base) Or for she whitnesse hadde of honestee

div.l: (base) For she ensample was by good techynge
(base) Or ellis Cecile as I writen fynde
(base) Is ioyned by a manere conioignynge
(base) Of heuene and lia and here in figurynge
(base) The heuene is set for thoght of holynesse
(base) And lia for hir lastynge bisynesse
(base) Cecile may eek be seyd in this manere
(base) Wantynge of blyndnesse for hir grete light
(base) Of sapience and for hir thewes clere
(base) Or ellis lo this maydenes name bright
(base) Of heuene and leos comth for which by right
(base) Men myghte hire wel the heuene of peple calle
(base) Ensample of goode and wise werkes alle
(base) For leos peple in englissh is to seye
(base) And right as men may in the heuene see
(base) The sonne and moone and sterres euery weye
(base) Right so men goostly in this mayden free
(base) Sayen of feith the magnanymytee
(base) And eek the cleernesse hool of Sapience
(base) And sondry werkes brighte of excellence
(base) And right so as thise Philosophres write
(base) That heuene is swift and round and eek brennynge
(base) Right so was faire Cecile the white
(base) Ful swift and bisy euere in good werkynge
(base) And round and hool in good perseuerynge
(base) And brennyng euere in charite ful brighte
(base) Now haue I yow declared what she highte
(base) Here endith the Second Nonnys prolog
(base) And here begynneth the tale
(base) This mayde bright Cecilie as hir lyf seith
(base) Was come of Romayns and of noble kynde
(base) And from hir Cradel vp fostred in the feith
(base) Of crist and baar his gospel in hir mynde
(base) She neuere cessed as I writen fynde
(base) Of hir prayere and god to loue and drede
(base) Bisekyng hym to kepe hir maydenhede

div.l: (base) And whan this mayden sholde vn til a man
(base) Ywedded be that was ful yong of age
(base) Which that ycleped was Valerian
(base) And day was comen of hir mariage
(base) She ful deuout and humble in hir corage
(base) Vnder hir robe of gold that sat ful faire
(base) Hadde next hir flessh yclad hire in an haire
(base) And whil that the Organs maden melodie
(base) To god allone in hir herte thus soong she
(base) O lord my soule and eek my body gye
(base) Vnwemmed lest that I confounded be
(base) And for his loue that deyde vpon the tree
(base) Euery seconde and thridde day she faste
(base) Ay biddyng in hir orisons ful faste
(base) The nyght cam and to bedde moste she gon
(base) With hire housbonde as ofte is the manere
(base) And priuely to hym she seyde anon
(base) O swete and wel biloued spouse deere
(base) Ther is a conseil and ye wolde it heere
(base) Which that right fayn I wolde vnto yow seye
(base) So that ye swere ye shul it nat biwreye
(base) Valerian gan faste vnto hir swere
(base) That for no cas ne thyng that myghte be
(base) He sholde neuere mo biwreyen here
(base) And thanne at erst to hym seyde she
(base) I haue an Aungel which that loueth me
(base) That with gret loue wher so I wake or slepe
(base) Is redy ay my body for to kepe
(base) And if that he may feelen out of drede
(base) That ye me touche or loue in vileynye
(base) He right anon wol sleen yow with the dede
(base) And in youre youthe thus ye shullen dye
(base) And if that ye in clene loue me gye
(base) He wol yow loue as me for youre clennesse

(base) This Valerian corrected as god wolde

div.l: (base) Answerde agayn if I shal trusten thee

(base) And if that it a verray Aungel be
(base) Thanne wol I doon as thow hast prayed me
(base) And if thow loue another man for sothe
(base) Right with this swerd than wol I sle yow bothe
(base) Cecile answerde right in this wise
(base) If that yow list the Aungel shal ye se
(base) So that ye trowe on crist and yow baptise
(base) Goth forth to Via Apia quod she
(base) That fro this town ne stant but Milys thre
(base) And to the poure folkes that ther dwellen

(base) He foond this holy olde Vrban anon

(base) The teerys from hise eyen leet he falle
(base) Almyghty lord o Ihu crist quod he
(base) Sowere of chaast conseil hierde of vs alle
(base) The fruyt of thilke seed of chastitee
(base) That thow hast sowe in Cecilie taak to thee

div.l: (base) As meke as euere was any lamb to yow

(base) Whan he this old man sawe standing so

(base) O lord o feith o god withoute mo

In erthe in eyre in water man swynke
To geten a gloton / deynte mete ⁊and drynke
Of this matire O Poule wel canst thou trete
Mete vn to wombe wombe eke vn to mete
Shal god distroyen both as Paule vs seith
Allas a foule thing it is / bi my feith
To say this worde ⁊and fouler is the dede
Whan man so drynketh of the white ⁊and rede
That of his throte he makith his privite
Thorugh that high cursed suꝑperfluyte
The Appostel weping / seith ful petously
Ther walken many / of which told haue I ¶
I seie it now weping with a pitous voice
Ther ben enemyes of cristis croice
Of whiche the ende is deth for wombe is here god
O wombe O baly O foule stinking cod
Fulfilled of donge ⁊and of corrupcione
At either ende of the / foule is the sowne
How grete cost ⁊and labour is hit to fynde
These cokes how thei stampe streyne ⁊and grynde
And turne substaunce in to accidente
To fulfille al thi likerous talente
Out of the harde bones / knokke they
The mary for thei cast it not awey
That may go thorugh the golet soffte ⁊and soote
Of spicerie of leves / barke ⁊and roote
Shal ben his savse I made bi delite
To maken him yit a newe appetite
But certis he that haunteth suche delices
Is deed whils that he levith in tho vices
A lecherous thing is wyne / ⁊and dronkenesse
It is ful of strivyng / ⁊and of wrecchidnesse
O dronken man / al disfigured is thi face
Sowre is thi breeth foule artow to enbrace
And thorugh thi dronken nose / sowneth thi soun
As though thou seidist ay Sampson Sampsoun
And yit god woot Sampson dronke neủer wyne
Thou fallest as it were / a dronken swyne
Thi tonge is lost ⁊and al thin honest cure
For dronkenesse is verray sepulture
Of man is witt ⁊and his discrecion
In whom that drynke hath dıı̄unacion
He can no counsail kepe it is no drede
Now kepe yow fro the white / ⁊and fro the rede
And namely fro the white wyne of lepe
That is to selle in fissh strete / ⁊and in Chepe
This wyne of Spayne crepith subtilly
In other wynes / growyng faste by ¶
Of which ther risith suche fumosite
That whan aman hath dronke draughtes two or thre
And wenyth that he be at home in Chepe
Than is he in Spayne / at the toun of Lepe
Not at the Rochel / ne at Burdieux toun
Than wol thei seie / Sampson Sampsoun
But herkeneth lordinges I yow pray
That alle the soủerayne actes / dar I say
Of victories in the oolde testament
That thorugh verray god / that is omnipotent
Were don in abstinence ⁊and in prayere
Loketh the bible / ⁊and there ye may it lere
Loke Attilla the grete conquerour
Deide in his slepe / with shame ⁊and dishonour
Bleding at his nose in dronkennesse
A Capitayne shuld live / in soburnesse
And oủer al this avisith yow right wel
What was commaunded / vn to Lamuel
Not Samuel / but Lamuel seie I
Redith the bible / ⁊and fyndith it expressely
Of wyne yevyng / to hem that haue Iustice
No more of this for it may wel suffice
And now that I haue speken of glotenye
Now wol I defende yow hasardie
Hasarde is verray moder of lesinges
And of disceite ⁊and cursed forsweringes
Blaspheme of crist manslaught̉er ⁊and wast also
Of catel ⁊and of tyme ⁊and ferthermo
Hit is repreff / ⁊and contrarie to honour
For to ben holden a comune hasardour
And eủer the highere he is of estate
The more is he holden disolate
If that a ꝓprorince vse hasardie
In al goủernaunce ⁊and policie
He is as bi comune oppinion
Holde the lasse / in reputacion ¶
that was holde awise enbassiatour
Was sente in to with ful grete honour
Fro Lacedomye / to make hire aliaunce
And whan he cam happed this chaunce
That al the grettest / that were of that londe
Pleying at the hasard he hem fonde
For whiche as sone / as hit myghte be
He stale him home ayen / to his contre
And seide there wil I not lese my name
I wol not take on me / so grete diffame
For to allye yow / to noon hasardoures
Sendith other wiser Enbassiatous
For bi my trouth / me were leủere die
Than I shuld yow / to hasardours alie
For ye that ben so glorious in honomres
Shal not allie yow / with hasardoures
As by my wil / ne as bi my trete
This wise Philosᵒphre / thus seide he
¶ Loke eke that to the kyng Demetryus
The kyng of Partes / as the booke seith vs
Sente him a peire of dies of gold / in skorne
For he had vsed hasardie / there biforne
For whiche he helde his glorie / ⁊and his renoun
At no valowe / of eny reputacioun
Lordis may fynde / other mane pley
Honest I now / to drive the day a wey
Now wol I speke of othes / fals ⁊and grete
A worde or two / as olde bookes entrete
Grete sweryng is a thing abhomynable
And fals sweryng / is mech more reꝓprovable
The high god forbad sweryng / at al
Witnesse of Matheu / but in especial
Of sweryng seith the holy Ieromye
Thow shalt swere sooth thin othes / ⁊and not lye
And swere in doome / ⁊and eke in rightwisnesse
But ydel sweryng / is a cursednesse ⁊and¶
Beholde ⁊and se that in the first table
Of high godis hestes most honourable
How that the seconde heste of him / is this
Take not my name in ydelnesse amys
Lo rather he forbedith the sweryng
Than homycide / or many a cursed thing
I seie as bi ordre thus it stondith
This knowe thei / that his hestes vnderstondith
How that the seconde heste of god is that
And ferther oủer I wil the telle al plat
That vengeaunce shal not deꝑparte / from his hous
That of his othes / is so foule outragious
Bi godis precious herte ⁊and bi his naylis
And bi the blood of crist that is in haylis
Seven is my chaunce ⁊and thin is synke ⁊and treye
Bi godis armes if thou falsly pleye
This dagger shal thorugh thin herte goo
This fruyte cometh of this cursed bones twoo
For sweryng Ire falsnesse ⁊and homycide
Now for the loue of crist / that for vs dide
Leueth youre othes both grete ⁊and smale
For I shal telle yow a merveilous tale
These riatoures thre of which I telle
Long erst or pⁱrime ronge of any belle
Were sette in a taủerne for to drynke
And as thei sate they herde a belle clynke
Biforn a corps was caried to his grave
That oon of hem gan calle to him his knave
Goo bet qd he ⁊and aske redily
What corps is this that passeth forth by
And loke that thow repoorte his name wele
Sir qd this boy / it nedith neủer a dele
Hit was me tolde er ye cam here two houres
He was ꝑparde an olde felawe of youres
Al sodeynly he was slayne this nyght
For dronke as he sat on his benche vpright ¶
Ther cam a previ cheeff men callen deth
That in this contre al the peple sleth
And with his spere he smote his herte a two
And wente his wey withoute wordes mo
He hath a thousand sleyne this pestilence
And maister er ye come in his psence
Me thenketh that it were necessarie
For to be war of suche an adủersarie
Beth redy for to mete him eủermore
Thus taughte me my dame / I seie nomore
Bi seint Marye seide this Taủernere
The childe seith soth for he hath sleyn this yere
Hens oủer a myle / withinne a grete vilage
Both man ⁊and woman hyne child ⁊and page
I trow that his habitacion be there
To be wel avised grete wisedome it were
Or that he do aman adishonoure
Ye godis armes qd this riatoure
Is it suche ꝑperel with him for to mete
I shal him seke bi dale ⁊and bi strete
I make a vow bi godis digne bones
Herkenth felowes we thre thre ben al ones
Lete eche of vs hold vp his honde to other
And eche of vs bi come otheris brother
And we wol sle this fals traitour deth
He shal be sleyne that so many sleth
Bi godis dignite er hit be nyght
To gedre han these thre here trouthes plight
To live ⁊and die eche of hem with other
As thowgh he were his owne born brother
And vp thei sterten / al dronken in this rage
And forth thei goon toward that vilage
Of whiche the Taủernere spake biforn
And many a grisly othe than han thei sworn
And cristes blissed body they to rente
That deth shal be deed if thei may him hente . ¶
Whan thei had goon not fully a myle
Right as thei wolden haue troden oủer a stile
An olde pore man with hem mette
This olde man ful mekely hem grette
And seide thus now lordes god yow se
The proudest of these riatoures thre
Answerd ageyne what cherle with harde grace
Whi artow al forwrapped / saue thi face
Whi livest thou so longe / in so grete age
This olde man gan loke in his visage
And seide thus for I can not fynde
A man though that I walked in to Inde
Neither in Cite ne in no mane vilage
That wil changen his youth for myn age
And therfore moty haue myn age stille
As longe tyme as it is godis wille
Ne deth allas ne wol not haue my liff
Thus walke I I like a recheles caytiff
And on the grounde which is my moder gate
I knoke with my staff both erly ⁊and late
And seye leve moder lete me inne
Lo how I wanyssh flessh blood ⁊and skynne
Allas whan shul my bones ben at reste
Moder with yow wolde I change my cheste
That in my chambre longe tyme hath be
Ye for an heyre cloutte to wrappe in me
But yit to me she wil not do that grace
For which ful pale ⁊and welkid is my face
¶ But sirs to yow it is no curtesie
To speken to an oolde man vilonye
But he trespace in worde / or ellis in dede
In holy write ye may your silff wel rede
Ayenst an olde man hoor vppon his hede
Ye shul arise therfore I yeve yow rede
Ne doth to an olde man harme as now
No more than ye wolde a man dede yow ¶
In age if ye so longe may abide
And god be with yow / where so ye go or ride
I most go theder as I haue to goo
Nay olde cherle bi god / thou shalt nat soo
Seide this other hasardour anoon
Thou ꝑpartist nat so lightly bi seint Iohn
Thou spake right now / of thilke traitour deeth
That in this contre alle oure frendes sleeth .
Haue here my trouthe thow art his aspie
Telle where he is or ellis thow shalt die
Bi god ⁊and bi the holy sacramente
Ful truly thow art oon of his assente
To slen vs yonge folke / thow fals theeff
Now sirs if it be to yow so leeff
To fynde deth turne vp this croked wey
For in that grove I lefft him bi my fey
Vnder a tre ⁊and there he wol abide
Ne for youre boost he nyl him nothing hide .
Se ye that ooke right there ye shul him fynde
God save yow that boughte ayen mankynde
And yow amende thus seide this olde man
And eủereche of these riatours fast ran
Til thei come to the tre / ⁊and there thei founde
Floreyns of fyne gold / I koyned rounde
Wel nygh an seven busshels / as hem thoughte
No lenger than after deeth / thei ne soughte
But eche of hem so glad was of that sight
For the floreyns / were so feire ⁊and bright
That doun thei sette hem / bi this pcious horde
The worst of hem / he spake the first worde
Brithren qd he take kepe what I seie
My witte is grete though that I borde ⁊and pleye
This tresoure hath fortune to vs yeven
In merthe ⁊and iolyte / oure liff to liven
And lightly as it cometh so wil we spende
Ey godis pcious herte who wende . ¶ꝑpar
Today that we shulde haue had so feire a grace
But myghte this gold be caried fro this place
Home to myn hous or ellis vn to youres
For wel I woot that al this golde is oures
Than were we / in high felicite
But truly bi day hit may nat be
Men wolde seie / that we were thevis stronge
And for oure owne tresoure / don vs honge
This tresoure mot be caried bi nyghte
As wisely ⁊and as slighly / as we myghte
Wherfore I rede / that Cutt amonges vs alle
We drawe / ⁊and lete se where the Cutt wol falle
And he that hath the Cutt with herte blithe
Shal renne to toune / ⁊and that ful swithe
To bringe vs brede ⁊and wyne / ful pⁱrivily
And two of vs shul kepen / ful subtilly
This tresoure wel / ⁊and if he wol nat tarie
Whan it is night / we wil this tresoure carie
Bi oon assente where as vs likith beste liste
That oon of hem / the cutt brought in his fiste
And bade hem drawe / ⁊and loke where it wol falle
And it fel on the yongest / of hem alle
And forth toward the toune / he wente anoon
And also sone as he was agoon
That oon of hem spake / vn to that other
Thou knowest wel / thou art my sworn brother
Thi profite wol I telle the anoon
Thou wost wel / that oure felawe is goon
And here is gold / ⁊and that ful grete plente
That shuld I ꝑparted be among vs thre
But natheles if I con the shap hit so
That hit deꝑparted were among vs two
Had I nat don / a frendes turne to the
That other answerde / I note how that myghte be
I wolde wel that the gold / were oures two
What shulde we do that it myghte be so . ¶
Shal hit be counsaille / seide the first shrewe
And I shal tellen it / in wordes fewe
What we shul don / ⁊and bringe it wel aboughte
I graunte qd that other / out of doute .
That bi my trouth / I wil the not biwreyene
Now qd the first / thou wost wel we ben tweyne
And two of vs / shul strenger be than oon
Loke whan he is sette / ⁊and that anoon
Arise as though thou woldest / with him pleye
And I shal rive him / thorugh his sides tweye
Whils that thou strogelest with him / as in game
And with thi dagger / loke thou do the same
And than shal al this gold / deꝑparted be
My dere frende / bi twix the ⁊and me
Than may we booth / oure lustes fulfille
And pleye at the dyse / at oure owne wille
And thus accorded ben / these shrewes tweye
To slen the thride as ye herde me seye
The yongest / which that wente to the toun
Ful offt in his herte / he rolled vp ⁊and doun
The beaute of these floreyns / newe ⁊and brighte
O lord qd he if so were that I myghte
Haue al this tresoure / to my silff allone
Ther is no man / that livith vnder the Trone
Of god / that shuld live so mery as I
And at the last / the fende oure enemy
Put in his thought / that he shulde poyson beye
With which he myghte / slen his felawes tweye
For whi the fende fonde him / in suche livynge
That he had leve / him to sorow bringe
For this was outerly / his entent
To slen hem both / ⁊and neủer to repent
And forth he gothe / no lenger wold he tarie
In to the toun vnto a poticarie
And praide him / that he wolde him sille
Some poyson that he myghte his rattes kille ¶ꝐPar
And eke ther was a polkat in his hawe
That as he seide / his Capons had I slawe
And seide he wolde a wreke him if he myghte
On vermyn / that distroyed him bi night
The Poticarie answerde / ⁊and seide thou shalt haue
A thing that als wis god / my soule save
In al this world / ther nys no creature
That eete or drynke of this confecture
Nat but the mountaunce of a corne of whete
That he ne shal anoon / his liff forlete
Ye sterve he shal / ⁊and that in lasse while
Than thou wolt goon / the space of halff a myle
This poyson so stronge / ⁊and violent
This cursed man / hath in his honde it hent
And put it in a box / ⁊and sithens he ran
In to the nexte strete / vn to aman
And borowith him / large botelles thre
And in the two / the poyson poured he
The thride he kepte clene / for his drynke
For al the nyght / he shope him to swynke
In cariyng of that gold / out of that place
And whan this Riatour with sory grace
Had fillid with wyne / his grete botels thre
To his felawes / ayen repairith he
¶ What nedith hit / to sermon therof more
For right as thei had cast his deth bifore
Right so thei han him sleyn / ⁊and that anoon
And whan this was don / than spake that oon
Now lete vs sitte ⁊and drynke / ⁊and make vs merie
And afterward we wol / his body burie
And with that worde / hit happed them ꝑparcaas
To take the botel / in which the poyson was
And dranke / ⁊and yaff his felawe drynke also
Thorugh whiche anon / thei sterven / bothe two
But certis I suppose / that a
Wrote neủere ¶
Mo wondre signes of enpoysenyng
Than had these wrecches two / at here endyng
Thus ended ben / these homycides two
And eke this fals enpoysener also
O cursed synne / of al cursednesse
O traitours / O homycides o wikkednesse
O gloteny / luxurie ⁊and hasardie
Thow blasphemour of crist with vilonye
And othes grete of vsage / ⁊and of pride
Allas mankynde / how may hit be tide
That to thi creatour / whiche that the wroughte
And with his pcious blood / the boughte
Thow art so fals ⁊and so vnkynde allas
Now gode men god for yeve yow / youre trespas
And kepe yow fro the synne of avarice
Myn holy ꝑpardoıı̄un may yow alle warisshe
So that ye offre nobles / or sterlinges
Or ellis silủere spones / broches / or ringes
Bowith youre hede / vnder this holy bulle
Cometh vp ye wivis offre ye wolle
Youre names I entre / in my rolle anoon
In to the blisse of heuen / shulle ye alle goon
¶ I yow assoile / bi myn high powere
Ye that wollen offre as clene ⁊and as clere
As ye were born / ⁊and lo sirs thus I preche
And ihıı̄un crist that is oure soules leche
So graunte he yow / his ꝑpardoıı̄un to resceive
For that is best / I wol yow nat disceive
But sirs o worde forgate I / in my tale
I haue relikes ⁊and ꝑpardoıı̄un / in my male
As faire as any man in Engelonde
Whiche were me yeven bi the Popes honde
If any of yow / wil of deuocion
Offren ⁊and haue myn absolucion
Cometh forth anoon / ⁊and knelith here adoun
And mekely resceivith my ꝑpardoun ꝐPar
Or ellis taketh pardon / as ye wende
Al newe ⁊and fresshe / at eủery mylis ende
So that ye offren alway newe ⁊and newe
Noblis or pans / whiche that ben good ⁊and trewe
Hit is honour to eủerych that is here
That ye may haue a sufficiaunt ꝑpardonere
To assoile yow in contre as ye ride
For auentures / which that may betide
For ꝑparauenture ther may falle oon / or two
Doun of his hors ⁊and breke his necke a two
Loke whiche a surete it is to yow alle
That I am / in youre felawship I falle
That may assoile yow / both more ⁊and lasse
Whan that the soule / shal fro the body passe
I rede that oure Ost shal newe bigynne
For he is most envolupte / in synne
Cometh forth sir Ost / ⁊and offre first anoon
And thow shalt kisse / the relikes eủerychoon
Ye for a grote vnbocle anoon thi purs
Nay nay qd he / than haue I godis curs
Lete be qd he / it shal nat be so theche
Thow woldist make me / to kisse thin olde breche
And swere hit were a relike of a seinte
Though it were / with thi fundement I peynte
But bi the croice / that Seint Elyne fonde
I wolde I had thi coilyons in myn honde
In stede of relikes / or of Seintuarie
Lete kitte hem off / I wol helpe the hem carie
Thei shul be shryned / in an hogges torde
This ꝑpardoner answerd / nat oon worde
So wroth he was / he wolde no worde seye
Now quod oure Ost / I wil no lenger pleye
With the / ne with noon other angry man
But right anoon / the worthi knyght bigan
Whan that he saw / that al the peple lough
No more of this / for it is right I nowgh ¶
Sir ꝑpardoner he seide / be glad ⁊and mery of chere
And ye sir Ost / that ben to me so dere
I pray yow that ye kisse / the ꝑpardonere
And Pardonere I pᵃy yow / drawe yow nere
And as we dide / lete vs laugh ⁊and pleye
n thei kissed / ⁊and riden forth here weye ;

endith the ꝑpardonere his tale . And next
gynneth the Frankeleyns ꝓprologo .
(base) Here bigynneth the Frankeleyns tale
(base) Thise olde gentil Britons in hir dayes
(base) Of diuerse auentures maden layes
(base) Rymeyed in hir firste Briton tonge
(base) Whiche layes with hir Instrumentz they songe
(base) Or ellis redden hem for hire plesaunce
(base) And oon of hem haue I in remembraunce
(base) Which I shal seyn with good wyl as I kan
(base) But sires by cause I am a burel man
(base) At my bigynnyng first I yow biseche
(base) Haue me excused of my rude speche
(base) I lerned neuere Rethorik certeyn
(base) Thyng that I speke It moot be bare and pleyn
(base) I sleep neuere in the Mount of parnaso
(base) Ne lerned Marcus Tullius Scithero
(base) Colours ne knowe I none withouten drede
(base) But swiche colours as growen in the mede
(base) Or ellis swiche as men dye or peynte
(base) Colours of Rethoryk they ben to queynte
(base) My Spirit feeleth nat of swich matere
(base) But if yow list my tale shul ye heere
(base) Heere bigynneth the Frankeleyns tale ~
(base) Ther was a knyght that louede and dide his payne
(base) In Armorik that called is Britayne
(base) To serue a lady in his beste wise
(base) And many a labour many a gret emprise
(base) He for his lady wroghte er she were wonne
(base) For she was oon the faireste vnder Sonne

div.l: (base) And eek ther to come of so heigh kynrede
(base) That wel vnnethes dorste this knyght for drede
(base) Telle hire his wo his peyne and his distresse
(base) But atte laste she for his worthynesse
(base) And namely for his meke obeysance
(base) Hath swich a pitee caught of his penance
(base) That priuely she fel of his acord
(base) To taken hym for hir housbonde and hir lord
(base) Of swich lordshipe as men han ouer hir wyues
(base) And for to lede the moore in blisse hir lyues
(base) Of his fre wyl he swoor hire as a knyght
(base) That neuere in al his lyf he day ne nyght
(base) Ne sholde vpon hym take no maistrye
(base) Agayn hir wyl ne kithe hire Ialousye
(base) But hire obeye and folwe hir wyl in al
(base) As any louere to his lady shal
(base) Saue that the name of soueraynetee
(base) That wolde he haue for shame of his degree
(base) She thonked hym and with ful gret humblesse
(base) She seyde sire sith of youre gentilesse
(base) Ye profre me to haue so large a reyne
(base) Ne wolde neuere god bitwix vs tweyne
(base) As in my gilt were outher werre or stryf
(base) Sire I wol be youre humble trewe wyf
(base) Haue heer my trouthe til that myn herte breste
(base) Thus been they bothe in quiete and in reste
(base) For o thyng sires saufly dar I seye
(base) That freendes euerich oother moote obeye
(base) If they wol longe holden compaignye
(base) Loue wol nat be constreyned by maistrye
(base) Whan maistrie comth the god of loue anon
(base) Beteth his wynges and farwel he is gon
(base) Loue is a thyng as any spirit free
(base) Wommen of kynde desiren libertee
(base) And nat to been constreyned as a thral
(base) And so doon men if I sooth seyn shal

div.l: (base) Looke who that moost is pacient in loue
(base) He is at his auantage al aboue
(base) Pacience is an heigh vertu certeyn
(base) For it venquysseth as thise clerkes seyn
(base) Thynges that rigour sholde neuere atteyne
(base) For euery word men may nat chide or pleyne
